                                    Committee on Military Affairs.
                            

                        
                        
                             AFTERNOON SESSION. 
                            Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's, bill (17) to so amend the misdemeanor act
                                of June 14, 1852, as better to protect the bodies of the dead,
                                coming up on the second reading - 
                            On motion by Mr. RITTER, it was referred, to a select committee of
                                five, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Ritter,
                                Hamilton, of Boone, Firestone, Sullivan and Gifford.
                            Mr. TURPIE'S bill (18) to repeal the Game Law, coming up - 
                            Mr. PARRETT moved to refer it to a select committee of five.
                            Mr. TURPIE objected to the reference of so plain a proposition.
                            Mr. DAVIS understood there was a diversity as to the time when game
                                may be killed, and hoped the bill would not now be put upon its
                                passage. The law had certainly operated to protect quails,
                                &c.
                            Mr. MELLETT had been entrusted with a petition for some modification
                                of the game law, which at the proper time he hoped would be referred
                                to the same committee, who should consider the bill. He also
                                objected to the re-seal of the law.
                            Mr. TURPIE insisted that no modification of the law could be made
                                without destroying ts principle - the most odious - principleof
                                jiving half the fine to the informer.
                            Mr. DAVIS. Why not strike out the objectionable feature?
                            Mr. TURPIE. Because that could not be lone without invalidating the
                                act. I move to ay the amendment on the table, and demand he yeas and
                                nays.
                            Mr. DAVIS. And the bill also.
                            Mr. DOBBINS demanded a division of the question.  The first question being on laying the
                                bill on the table, was determined by yeas 38, nays 5 - as follows: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Black, Bowman, Boxley,
                                            Brotherton, Carr, Claypool, Clayton. Cotton, Davis,
                                            Dougherty, Edwards, Firestone, Fordyce, Gifford,
                                            Gregory, Hancock,Jeffries, Johnston, Keefer, Lawhead,
                                            Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Murray, Nebeker, of
                                            Vermillion, Nebeker, of Warren. Scott, Sherman, Snyder.
                                            Stanfield, Stiles, Thompson, of Elkhart, Thompson, of
                                            Madison,Treadway,Waterman, and Mr. Speaker 38. 
                                        NAYS Messrs. Austin, Blythe, Boyd,
                                            Cavins. Clark, Clements, Colgrove, Collier, Comstock,
                                            Davidson, Dobbins, Durham. Devol, Early, Griffin, Hall,
                                            of Grant, Hall, of Rush, Hamilton, of Boone, Hamilton,
                                            of Wayne, Harney, Hartley, Hunter, Jones, Jordan, Kelly,
                                            Kempf, Knowlton, Lewis, McLain, Massey, Martin, Nelson,
                                            Newton, Parks, Parrett, Power, Prosser, Ritter,
                                            Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Shields, Shockley, Shull,
                                            Smith, of Miami, Stanley, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs,
                                            Turpie, Usrey, Wheeler, Whetzel, Wildman and Wood-55.
                                        
                                    
                                
                            
                             So the House refused to lay the bill on thetable; and the question
                                recurring on laying e motion to commit on the table, was decided by
                                yeas 58, nays 36; so that motion was laid on the table.
                            Mr. MURRAY proposed to commit to the Conmittee on the
                                    Judiciary, with instructions "to inquire into the
                                expediency of repealing at part which relates to giving compensation
                                to the informer." He hoped our game law is not going to be repealed.
                                He objected tounrestrained onslaught on the wild game.
                            Mr. TURPIE felt satisfied that a majority of the House were in favor
                                of the repeal of this law. The present law invited the onslaught
                                deprecated by the gentleman. It was a law also to invite an
                                onslaught by the fancy of the metropolitan saloons upon theme
                                fattened at the expense of the farmer all the game regions of the
                                State. He moved again to lay the motion to commit and the
                                instructions on the table, and again demanded the yeas and nays,
                                which being seconded and and ordered, resulted - yeas 52, nays 41;
                                so the House again refused to commit.
                            Mr. MILLER moyed to recommit to the Judiciary
                                    Committee, with instructions "to end the game law so
                                as to prolong the time ed which prairie chickens may be killed till
                                first of February, also to repeal that part a which gives
                                compensation to the informers."
                            Mr. STILES spoke to this motion, and in be reply to Mr. Turpie.
                            Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, proposed to addto the instructions "that the
                                committee change the law so as to permit farmers to kill game on at
                                all times on their own farms," speaking at length against the repeal
                                of the law. 
                            Mr. DOBBINS. Perhaps every man in his county was opposed to this law.
                                He wanted a direct vote.
                            Mr. TURPIE spoke again in reply, and proceed to state that the law
                                was not so objectionable to him as to the mass of the farmers who
                                demanded this repeal. The principle of a game law was as old as
                                feudalism, and could have little applicability to our country,
                                though one might go for one framed on proper principles. He demanded
                                the previous question, and there being a second, the main question
                                was ordered, viz.: The adoption of Mr. Nebeker's amendment to the
                                instructions, the vote resulting yeas 54, nays 36.
                            So the amendment to the instructions was adopted, and the question
                                recurred on commitment with the instructions as amended, the vote
                                resulting - yeas 54, nays 39.
                            So the bill was referred to the Judiciary
                                    Committee.
                            Mr. MELLETT (by leave) presented a petition of T. M. Scott and
                                others, for amendment of the game law so as to extend the time for
                                taking quails till February, which was referred to the same
                                committee.
                            The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the
                                Superintendent of the Asylum for the Insane, responding to Mr.
                                Smith, of Perry's resolution of the extra session, in regard to
                                expense of patients, &c.
                            On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, it was ordered to lie on the table, and
                                that 500 copies thereof be printed for the use of the House of
                                Representatives.
                            Mr. Mellett's bill (19) to prohibit false entries by trustees,
                                declaring the same a felony, &c., coming up on the second
                                reading, it was referred to the Committee on the
                                    Judiciary.
                            Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's bill (20) to prevent the carrying of
                                concealed weapons, coming up, it was referred to the
                                    Committee on Rights and Privileges.
                            Mr. Scott's bill (21) to provide for voluntary assignments for the
                                benefit of creditors, coming up - 
                            Mr. DAVIS proposed to refer to the Committee on the Judiciary, but
                                did not press the motion.
                            Mr. PARRETT preferred a select committee of five, which prevailed,
                                and it was referred to a committee, which the Speaker makes to
                                consist of Messrs. Parrett, Mellett, Scott, Colgrove and
                                Griffin.
                            Mr. Nebeker, of Warren's bill (22) for a conventional interest,
                                coming up, it was referred to the Committee on Rights and
                                    Privileges.
                            The House then (at 4 o'clock) adjourned.
                        

                    



                    
                        IN SENATE
                        
                            
                                THURSDAY, JANUARY 13, 1859.
                            
                        
                        The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate a
                            communication from M. G. Bright and J. P. Drake, Esq's., offering to
                            liquidate by transfer of real estate, the claim of the State against
                            Colonel Allen May, whose securities they were.
                        Mr. SLACK moved its reference to the Committee on
                                Finance.
                        Mr. WEIR said this subject has been before the Committee on Finance and
                            afterwards it had been referred to the Judiciary Committee ; he
                            therefore moved to amend the motion by referring it to a select
                            committee of three.
                        Mr. HEFFREN thought we had nothing to do with Messrs. May, Bright and Drake; we should hold Dr. Noffsinger
                            responsible, because he, as the financial officer of the State, loaned
                            this money unlawfully.
                        Mr. STEELE said that the Senator from Washington, [Mr. Heffren,] takes
                            strange views of this matter; and therefore proceeded to defend Dr.
                            Noffsinger from any imputations that may be cast upon him.
                        Mr. TARKINGTON could not see why the Legislature should proceed against
                            these sureties, but thought it proper that the Treasurer himself should
                            be held responsible for the amount.
                        Mr. LINE moved to amend the amendment by adding the following: "with
                            instructions to investigate all the facts in the case, and present to
                            this Senate a detailed statement of such facts at as early a day as
                            practicable."
                        Mr. WEIR accepted the amendment.
                        Mr. TARKINGTON moved to lay the whole matter upon the table.The motion
                            was rejected by yeas 18, nays 31.
                        The motion of the Senator from Huntington, [Mr. Slack,] was lost, upon a
                            division, by the vote of the PRESIDENT pro tem.
                        Mr. CONNER offered an amendment to the motion to refer, as follows: 
                        
                            
                                
                                    Resolved,That the Committee on the
                                            Judiciary, to whom was referred the resolution
                                        and instructions in reference to the protested drafts of
                                        Messrs. Bright and May, be further instructed to inquire
                                        into the legality and expediency of not only instituting
                                        suit against the said Bright and May, and others, their
                                        securites, but also against William R. Noffsinger, late
                                        Treasurer of State, and his securities, in order that the
                                        State may recover the amount due on account of that
                                        transaction as speedily as possible. 
                                
                            
                        

                        Mr. WIER moved to lay on the table.
                        The motion was lost.
                        Mr. HEFFREN moved the following as additional instructions to the
                            amendment:

                        Instruct committee to report a joint resolution directing the Attorney
                            General to bring suit upon the official bond of William R. Noffsinger,
                            for the amount of the bills of exchange endorsed by Bright and Drake. 

                        Mr. SLACK moved the following as further instructions:
                        Add to the amendment the following: 

                        And that they examine into any other amounts for which he may be liable
                            as a former Treasurer of State; and also, inquire as to the liability
                            and defalcation of any other former Treasurer of State. 

                        Mr. HEFFREN accepted the amendment.
                        Mr. TARKINGTON offered additional instructions as follows: 

                        That the committee report a bill (if necessary) making it the duty of the
                            Attorney General to commence suit against all persons from whom money is
                            due to the Treasury of State, as officers or otherwise. 


                         Mr. ANTHONY moved to lay on the table all instructions subsequent to
                            those offered by the Senator from Wabash, [Mr. Conner.]
                        Mr. TARKINGTON called for a division of the question.
                        Mr. ANTHONY withdrew his motion.
                        The question being upon the adoption of the amendment proposed by the
                            Senator from Wabash [Mr. Conner] with the pending instructions,Mr.
                            TARKINGTON demanded a division of the question.
                        The question being upon the reference the matter to the Judiciary
                            Committee, it was so referred.
                        The instructions proposed by the Senate from Washington [Mr. Heffren]
                            coming up,
                        Mr. WAGNER moved that they be laid on the table.
                        The motion was agreed to, by yeas 28, nays 22.
                        The instructions proposed by the Senator from Brown [Mr. Tarkington] were
                            adopted.
                        The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate the
                            biennial report of the State Bank, of Indiana.
                        Mr. SLACK moved that it lay on the table and 500 copies be printed.
                         The motion was agreed to

                        

                             NEWSPAPERS AND REPORTING. 
                            Mr. TARKINGTON obtained leave to make a report from the select
                                committee appointed to ascertain on what terms a report of the
                                proceedings of the Senate could be published in the same manner and
                                as fully as they were published in the Legislative Sentinel of the
                                last session.
                            The committee reported several propositions, and recommended the
                                adoption of the following: 

                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the Door-keeper procure
                                            three copies each of the Daily
                                                Sentinel and Daily Journal,
                                            two enveloped and stamped, and one copy of each loose,
                                            as per agreement. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. WALLACE said he had authority to say that the Citizen office
                                would print the reports, as they may be furnished by an official
                                Reporter, for about one-half those rates.
                            Mr. GREEN submitted a supplemental report, recommending a
                                subscription to the Weekly American,
                                Volksblatt and Free Presse,
                                three copies eachtwo of the American and all of the German papers
                                stamped.
                            Mr. GOODING saw no reason why the Citizen should not have the job, if
                                it would do it for half price.
                            Mr. WILLIAMS moved to recommit, with instructions to contract with
                                the proprietors of the daily papers of this city for four hundred
                                copies of their daily papers, to be taken daily by the Senate,
                                provided they will publish as full proceedings as the Daily State Sentinel did at the extra session, provided
                                the same can be had at the same rates they furnished them at the
                                extra session.
                        
                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                             Mr. WILLIAMS said he was opposed to taking papers unless we had the
                                proceedings of this body published something near as full as we had
                                last session in the Legislative Sentinel, and in
                                order to enable the printers to keep a competent reporter upon this
                                floor, he had submitted his proposition to take eight copies of the
                                daily paper publishing full reports. 

                        
                        
                    
                    
                
                
                

                
                    BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
                    BY ARIEL & W. H. DRAPIER
                    
                        Vol. II.
                        INDIANAPOLIS, JAN. 25 1859.
                        No. 3.
                    
                    
                        

                             Mr. WALLACE said that he had been handed a proposition from the
                                Citizen office, but he saw nothing to be gained by their proposal.
                                He was satisfied that each Senator is so desirous of having the
                                Legislative Sentinel that they would pay for it out of their own
                                pockets, should the Senate refuse to subscribe for it.
                            Mr. HEFFREN moved to lay the whole matter on the table, to enable a
                                resolution to be introduced covering the whole matter, and settling
                                the question at once.
                            The resolution was agreed to.
                            Mr. HAMILTON obtained leave to introduce the following resolution,
                                which was adopted: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the Committee
                                                on Printing inquire into the expediency of
                                            reducing the price paid for the printing of the Journals
                                            of the Legislature, the Laws of the State, and such
                                            other printing as is necessary for the State of Indiana,
                                            for which the State pays, of every kind, and to report
                                            by bill or otherwise.
                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. GREEN, from the Select Committee to which was referred his bill
                                (S. 3) enlarging the Seventh Judicial Circuit, by adding to the same
                                the counties of Hancock, Madison, Hamilton, Tipton and Howard, and
                                fixing the time of holding Circuit Courts therein, reported the same
                                back with sundry amendments.
                            The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time by its
                                title.
                            On motion of Mr. MURRAY, the bill was considered as engrossed, read
                                through the third time and finally passed the Senateyeas 47, nays
                                2.
                            The PRESIDENT, pro tempore, laid before the Senate
                                the annual report from the Trustees of the Wabash and Erie
                                Canal.
                            Mr. HEFFREN moved that it be laid on the table, and 200 copies
                                printed.
                            The motion was rejected, after two votes, by yeas and nays - the
                                second resulting - yeas 19, nays 30.
                            The report was then read.
                            Mr. WALLACE moved its reference to the Committee on Canals
                                    and Internal Improvements, and that 500 copies be
                                printed.
                            The motion was agreed to.
                            On motion by Mr. WALLACE, Senators Hamilton, Conner, Carnahan and
                                McLain were added to the Committee on Canals and Internal
                                Improvements.
                            On Mr. WEIR'S motion, Mr. Murray was also added to the same
                                committee.
                            Mr. TURNER offered a resolution that the Senate subscribe for three
                                copies each of the Daily Journal, Sentinel,Citizen, weekly American,
                                Volksblatt and Frie Presse, two
                                of the English and all the German papers to be enveloped and
                                stamped.
                            Mr. JOHNSTON moved to strike out all papers except the Sentinel and Journal.
                            Mr. MARCH offered the following as an amendment.


                            Providing that each daily paper publish full reports of the
                                proceedings of this body.

                            Mr. TURNER accepted the amendment, and moved the previous
                                question.
                            There being a second, under its operation the amendment of the
                                Senator from Putnam [Mr. Johnston] was rejected - yeas 23, nays
                                26and the original resolution, as amended by the Senator from
                                Delaware [Mr. March] was adopted by yeas 27, nays 23.
                             Mr. GOODING offered the following:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        ResolvedThat the Senate will, the House
                                            of Representatives concurring therein, proceed, in the
                                            Hall of the House ot Representatives, at 10 o'clock, A.
                                            M.,on to-morrow, to elect by joint viva
                                                voce vote, a State Agent, a Canal Trustee, a
                                            State Librarian, and Trustees for the Insane, Blind, and
                                            Deaf and Dumb Asylums, according to law. 
                                    
                                
                            
                             Upon Mr. TARKINGTON'S motion the resolution was laid on the table by
                                yeas 32, nays 17.
                            A message was received from the House of Representatives announcing
                                the passage by that body of a joint resolution (H. R. 5) instructing
                                our legally elected Senators and requesting our Representatives to
                                vote for a law giving to each settler on the public lands 160
                                acres.
                            Also, a joint resolution (H. R. 6) authorizing a number of German
                                books to be delivered to township libraries where the number of
                                German voters justify it.
                            Mr. HEFFREN offered the following resolution, which was adopted by
                                consent: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Resolved That the Committee
                                                on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire
                                            into and report to the Senate whether under the
                                            provisions of the Constitution a Senator elected to fill
                                            a vacancy occasioned by resignation, or otherwise, shall
                                            hold his office for the unexpired term, or for the full
                                            term of four years. 
                                    

                                
                            
                            Mr. BEESON offered a preamble and resolution that on the 19th inst.,
                                the Senate repair to the Hall of the House of Representatives, to
                                receive and hear petitions from women of the State, praying for
                                legislation in their behalf. He sustained his resolution in a few
                                remarks.
                            The resolution was adopted.
                            And then the Senate adjourned.

                            

                        
                        
                    
                    

                    
                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
                        
                            Thursday, January 12, 1859 
                        
                        
                            HIGH PRESSURE, CONFISCATION AND DESTRUCTION. 
                            The SPEAKER laid before the House the petition of sundry citizens of
                                the counties of Marion and Hancock, praying for a liquor law on the
                                "high pressure, confiscation and destruction principle," which was
                                being read, when - 
                             Mr. KNOWLTON moved that the further reading be dispensed with - 
                            Mr. FIRESTONE moved to refer to the Committee on Military
                                    Affairs.
                            Mr. SCOTT moved that it be tabled, as its terms were disrespectful to
                                the House of Representatives.
                            Mr. PROSSER proposed to amend by substituting a motion to reject.
                            Mr. Speaker GORDON said he had had no time to read the petition
                                having received it from one of the most intelligent citizens of the
                                State, who assured him it was from the people of Hancock and Marion.
                                They may have used indecorous language, but certainly no insult
                                could have been intended. I know them - many of them - to be as good
                                men as there are in the State. It might not appear so offensive if
                                it were read well, instead of the slow and faulty manner in which it
                                was begun. I ask that it may take the usual course. I ask it on the
                                part of the signers of the paper whom I know.
                            A lengthy debate here ensued upon the reference of the petition which
                                occupied nearly the entire morning session. The discussion involved
                                the right of petition, prohibitory laws, the license system,
                                &c., &c.
                            The SPEAKER decided the motion to reject to be out of order.
                            Mr. KNOWLTON demanded a division of the questionthe first question
                                being: Shall the petition be received; was decided by yeas 80, nays
                                16 - Messrs. Keefer, Merrifield, Sullivan and others voting in the
                                negative, because the paper was considered unfit to be read. Pending
                                the next question: Shall the petition be referred to the
                                    Committee on Temperance ? 
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY moved to lay the motion and the petition on the table,
                                and the vote resultedyeas 36, nays 62, so the latter motion was
                                rejected.
                            Mr. BAIRD made an ineffectual motion to refer to a select committee
                                of three.The petition was then referred to the Committee on
                                    Temperance.Mr. DAVIS presented the petition of Jared
                                O. Jocelyn, praying for compensation for services, which was
                                referred to the Committee on Fees and Salaries
                                .

                        
                        
                             THE EDWARDS AND FIRESTONE CONTEST. 
                            Mr. STANFIELD, in conformity with an order of the House, at the extra
                                session, submitted the following report:
                            MR. SPEAKER :In obedience to the resolution of this House at its
                                special session, I proceeded to Huntington to take the deposition of
                                witnesses in the case mentioned in second resolution. Finding that a
                                full investigation had been had of all the facts in controversy
                                arising in said election in a contest of the seat of a County
                                Commissioner elected at that election, which had been reduced to
                                writing, and eould, by an agreement between the parties, be made
                                applicable as evidence in this cause, I procured such an agreement
                                to be made; and I herewith lay befere the House the evidence taken
                                in pursuance of it, and also the poll books and tally papers of said
                                election in Huntington township, which may be valuable in showing
                                the truth of the fact in controversy. All of which is respectfully
                                submitted.
                            THOS. S. STANFIELD.
                            The report was received and referred to the  Committee on
                                    Elections.
                            Mr. DURHAM (by consent) presented the petition of Thomas Johnson,
                                which was referred to the Committee on
                                Claims.
                            Mr. KNOWLTON, from a majority of the select committee to which was
                                referred Mr. Martin's bill (H. R. 14) to amend the 14th section of
                                the Justices act, reported the same back, with an amendment,
                                inserting appropriately, "or where a defendant or defendants has or
                                have promised in writing to discharge any debt or contract in a
                                township, suit may be commenced either in the township where said
                                defendant promised to discharge the same, or where either of the
                                defendants reside;" and so amended they recommend the passage of the
                                bill.
                            Mr. MARTIN opposed the adoption of the amendment.
                            Mr. KNOWLTON explained it.
                            Mr. LAWHEAD opposed it from the fact that three-fourths of the
                                promissory notes were made at the county seat.
                            Mr. CAVINS. The bill provides that the assignors of the note shall
                                not be made parties to it. We propose to make an additional
                                amendment: that where a man has promised to pay a note at a
                                particular place, it shall be collectable there, or where he
                                resides.
                            Mr. MURRAY. The effect of the amendment would be to compel their
                                creditors to sign notes collectable at the county seats. It would
                                break up the business of the Justices of the Peace in rural
                                townships. The proposed change would increase costs in the mileage
                                of constables. Should not we legislate for the benefit of the people
                                at large, rather than those petty office-holders?
                            Mr. LAWHEAD. The adoption of this amendment would create a necessity
                                for drawing notes, waiving its force.
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush, also approved the amendment. 
                        
                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                            The SPEAKER laid before the House a report from the Trustees of the
                                Wabash and Erie Canal.
                            On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, it was laid on the table, and 500 copies
                                thereof be printed for the use of the House of Representatives. 
                            
                            
                                CONGRESSIONAL HOMESTEAD.
                                Mr. STILES asked and obtained leave to introduce a joint
                                    resolution (No. 5) viz.: 
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Resolved,That our legally elected
                                                Senators and Representatives in Congress be
                                                requested to take such action as may be necessary to
                                                give to each of the actual settlers on public lands
                                                a homestead of one hundred and sixty acres. 
                                        
                                    
                                
                                Whereupon - 
                                The SPEAKER, ruling that a joint resolution is not a law and does
                                    not require three readings, ordered the yeas and nays, which
                                    being taken, resulted - yeas 77, nays 1.
                                So the joint resolution was adopted on the part of the House of
                                    Representatives.
                            

                            
                                GERMAN BOOKS.
                                Mr. KEMPF, (by unanimous consent,) submitted a joint resolution
                                    (No. 6) authorizing the addition of a number of books to any
                                    township library, where the number of German voters in such
                                    township will justify so doing [in the opinion of the State
                                    Board of Education.]
                                The yeas and nays being taken thereon, under the constitutional
                                    provision, the result was yeas 77, nays 8.
                                Mr. KNOWLTON, (by leave,) explained. He understood the resolution
                                    to include a distribution of all the books by law required to be
                                    distributed. He could go for distributing in the German language
                                    books on Government, Agriculture, Commerce and the Mechanic
                                    Arts, but no farther.
                                Mr. KEMPF. The terms of the resolution were so restricted.
                                So the joint resolution was adopted.
                                Mr. SHULL asked and obtained leave to submit a joint resolution
                                    (No. 7) expressive of the sense of the General Assembly with
                                    reference to the distribution of the Common School Fund, [that
                                    said distribution among the counties be in proportion to the
                                    number of children entitled thereto.]
                                Mr. DOUGHERTY moved to refer to the Committee on
                                        Education.
                                Mr. BOYD preferred a vote of the House on this resolution. In
                                    this way, the Committee on Education would be guided in their
                                    action.
                                Mr. PARKS spoke against the constitutionality of the Senate bill
                                    on this subject.
                                Mr. MANSFIELD. This subject has been before the Committee on
                                    Education. If the matter was to be decided By this vote, he
                                    would be in favor of sending it first to some committee.
                                Mr. KEEFER should vote to lay the resolution on the table. He was
                                    in favor of each county collecting and appropriating its own
                                    school tax.
                                Mr. SHULL. There was diversity of opinion as to the distribution
                                    of this fund. He was satisfied that the northern portion of the
                                    State would be loser by any change of the present law of
                                    distribution. He desired an expression on the subject by both
                                    Houses of the General Assembly.
                                Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, moved to lay the motion and joint
                                    resolution on the table.
                                The motion was agreed to.
                                The SPEAKER announced the following additional members of the
                                    Committee on Judiciary: Messrs. Parrett, Scott and Stiles.The
                                    House now resumed the consideration of the committee's amendment
                                    to Mr. Martin's bill. (H. R. 14.)
                                On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the amendment was laid on the table.
                                The bill was again read through.
                                Mr. CLEMENTS proposed to amend by adding a section.
                                
                                    "SEC. - Nothing herein contained shall
                                        prevent the collection of debts in townships where the same
                                        shall have been contracted."
                                
                                Mr. MURRAY moved to lay the amendment on the table.
                                Which was agreed to - affirmative 44, negative 20.
                                Mr. BROTHERTON moved to refer the bill to the Committee
                                        on the Judiciary.
                                Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, moved to instruct the committee to strike
                                    out the exception in the proviso.
                                Mr. MARTIN explained the abuse which had grown up under the
                                    present law.
                                Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, said it was wrong to impose upon one a
                                    responsibility that belongs alike to all the parties
                                    defendant.The House refused to recommit, and the question
                                    recurred on engrossment.
                                On motion by Mr. MURRAY, it was referred to the
                                        Judiciary Committee without alterations.
                                
                            

                            
                                RESOLUTIONS.
                                Mr. HARNEY submitted the following, which was adopted: 

                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Resolved,That this Hall be tendered
                                                for the use of the State Temperance Convention, on
                                                Monday evening, the l7th, and on Tuesday the 18th
                                                inst., to transact their business and hold their
                                                meetings.
                                        
                                    
                                

                                Mr. DOBBINS submitted the following:
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Resolved, That the
                                                  Committee on Rights and
                                                  Privileges to whom was referred the bill
                                                (No. 7) providing for ten per cent, interest on
                                                contract be instructed to report an amendment
                                                thereto prohibiting all banks from a greater rate of
                                                interest on notes, bills of exchange, &c., per
                                                annum, than that which is allowed in said bill to
                                                individuals on moneys loaned, with proper penalties
                                                and restrictions. 
                                        
                                    
                                

                                Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, moved to make it a resolution of
                                    inquiry.
                                Which was agreed to, and, as thus amended, the resolution was
                                    adopted.
                                Mr. MURRAY submitted the following, which was adopted: 
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Resolved, That the
                                                  Committee on the Judiciary be
                                                instructed to inquire into the power and expediency
                                                of providing, by law, for setting apart a sufficient
                                                portion of the funds arising from the State's
                                                interest in the State Bank, and distributing the
                                                residue immediately among the several counties of
                                                the State, in just proportions, to be loaned upon
                                                mortgaged security for the benefit of common
                                                schools. 
                                        
                                    
                                
                                Mr. SUMMERS submitted the following: 
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Resolved,That the
                                                  Committee on County and Township
                                                  Business be requested to inquire into
                                                the expediency of so amending section 18 of the Act
                                                of May 6, 1852. that the Trustees shall annually, on
                                                the third Monday in March of each year, settle and
                                                audit the accounts of the Treasurers and Supervisors
                                                of roads in their respective townships, instead of
                                                February, as now provided by law. 
                                        
                                    
                                

                                

                                Other resolutions were submitted as follows:

                                By Mr. SULLIVAN, referring that portion of the Governor's Message
                                    which refers to banks and bank laws, to a committee of one from
                                    each Congressional District.



                                By Mr. COLLIER, excusing Mr. Dougherty and appointing Mr. Parks a
                                    member of the Committee on Education.


                                By Mr. SNYDER, instructing the Committee on Fees and
                                        Salaries, to inquire into the propriety of so
                                    amending the law as to attain uniformity in fees and allowances
                                    made to County Auditors; to provide a fee for transferring the
                                    lands described in each deed instead of as now giving a fee for
                                    each description contained in a deed; to provide for a cross
                                    index to be made by the County Recorder, and making it a part of
                                    the Recorder's duty to continue and keep up the same without
                                    charge of allowances.

                                By Mr. DOBBINS, that Mr. Eastham be excused and Mr. Firestone
                                    appointed as a member of the Committee on Military
                                        Affairs.

                                By Mr. JORDON, instructing the Judiciary
                                        Committee to inquire whether the circulation of
                                    bank bills of a less denomination than five dollars issued by
                                    banks in this State can be prohibited by law.

                                By Mr. WATERMAN, instructing the Fees and Salaries
                                        Committee to inquire into the propriety of so
                                    amending the law regulating fees and salaries as to allow County
                                    officers stated annual salaries, with authority given to Boards
                                    doing County Business to allow said officers for clerk hire in
                                    counties where justice requires it.


                                By Mr. JOHNSON, directing the Judiciary
                                        Committee to inquire into the expediency of
                                    abolishing the present mode of selecting jurors of the Circuit
                                    and Common Pleas Courts and providing a cheaper system.

                                    report as relates to the insurance laws to the
                                        Committee on Corporations.

                                By Mr. WILDMAN, instructing the Judiciary
                                        Committee to inquire into the expediency of so
                                    amending the law as to allow parties to swear to their book
                                    accounts.

                            




                            
                                JOINT RESOLUTIONS.

                                 By Mr. SMITH, of Perry, accompanying a memorial from the State
                                    Board of Agriculture, on the subject of a geological survey of
                                    the State. The memorial was referred to the Committee
                                        on Agriculture, and it was ordered to be
                                    subsequently returned and referrred to a select committee of
                                    sixteen - nine on the part of the House and seven on the part of
                                    the Senate - one to be selected from each Agricultural District

                                    Government for the improvement of the harbor at Michigan City. 

                                By Mr. MURRAY, on the subject of the admission of Oregon and
                                    Kansas into the Union.

                                By Mr. BOYD, amendatory of the act providing for the election and
                                    prescribing certain of the duties of Recorders, approved May 31.
                                    1852.

                                By Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, to regulate and restrain the sale of
                                    spirituous and intoxicating liquors to prevent and punish
                                    drunkenness and crime.

                                By Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, to prevent the killing or destruction
                                    of wild game repealing laws conflicting therewith.

                                    interest on money, approved May 27, 1852, so as to allow the
                                    recovery of principal and interest.

                                    incorporated by the State of Indianato punish violations of its
                                    provisions and to repeal former enactments in regard to such
                                    companies.

                        IN SENATE
                        
                            FRIDAY, JANUARY 14, 1859.
                        

                        The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate a
                            communication from the Superintendent of the Indiana Hospital for the
                            Insane, in compliance with a resolution of the Senate, respecting the
                            pay in mileage and per diem of each Trustee for the years 1854, 1855,
                            1856, 1857 and 1858, &c.
                        Mr. CULVER presented the petition of a large number of voters of the
                            county of Tippecanoe, praying for the passage of a law raising the rate
                            of interest to 10 per centum, which was referred to the
                                Committee on Finance. Also, a petition from the
                            same county, asking for a law making railroad companies liable for stock
                            killed where said roads can not be fenced, which was referred to the
                                Committee on Corporations.
                        Mr. HARGROVE presented a petition from sundry citizens of the county of
                            Gibson on the subject of temperance, which was referred to the
                                Committee on Temperance.
                        Mr. ODELL presented the petition of Henry M. Wright, praying an allowance
                            for pursuing and arresting a murderer, which was referred to the
                                Committee on Claims.
                        Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee, to whom was
                            referred the bill (II. R. 10) establishing a Board of Sinking Fund
                            Commissioners, recommending its adoption with the following
                            amendments:
                        Strike out the provision relating to the employment of assistants, and
                            add that the salary of the President shall not exceed $1,500, and the
                            Clerk $ 1,000.
                        Mr. SLACK made a minority report from the same committee, recommending - 
                        
                        That all that part of the bill giving to the Board the power of fixing
                            the salary of President, be stricken out, and that the amount be fixed
                            at $500 per annum.
                        On Mr. MURRAY'S motion, the minority report was tabled - yeas 37, nays
                            11.
                        Mr. HARGROVE moved to concur and amend by striking out $1,500 and
                            inserting $1,000.
                        Mr. SLACK moved that it be $800.
                        On Mr. STUDABAKER'S motion, the amendments were laid on the table - yeas
                            34, nays 14.
                        Mr. SLACK moved to strike out $1,500 and insert $900.
                        Mr. MURRAY moved the previous question, and there being a second, under
                            its operation the amendment was lost - yeas 11, nays 88 - and the report
                            was concurred in, by yeas 35, hays 14.
                        On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, the bill was considered as engrossed and
                            read a third time.
                        Mr. LINE moved to recommit to a select committee of five, with
                            instructions to strike out $1,500 and insert $1,250.
                        On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, this motion was tabled - yeas 31, nays
                            17.
                        Mr. SLACK moved to recommit to a committee of five, with instructions to
                            limit the salary of President to $1,100.
                        Mr. HEFEREN demanded the previous question.
                        There being a second, under its operation, the motion to recommit was
                            rejectedyeas 15, nays 31and the bill finally passed the Senate, by yeas
                            36, nays 12.
                        Mr. SLACK made a motion to take up his resolution, giving the journal of
                            the last session of the Senate into the hands of the State Printer,
                            which was rejected by yeas 21, nays 25.
                        Mr. WALLACE submitted a resolution to the same effect, which - 
                        On Mr. MURRAY'S motion, was laid on the table - yeas 27, nays 22.
                        Mr. WAGNER offered a resolution that the Senate will, the House
                            concurring therein, proceed to the Hall of the House this day at
                            half-past two o'clock, for the purpose of electing three Directors of
                            the State Prison, Librarian, Trustee of the Wabash and Erie Canal, State
                            Printer and Agent of State, in the order as above stated.
                        Mr. STUDABAKER made an ineffectual motion to lay it on the table - yeas
                            19, nays 30.
                        Mr. MURRAY moved the previous question; there being a second, under its
                            operation the main question was ordered - yeas 26, nays 24 and the
                            resolution was not adopted - yeas 25, nays 25.
                        Mr. CONLEY offered a resolution which was adopted, that the
                                Committee on Organization of the Courts inquire
                            into the expediency of abolishing the Court of Common Pleas and
                            establishing a surrogate system for the settlement of estates of
                            decedants, and report a bill to that effect.
                        Mr. HAMILTON offered a resolution, which was adopted, that the
                                Committee on Finance inquire into the expediency
                            of prohibiting all officers of the State holding public moneys from
                            loaning the same, and also providing by law where the public funds shall
                            be deposited.
                        On motion by Mr. GREEN a concurrent resolution was adopted, appointing a
                            joint committee of two in the Senate and three in the House, to inquire
                            into and make a full investigation of the alleged swamp land frauds.
                        Mr. COOPER offered a resolution, which was adopted, that the Committee on
                            the State Prison inquire into the expediency of erecting a House of
                            Refuge as contemplated by the Constitution, section 2, article 9.
                        Mr. JONES offered a resolution, the same as Mr. Wagner's, which is
                            recited above.
                        Mr. TARKINGTON made an ineffectual motion to lay it on the tableyeas 23,
                            nays 27.
                        Mr. WAGNER moved the previous question.
                        There being a second, under its operation the resolution was passed -
                            yeas 27, nays 22. 


                        
                            BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS
                             Mr. BENNETT offerered the following:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the Door keeper be
                                            directed to contrat with A. E.Drapier & Son, for six

                                            Assembly, after the style [?] their reports in the

                                            newspaper column; provided the cost I the same shall not

                                            resolution.

                                resulted - yeas 29, nays 19 - as follows:

                                            Cobb, Connelly, Cravens of Jefferson, Fisk, Gooding,
                                            Hamilton, Heffren, Line, Lomax, McClure, McLean, March,
                                            Miller, Murray, O'Brien, Rice, Shoemaker, Slack, Steele,
                                            Stevens, Studabaker, Tarkington, Turner, Wallace,
                                            Weir,Williams - 29.

                                            Carnahan, Conn[?], Cooper, Craven of Madison, Culver,
                                            Green, Hargro[?], Hendry, Hill, Johnston, Jones, Kinley,
                                            Odell, Robins, Thompson, Wilson - 19.
                                    
                                
                            
                             So the resolution was adopted.,
                             [A message from the House of Represenatives announced the
                                concurrence of that bo in the memorial to the Senate of the United
                                States in relation to the seats of Mess[?] Lane and McCarty.,
                             Also, the concurrance of the House in Senate amendments to the bill
                                (H. R. 10), establishing a Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners.]
                            
                        
                        
                             AFTERNOON SESSION.
                             On Mr. WEIR'S motion, the special order being the consideration of
                                the Governor's  Message was
                                postponed until Monday two o'clock, P. M.
                            On motion by Mr. CONNELLY, the Committee on Banks
                                were directed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the
                                Bank, law as to prohibit the circulation of bills of the Banks of
                                other States of a less denomination than $5.
                            Mr. WEIR offered a resolution directing the Committee on
                                    Agriculture to inquire into the expediency of
                                authorizing County Commissioners to purchase and held lands for the
                                use of county agricultural societies.
                            Mr. BROWN moved, as an amendment, that the Committee on
                                    County and Township Business, inquire into the
                                expediency of allowing County Commissioners to purchase sufficient
                                grounds for county fairs.
                            On motion by Mr. WALLACE, they were preferred to the
                                    Committee on Agriculture.
                            On motion of Mr. WALLACE, it was - 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That a special committee of
                                            three be appointed to prepare and submit to the Senate a
                                            bill denning he duties of the Commissioners and
                                            President of the Sinking Fund. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. WILSON introduced a resolution that in the opinion of the Senate,
                                any law restricting and regulating the sale of spirituous and
                                intoxicating liquors ought to contain a [?]ay license clause.
                            Mr. GOODING was in favor of the resolution.
                            Mr. SLACK wanted to put every thing upon tie same level. If liquor is
                                to be sold let it put upon the same terms as any thing else hat is
                                sold.
                            Mr. HENDRY opposed the resolution because if it passed it would fail
                                of the object [?] view - it would not be an expression of the
                                opinion of the Senate, because the amount of money for the license
                                is not fixed.
                            Mr. CARNAHAN was in favor of a pay liscense system, and did not
                                believe a law uponany other plan would effect any thing.
                            Mr. HAMILTON moved to amend by issuing licenses for not less than $25
                                nor more than $200, at the option of the County Commissioners.
                            Mr. WEIR was opposed to their being any money attached to the license
                                system, but if their must be, he was in favor of some low figure
                                [?]th good freehold sureties.
                            Mr. GREEN moved that it be not less than [?]0 nor more than
                                $5000.
                            Mr. HAMILTON accepted.
                            Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend by adding: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        "Also, to prohibit all but pure liquors from being sold
                                            making it a misdemeanor to sell any impure, drugged
                                            mixed liquors." 
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. WAGNER, could vote for no law that [?] not license for $50.
                            [?] message from the House of Representatives announced the
                                concurrence of that body the Senate's resolution to go into the
                                election of State officers, and inviting the Senate to the Hall for
                                that purpose.
                            Mr. WAGNER having the floor, moved that the Senate repair to the Hall
                                of the House instanter, but withdrew it for
                            Mr. WALLACE, who demanded a call of the Senate.
                            The call was had and every Senator reported as present.
                            Mr. WAGNER renewed his motion, which was agreed to, and Senators
                                preceded by the PRESIDENT pro tempore, vacated the
                                Chamber.
                            When Senators returned -
                            The Senate adjourned. 
                        
                    
                    

                    
                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
                        
                            
                                FRIDAY, JANUARY 14, 1859.
                            
                        
                         The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the Auditor of
                            State, responding to Mr. Davis' resolution, of the llth inst., embracing
                            statements of the amount due from Hiram E. Talbott, at the time of his
                            retirement from the Auditor's office, and the amount which has been
                            collected of him; also, the amount which has been received by the
                            Auditor of State from all sources during the present term, the amount by
                            him paid out, the balance on hand, and where deposited, which was read,
                            and on the motion of Mr. Davis referred to the Committee on
                                Ways and Means.
                        On motion of Mr. HUNTER, the Senate amendments to Mr. Smith's, of Perry,
                            bill (H. R. 10) were taken up, viz: Strike out from section 7, all that
                            relates to the employment of assistants, and adding to the 9th section,
                            "nor shall the salary of the President exceed $1,500 a year, and the
                            Clerk $1,000 a year; and amending the title accordingly;" and they were
                            concurred in as a whole, without a division.
                        Mr. FIRESTONE presented the petition of C. W. Hughes and others, for a
                            law to regulate the exhibition of stallions, which was referred to the
                                 Committee on Agriculture.

                        
                             THE LANE AND M'CARTY MEMORIAL.
                            On motion of Mr. MURRAY, this memorial, communicated from the Senate
                                as having been adopted by that body in the name of the people of the
                                State of Indiana, rehearsing at length the history and the
                                Republican view of the election of Senators Bright and Fitch, and
                                memorializing the Senate of the United States against the legality
                                of the seats of Messrs. Bright and Fitch, and in favor of the
                                alleged election and claim preferred to their places by Messrs.
                                Henry S. Lane and William M. M'Carty, and entrusted by resolution to
                                the Vice President of the United States, was taken up, and the same
                                having been read through by the Clerk - 
                            Mr. DAVIS said: Mr. Speaker, I do not propose to discuss this
                                question now, or to reply to or review the memorial. I had the
                                privilege and the honor, when this question of the election, or the
                                pretended election, of United States Senators was pending in ; the
                                extra session, of presenting in brief, the views I then entertained;
                                and I wish now merely to say, in addition to the remarks I then sub-
                                     submitted, that I have the
                                gratification of knowing that the view then taken of this question,
                                by the gentleman from Vanderburg and Posey, and myself, has been
                                sustained by the voice of at least one of the greatest men of the
                                ageone who, like the gentleman from Vanderburg and I, is himself " a
                                fossil " of the great Whig party - I mean the Honorable John J.
                                Crittenden, of Kentucky. He looks upon this question as a settled
                                judicial question - a question that is judicially closed, and cannot
                                be opened by any action of ours; a question that can not now be
                                placed in a position in which the memorial seeks to place it.
                                Further I am gratified to learn that the venerable Joseph Gales,
                                editor of the  National Intelligencer - a paper
                                standing in the same relation to other papers that the Bible
                                sustains to other books sustains the same view. I am also further
                                advised that William Pitt Fessenden, a Senator from the State of
                                Maine, entertains the same viewand no one questions his
                                Republicanism. I am further advised - and you, Mr. Speaker, know the
                                fact - that Senator Collamer, of Vermont, a sound lawyer and
                                statesman, entertains precisely the same view which has been
                                declared on this floor by the gentleman from Vanderburg and Posey,
                                and myself. Again, sir, I am advised that the great wheel-horse of
                                Republicanism in the State of Ohio, Mr. Wade, looks upon this as a
                                settled question. I have been told also, that Senator Bell, of
                                Tennessee, a sound lawyer, and one of the most accomplished
                                statesmen of the day, entertains the same view.
                            It may be that the gentleman from Vanderburg and myself are wrong,
                                but certain it is, if we are wrong, we are in very good company. And
                                is it not strange, Mr. Speaker, that when, in the conscientious
                                discharge of a sworn duty here a duty we have been compelled to
                                discharge under the obligation of a solemn oath we have taken
                                herethat because we have not shrunk from our duty, we are to be
                                traduced by little scribblers all over the State, in every little
                                eight-by-ten, dog-fennel gazette merely because we have discharged
                                our honest duty according to our best understanding in the case.
                            As I have said before, Mr. Speaker, so I say yet, that I deeply
                                regret that we have no power to go now into an election of United
                                States Senators; for if I had the power to elect United States
                                Senators by my vote, certain it is, that by my vote, Jesse D. Bright
                                and Graham N. Fitch would not be in the Senate of the United States
                                for the State of Indiana. Having stated, when called upon on a
                                former occasion in this place, that I believed it was not in our
                                power to go into that electionthat the question had been settled and
                                closed up against us. And being called upon again by those who have
                                a right to know my views, I say now, that I still see no reason to
                                change the views I then expressed.
                            What, sir, would be my proper position,should I feel disposed to
                                change my views ? I was a candidate before the people and was
                                elected to this seat here upon a full and free exposition of the
                                views I have expressed on this question. Would it not have been
                                acting unfaithfully to my people had I attempted here to disobey
                                their voice, or to act in deliberate contravention of their
                                expressed will? Most assuredly. No, Mr. Speaker, had I changed my
                                views, I would at once have resigned my seat, in order that the
                                people of the county of Floyd might have found another man to carry
                                out their views. But, sir, 1 say here in my place, that I do not
                                believe there are ten men in the county of Floyd, who do not
                                entertain the views I have here endeavored to represent upon this
