                                question.
                            I have said this, sir, in order that, at some future time, and in my
                                own way I might put tegether what I have now said, and the
                                declarations which I made upon this subject in the extra session;
                                for, although I may have but little reputation abroad in the State,
                                still I desire to be placed right before my constituents upon this
                                question, and especially those of them who take a deep interest in
                                the matter. I desire also to avoid misrepresentation, and,
                                therefore, for my constituents, as well as for myself, I propose
                                that what I say now, and what I have heretofore said on this
                                question, shall be prepared and published in the shape of a
                                speech.
                            I will not further occupy the time of the House, because I know the
                                friends of this paper desire to have the vote this morning.
                            And then under the force of the previous question demanded by Mr.
                                Murray, the memorial and resolution were adopted and concurred in by
                                yeas 51, nays 49, as follows : 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS. -Messrs. Austin, Baird, Boyd,
                                            Boxley, Branham, Brotherton, Cavins, Clark, Colgrove,
                                            Collier, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Duvoll, Edwards,
                                            Pordyce, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant. Hall of Rush,
                                            Hamilton of Boone. Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison, Hunter,
                                            Jeflfries, Johnston, Jones, Mansfield. Mellet, Miller,
                                            Murray, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of
                                            Warren, Parks, Power. Bitter. Robinson, Rynerson, Scott,
                                            Sherman, Shields, Smith of Miami, Stanfield, Stiles,
                                            Thompson of Elkhart, Tread-way, Whetzel, Whiteman,
                                            Wildman, Mr. Speaker. - 51. 
                                        NAYS. - Messrs. Black, Blythe, Bowman,
                                            Carr, Claypool, Clayton, Clements, Davis, Dobbins,
                                            Dougherty, Durham, Early, Eastham, Firestone, Gifford,
                                            Hancock, Harney, Hartley, Jordan, Reefer, Kelly, Kempf,
                                            Knowlton, Law-head, Lewis, McLain, Major, Massey,
                                            Merrifield, Nelson, Newton, Parrett, Prosser,Row,
                                            Shockley, Shull, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley,
                                            Stinson, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison,
                                            Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Wood. - 49. 
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                             ALLEN MAY AND SECURITIES. 
                             Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, submitted a resolution requiring the
                                Attorney General to proceed immediately to institute suit against
                                Colonel Allen May, and his securities, on the $40,000 due from said
                                May to the State, and that any judgment thereon be pressed as
                                speedily as possible, without any unnecessary delay.
                            Mr. DAVIS raised the question, whether those notes were not the paper
                                of the State Treasurer, and preferred to defer action. He  did not recognize the right of the
                                Treasurer to loan out money and take such notes. If we were to
                                pursue this against May, it would relieve the Treasurer.
                            On the motion of Mr. EDWARDS, the resolution was referred to the
                                Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions "to inquire whether
                                the resolution proposes the proper course to be pursued, and if not,
                                what should be done in the premises?" 
                        
                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.

                            After sundry calls of the House, the Senate concurrent resolutions
                                for the two houses in joint convention, at 2 1/2 o'clock, in the
                                Hall of the House of Representatives to proceed to the election of
                                three Directors of the State Prison, a State Librarian, a Trustee of
                                the Wabash and Erie Canal, a State Printer, and an Agent of State,
                                in the order herein stated, was taken up and concurred in by yeas
                                58, nays 39. 


                            
                                IN THE JOINT CONVENTION.

                                The Convention of the two Houses was organized according to order
                                    - the PRESIDENT pro tem, of the Senate in the
                                    Chair - and on the first vote for Directors of the State Prison
                                    - 
                                Mr. TURPIE nominated Grafton F. Cookerly, of Vigo county, and Mr.
                                    EDWARDS nominated Cullum H. Baily, of Vigo county.
                                
                                    
                                        Mr. Cookerly received 74 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Baily recieved 70 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        So Mr. Cookerly was declared elected.
                                    
                                    
                                        Senator MURRAY nominated Mr. Earlywine, of Shelby
                                            county.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. TURPIE nominated Thomas M. Brown, of Floyd
                                            county.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Brown received 75 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Earlywine received 69 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Brown was declared elected.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. TURPIE nominated Samuel H. Buskirk, of Monroe
                                            county.
                                    
                                    
                                        Senator GREEN nominated J. D. Kelso, of Floyd county.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Buskirk received 72 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Kelso received 67 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Buskirk was declared elected. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            
                                STATE LIBRARIAN.
                                Under the order for the election of State Librarian - 
                                Mr. TURPIE nominated James R. Bryant, of Marion county.
                                Senator MURRAY nominated N. Wilson, of Tippecanoe county.
                                
                                    
                                        Mr. Bryant received 74 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Wilson received 69 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Bryant was declared elected.
                                    
                                
                                Under the order for the election of Canal Trustee (which was by
                                    ballot according to the statutory provision, older than the
                                    Constitution.) - 
                                Mr. TURPIE nominated Richard Raleigh, of Vanderburg county.,
                                 Senator WEIR nominated Dudley G. Coffin, of Parke county.
                                On the first ballot - 
                                
                                    
                                        Mr. Raleigh received 69 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Coffin received 70 votes. 
                                    
                                    
                                        Scattering 5 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        On the second ballot - 
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Raleigh received 72 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Coffin received 71 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Scattering 1 vote.
                                    
                                    
                                        On the third ballot - 
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Raleigh received 72 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Coffin received 72 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        On the fourth ballot - 
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Raleigh received 71 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Coffin received 71 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Scattering 1 vote.
                                    
                                    
                                        On the fifth ballot- 
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Raleigh received 69 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Mr. Coffin received 69 votes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Blank 1 vote. 
                                    
                                
                                Here the Convention took a recess till half-past seven
                                    o'clock.
                            
                        

                        
                             NIGHT SESSION. 
                             A call of the Convention proceeded and brought in the absentees:
                            Mr. Austin and Mr. Newton, Mr. Griffin and Mr. Sullivan, Mr. Black
                                and Mr. Hamilton, of Boone, Mr. Smith, of Perry, and Mr. Branham,
                                Mr. Clements and Mr. Miller, having paired off respectively - the
                                vote on the sixth ballot for Canal Trustee proceeded.
                            
                                
                                    Mr. Raleigh received 71 votes.
                                
                                
                                    Mr. Coffin received 69 votes.
                                
                            
                            Mr. Raleigh was declared elected.
                            Mr. TURPIE moved the order of the election of State Printer, and
                                nominated Colonel, John C. Walker, of Laporte county.
                            Mr. Senator MURRAY nominated Berry R. Sulgrove, of Marion county.
                            The PRESIDING OFFICER of the Senate directed a viva
                                    voce vote in this election, under the constitutional
                                provision.
                            Mr. Anthony failing to answer, a call of the House on the part of the
                                Senate was demanded, and proceeded without result, until it was
                                dispensed with, when the vote was taken.
                            For Walker, 73 votes were cast.
                            For Sulgrove, 68 votes were cast.
                            Mr. Walker having received a majority of the votes cast, was declared
                                elected.
                            In the order for the election of State Agent - 
                            Mr. TURPIE nominated Aquilla Jones, of Marion county.
                            Mr. Senator JONES said he had been requested to withdraw the name of
                                Mr. Jones, and he nominated James A. Cravens, of Washington
                                county.
                            Mr. Senator MURRAY nominated John D. Defrees, of Marion county.
                            Mr. Senator SLACK nominated D. C. Stover, of Montgomery county.
                            Mr. Senator HEFFREN nominated Samuel H. Owen, of Floyd county.
                            
                                
                                     Mr. Defrees received 58 votes.
                                
                                
                                    Mr. Cravens received 42 votes.
                                
                                
                                    Mr. Stover received 17 votes.
                                

                                

                                
                                    Mr. Owen received 10 votes.
                                
                                
                                     Scattering received 11 votes.
                                
                            
                            Mr. Senator HEFFREN withdrew the name of Mr. Owen.
                            On the second ballot - 
                            
                                
                                    Mr. Defrees received 57 votes.
                                
                                
                                    Mr. Cravens received 64 votes.M
                                

                                
                                    Mr. Stover received 7 votes. 
                                
                                
                                    Scattering received 13 votes.
                                
                            
                            
                                
                                    On the third ballot - 
                                
                                
                                    Mr. Defrees received 53 votes.
                                
                                
                                     Mr. Cravens received 59 votes.
                                
                                
                                    Mr. Stover received 8 votes.
                                
                                
                                    Scattering received 12 votes.
                                
                            

                            Mr. HARNEY now withdrew the name of Mr. Stover.
                            On the fourth ballot - 
                            
                                
                                    Mr. Defrees received 52 votes.
                                
                                
                                    Mr. Cravens received 68 votes.
                                
                                
                                    Scattering received 13 votes.
                                
                            

                            Mr. Cravens was declared elected.
                            The Presiding Officer then adjourned the Joint Convention.
                             The House then (at forty minutes past 9 o'clock) adjourned. 
                        
                    

                    

                    

                        IN SENATE
                        
                             SATURDAY, JANUARY 15, 1859. 
                        

                        The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate the
                            annual report of the Superintendent of the Hospital for the Insane;
                            which was referred to the Committee on Benevolent
                                Institutions.
                        

                        
                            HEATING THE SENATE CHAMBER. 
                            Mr. BOBBS submitted the bill of cost for the,' heating apparatus
                                furnished for the Senate Chamber, amounting to $940 00; which was
                                referred to the Committee on Finance without
                                reading.

                        
                        
                            BILLS ON THE FIRST READING.
                             On motion of Mr. CONNER, the order of business was dispensed with,
                                and the following bills were introduced, read the first time and
                                passed to the second reading:
                            By Mr. CONNER, (No. 17) providing for the partition of real estate
                                and for laying the same out into lots and outlots.
                            By Mr. HAMILTON, (No. 18) authorizing incorporations under the
                                general laws of this State to borrow money, and securing the
                                repayment of the same by mortgage.
                            By Mr. GREEN, (No. 19) providing for an enumeration to be made of
                                white inhabitants over 21 years of age in 1860, and every five years
                                thereafter.
                            By Mr. WALLACE, (No. 20) providing for and regulating the payment of
                                costs occasioned by the prosecution and conviction of persons
                                charged with felony, and punishable by imprisonment in the State
                                prison.
                            By Mr. HEFFREN, (No. 21) to prevent the issuing and circulation of
                                unauthorized paper currency, and providing a penalty for failure to
                                redeem any such currency.
                            By Mr. HILL, (No. 22) to prevent the inter-marriage of first cousins,
                                and defining the duties of Clerks of Circuit Courts in issuing
                                license.
                            By Mr. STUDABAKER, (No. 23) fixing the time of holding the Court of
                                Common Pleas in Alien and Adams counties.
                            By Mr. TURNER, (No. 24) to incorporate "the International
                                University."
                            By Mr. BOBBS, (No. 25) to provide for the redemption or purchase of
                                bank bonds, of Indiana State stocks, &c., 
                             By Mr. ANTHONY, (No. 26) to amend section 9 of an act to exempt
                                property from sale in certain cases, approved February 17, 1852.
                            By Mr. HARGROVE, (No. 27) to amend section 63 of an act defining
                                misdemeanors, approved June 14, 1852.
                            By Mr. TARKINGTON, (No. 28) providing for the safe keeping of public
                                moneys, bonds, and other securities entrusted to officers therein
                                mentioned.
                            By Mr. BROWN, (No. 29) to exempt personal property from forced sale
                                on execution.
                            By Mr. HEFFREN, (No. 30) to provide for the transfer of certificates
                                of State stocks, &c., and to prevent the fraudulent issue
                                thereof.
                            By Mr. BEESON, (No. 31) to suppress the publication of lotteries, and
                                defining the punishment therefor.
                            By Mr. BROWN, (No. 32) for the better protection of growing
                                cranberries, and to prohibit the sale or purchase thereof in the
                                time specified.
                            By Mr. FISK, (No. 33) to tax dogs, and indemnify owners of sheep
                                killed or injured by dogs or wolves.
                            By Mr. STEELE, (No. 34) making a misdemeanor, and punishable as such,
                                any assignee guilty of fraud; any person putting a bank note in
                                circulation after it has been redeemed; any person who may try to
                                prevent the speedy return of any bank issue, &c., &c.
                            By Mr. BENNETT, (No. 35) to amend section 433 of the law reform act,
                                approved June 18, 1852.
                            By Mr. RICE, (No. 36) to amend section 6 of an act providing for the
                                valuation and assessment of real and personal property, &c.,
                                approved June 21, 1852, so as to exempt certain property therein
                                named from taxation.
                            [A message from the Governor was here received, announcing his
                                approval and signature of the bill (H. R. 10) establishing a Board
                                of Sinking Fund Commissioners, providing for their election, and
                                prescribing the powers thereof.]
                            By Mr. CULVER, (No. 37) to amend section 4 of an act to provide
                                compensation to owners of animals killed or injured by the cars,
                                locomotives or carriages of railroads, approved March 1, 1853.
                            By Mr. CARNAHAN, (No. 38) to enable industrious indigent persons, who
                                are unable to give security, to rent. land.
                            By Mr. LOMAX, (No. 39) to amend an act providing for the election of
                                Clerks of Circuit  Courts, and
                                prescribing their duties, approved June 7, 1852.
                            By Mr. CONNER, (No. 40) to amend section 157 of an act to provide for
                                the valuation and assessment of real and personal property, approved
                                June 21, 1852.
                            By Mr. GREEN, (No. 41) to separate law books from the State Library,
                                and forming a law library of the State, and for the management and
                                government of the same.
                            By Mr. CONLEY, (No. 42) to repeal an act entitled an act establishing
                                a bank and branches, passed March 3, 1855, the Governor's objections
                                to the contrary, notwithstanding, and setting forth that the act was
                                procured by fraud.
                            By Mr. WILLIAMS, (No. 43) to amend section 33 of an act providing for
                                the valuation and assessment of real and personal property, approved
                                June 21, 1852.
                            By Mr. WAGNER, (No. 44) to change the time for the election of
                                members of Congress, and providing for their election.
                            By Mr. CRAVEN, (No. 45) to provide compensation to owners of animals
                                killed or injured by the cars, locomotives or carriages of any
                                railroad company in this State.
                            [Mr. JENNINGS, by unanimous consent, submitted a resolution, which
                                was adopted, that when the Senate adjourns it stands adjourned until
                                Monday, 2 o'clock P. M.]
                            [Mr. CULVER also, by leave, submitted a resolution, which was
                                adopted, requiring the Committee on the Organization of
                                    Courts, to inquire and report as to the propriety of
                                amending sec. 42, of the act of May 14, 1852, so as to require a
                                portion of said term to be set apart for probate business.]
                            By Mr. WALLACE, (No. 46) to amend section 4 of an act providing for
                                the election, fixing the compensation and prescribing the duties of
                                the Attorney General of the State of Indiana.
                            By Mr. COBB, (No. 47) to repeal an act providing for the protection
                                of wild game, approved February 26, 1857.
                            By Mr. MARCH, (No. 48) to repeal an act to provide for the election,
                                fixing the compensation and prescribing the duties of the Attorney
                                General of the State of Indiana.
                            By Mr. BOBBS, (No. 49) fixing the time of holding Courts in the Fifth
                                Judicial Circuit.
                            By Mr. HARGROVE, (No. 50) to amend section 16 of an act concerning
                                the partition of lands, approved May 2, 1862.
                            By Mr. WAGNER, (No. 51) for the better protection of religious
                                meetings, agricultural fairs and other lawful assemblages of the
                                people.
                            [The PRESIDENT pro tempore designed Senators Wallace, Tarkington and
                                Conner, as the committee, authorized by a resolution adopted
                                yesterday, to prepare and submit to the Senate, a bill defining the
                                duties of the Commissioners and President of the Sinking Fund.]
                            By Mr. BOBBS, (No. 52) to provide a site and place for the erection
                                of a House of Refuge for the reformation and correction of juvenile
                                offenders.
                            By Mr. CARNAHAN, (No. 53) authorizing County Commissioners to award
                                compensation to persons who may bring fugitives to justice.
                            [The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate
                                the annual report of the President of the Bank of the State of
                                Indiana, containing a statement of the condition of the bank and its
                                branches on the 20th of November 1858, which was laid on the table
                                and 200 copies ordered to be printed.]
                            By Mr. WAGNER, (No. 54) to amend an act authorizing the formation of
                                new counties and changing county boundaries, approved May 7,
                                1857.
                            By Mr. CONNER, (No. 55) to amend section 315 of the law reform act,
                                approved June 18, 1852.
                            By Mr. BLAIR, (No. 56) to amend sections 1 and 27 of an act providing
                                for the election of supervisors of highways, approved June 18,
                                1852.
                            By Mr. HILL, (No. 57) authorizing township trustees to establish
                                water courses, &c,
                            By Mr. TURNER, (No. 58) to amend section 14 of an act for the
                                reformation of the Hospital for the Insane, approved January 15,
                                1852.

                        
                        
                            "INDIANA SCHOOL JOURNAL." 
                            Mr. CONLEY, by leave, offered a resolution which was adopted,
                                directing the Committee on Education to report a
                                bill providing for placing a bound copy of the Indiana State Journal
                                in all the school libraries in the State.
                        
                        
                             STATE LIBRARY.
                            Mr. WALLACE had leave to offer a resolution, which was adopted,
                                directing the Librarian to prepare a complete catalogue of books in
                                the State Library, for the use of those having the privilege of the
                                same.
                            And then the Senate adjourned till Monday two o'clock P. M.
                        


                    
                    
                    

                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
                        
                             SATURDAY, JANUARY 15, 1859. 
                        
                         Leave of absence till Monday was accorded to Messrs. Carr, Parks, Kempf,
                            Robinson, Whetzel and Hall, of Rush; and to Mr. Knowlton till Wednesday,
                            on account of sickness in his family.
                        
                            ADJOURNMENT TILL MONDAY.
                             Mr. SNYDER submitted a resolution making it a standing rule to
                                adjourn from Saturday at 11 A. M. to Monday, 2 P. M.
                            The SPEAKER. It can not be considered now because it proposes a new
                                rule.
                            Mr. SNYDER withdrew the resolution, and moved to suspend the order of
                                business to enable him to make a motion to take up Mr. Park's
                                resolution, submitted last Thursday, which proposes a standing rule
                                for Saturday's adjournment, to the same effect.
                            
                            Mr. POWER should vote for the resolution,out of consideration for
                                those members standing here in opposition to the Republican
                                party,who had been to a weding and infair last night and needed
                                rest. [Laughter.]
                            The rules were suspended and the resolution was taken up.
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush.The adoption of this rule would not retard
                                business.
                            Mr. MURRAY preferred that gentlemen gohome on leave, and leave a
                                sufficient number disposed to work, at least to read the journal and
                                submit their reports, and asked the House to vote the resolution
                                down.
                            Mr. RITTER was willing to adopt the rule provided the House would act
                                upon another rule - not to excuse the aboence of any gentleman,
                                except for sickness in his family. The fact was, we sit here too
                                long. It was a clog to legislation to sit here when we ought to be
                                at work in the committees. 
                        
                        
                             BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
                             A message from the Senate by Mr. Vawter,their Secretary, announced
                                the adoption in that body of the following resolution: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the Door-keeper be
                                            directed to contract A. E. Drapier & Son for six
                                            hundred copies of "Brevier Legislative Reports" of the
                                            Proceedings and Debates the present General Assembly,
                                            after the style of their reports of the proceedings of
                                            the late extra session in the"Legislative Sentinel" -
                                            said reports to be made up from columns of some daily
                                            newspaper printed in the town of Indianapolis, and laid
                                            upon the desks of members as fast as they shall complete
                                            sixteen pages in double newspaper column: provided the
                                            cost of the same shall not exceed one dollar per copy,
                                            the House adopting a similar resolution.
                                    
                                
                            
                             [A message from the Governor, by Mr. Osburn, Executive Messenger,
                                announced that his Excellency had approved and signed the Fund
                                Commissioners bill (18. 12.10.) introduced by Mr. Smith, of
                                Perry.]
                            The rule for adjourning over from 11 till Monday 2 o'clock was
                                adopted, by yeas 25, nays 29. 
                        
                        
                             WOMAN'S RIGHTS.
                            Mr. WHITEMAN moved further to suspend the rules to enable him to make
                                a motion to take up the consideration of the Senate's concurrent
                                resolution; inviting certain ladies to present a petition in their
                                own persons, in the Hall of the House of Representatives, on
                                Wednesday next, the 19th instant, at 2 o'clock P. M.
                            The motion was agreed to and the resolution was taken up.
                            On the motion of Mr. DOUGHERTY, the blank was filled with "two."
                            Mr. MERRIFIELD, and Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison, demanded the yeas and
                                nays on the question of concurrence.
                            Mr. BRANHAM hoped the House would not concur. He was in favor of the
                                right of petition, but did not think it right to waste the time of
                                the House with such an exhibition as was proposed. It was
                                unnecessary for these petitioners to come into this presence. If
                                they wish to petition for a redress of grievance, let them proceed
                                as in other cases of petition to the Legislature. He considered it
                                due to the reputation of our wives and mothers to refuse to concur
                                in this resolution.
                            Mr. LAWHED spoke in favor of the adoption of the resolution.
                            Mr. STILES should vote against the resolution out of consideration
                                for the sex.
                            Mr. DEVOL, understanding that the petition was to be presented by the
                                ladies in person, was very anxious that the resolution should be
                                concurred in.
                            Mr. CLAYTON thought this was carrying the joke a little too far in
                                the way of petition. Such an exhibition he believed had never before
                                been proposed in a deliberative body.
                            Mr. MURRAY was willing to concur in the resolution, with the
                                following amendment:
                            
                                "That the House will not organize till said
                                    petition is presented, and the parties presenting the same shall
                                    retire from this Hall."
                            
                            If he understood the reading of the resolution, it was that this
                                petition should be presented in person by the ladies at 2 o'clock
                                next Wednesday. He was in favor of giving the ladies the use of the
                                Hall for the presentation of their petition. They desired to present
                                it to the Legislature to read it themselves. He supposed it was to
                                be read. It was directed to the Legislature of the State of Indiana,
                                and all the ladies claimed was the right to read it to us as the
                                Legislature of the State. With the gentleman from Jefferson, (Mr.
                                Branham,) he held that it would be setting a bad example to give the
                                right to these ladies to come in here and occupy our time; for if we
                                allow it to them, we ought not to with old the same right to the
                                humblest petitioner in the State. But what right had the Senate to
                                set apart this Hall for this purpose? Why did they not permit the
                                ladies to come into their chamber?
                            Mr. POWER should vote for the resolution, because his mother was a
                                woman, and because he loved the ladies generally.
                            The SPEAKER. On reflection, the Chair decides the amendment out of
                                order.
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, did not under stand the programme; but if the
                                petition was to be presented by the ladies in person - read by
                                themselves, and acted on here under their influence and dictation,
                                he could not but be apprehensive for the result of such legislation.
                                Still he could not refuse the exercise of the right of petition, and
                                would vote for the resolution with the proposed modification.
                            Mr. COLGROVE interupting. Is the gentleman from Boone a married
                                man?
                            Mr. HAMILTON. I am, sir, and have three little babies.
                            Mr. COLGROVE. Then it was not to be supposed that the gentleman was
                                in danger of coming too much under the influence of these ladies.
                                [Laughter.]
                            Mr. Speaker GORDON (Mr. Blythe in the Chair) was never averse to
                                doing an act of  kindness - and
                                least of all doing an act of kindness to the gentler sex. He did not
                                think we could consume more time in the hearing of the proposed
                                petition, than we have occupied this morning in discussing this
                                resolution. Many ladies (he continued) not only in our own State,
                                but in every State of the Union, deem themselves neglected, and
                                their God-given rights withheld by our legislation. This may be
                                true. I am not going to discuss that. But I will say that they
                                certainly have the right of petition. There can be no discussion
                                about the right - the only question is as to the manner of
                                petitioning. Here the ladies ask to be heard - to present their
                                petition in their own proper persons - to present their grievances
                                in their own way. And as for the influence of their presence here,
                                there was need for it this moment to repress the discourteous
                                language of gentlemen, for who could believe that in the presence of
                                ladies, any gentleman could indulge in expressions of contempt for
                                their proposition? Gentlemen have made themselves merry over it -
                                have made this proposition a subject of burlesque and ridicule. It
                                is not right that ladies should be treated in that way. If we look
                                at the history of the right of petition, and the manner in which it
                                has been exercised in connection with legislation - all we have of
                                this is derived from the parliamentary history of Great Britain - we
                                shall find it as old as the right of representation in that Island,
                                that men and women entered the parliament of Great Britain,
                                submitting their grievances in their own proper persons. We find
                                laws enacted to limit the number that shall present a petition, and
                                to restrain petitioners from coming into the parliament with arms
                                upon their persons, so that the lives and liberties of members might
                                not be endangered. But here, sir, there is no danger from these
                                ladies. True, some of us may be conquered by them, but if so, of
                                course it will be in a way that we can not regret. I hope, indeed,
                                that we may be conquerred so far as to do justice, and to be
                                courteous in all cases where the rights of ladies are in the
                                question - that, we shall have the manhood to give to the ladies
                                that position in civil society which shall enable them to press the
                                demand for all their right to the utmost extent - to the very
                                furthest verge. This is due to them. Let us remember that the ladies
                                constitute half the people of the State, and, as we all say, the
                                better half.
                            Mr. MURRAY interrupting. Does the gentleman know the object of the
                                proposed petition?
                            Mr. GORDON. I do not. I know some of the ladies concerned in it. I
                                have the honor to be acquainted with Mrs. Thomas and Mrs. Birdsall,
                                who have both written to me upon the subject, and I will here say,
                                that more worthy or intelligent ladies do not live in the State of
                                Indiana. They are ornaments to the State and to their sex. * * * *I
                                am just now informed of their object. Part of it I should vote
                                against and part of it I should be willing to concede. The first is
                                to give them an equal right with men to property. The second is to
                                give them the right of sufrage. They reason that the right of
                                taxation follows the right of property, and that taxation and
                                representation should go together. There is force in this. It was
                                upon this very ground that our fathers went to war in 1776.
                            Mr. GIFFORD, Mr. MERRIFIELD and Mr. MANSFIELD each spoke against
                                concurra and the resolution was further supported Messrs. SCOTT,
                                HALL, of Rush, and Mr. LAWHEAD.
                            Mr. RITTER demanded the previous question, and under its force the
                                House concurred by yeas 44, nays 37 - as follows:
                            
                                
                                    

                                        YEAS - Messrs. Austin, Bowman, Boyd,
                                            Boxley, Brotherton, Clark, Colgrove, Collier, Comstock,
                                            Cotton, Davidson, Dougherty, Devol, Early, Firestone,
                                            Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Eush, Hamilton of Wayne,
                                            Harney, Jeffries, Johnston, Jordan. Keefer, Kelley,
                                            Lawhead, McLain, Miller, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker
                                            of Warren, Parks, Power, Scott, Shockley, Smith of
                                            Miami, Snyder, Stanley, Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway,
                                            Usrey, Waterman, Whiteman, Wildman and Mr. Speaker -
                                            44.

                                        NAYS - Messrs. Baird, Blythe. Branham,
                                            Cavins, Claypool, Clayton, Dobbins, Durham, Edwards,
                                            Fordyce, Gifford, Gregory, Hamilton of Boone, Hartley,
                                            Jones, Lewis, Major, Mansfield, Massey, Merrifield,
                                            Murray, Martin, Nelson, Parrett, Prosser, Ritter, Row,
                                            Shields, Shull, Smith of Perry, Stiles, Stinson,
                                            Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Turpie and Wood37.
                                        
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                            BANK OF THE STATE OF INDIANA.
                            The SPEAKER laid before the House the reports from the officers of
                                the Bank of the State of Indiana and its several Branches.
                            On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, they were referred, without reading, to the
                                    Committee on Banks. 
                        
                        
                             ASYLUM FOR THE DEAF AND DUMB. 
                            The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from Thomas
                                McIntyre, Superintendent of the Hospital for the Deaf and Dumb,
                                appointing next Wednesday even: for the time, and Masonic Hall the
                                place, for an exhibition of the proficiency of the pupils under his
                                care - no tickets to be given out but to members, who are invited to
                                occupy reserved seats.
                            It was referred to the Committee on Benevolent
                                    Institutions. 
                        
                        
                             HOSPITAL FOR THE INSANE.
                            The SPEAKER laid before the House the annual report of Dr. James S.
                                Athon, Superintendent of the Indiana Hospital for the Insane for the
                                year ending October 31, 1858.
                            On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, it was ordered that it lie on the table -
                                the order for printing to be made on Monday. 
                        
                        
                             FOREIGN WILLS.
                            Mr. STILES asked and obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 67) in
                                regard to the contest of foreign wills and testaments, [parties
                                interested in foreign wills admitted to probate  may contest under the legal provisions
                                for contests in cases of the probate of domestic wills,] which was
                                passed the first reading.
                            Mr. STILES asked that the rules be suspended to enable him to move
                                the second reading of the bill.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY would ask whether the bill is not intended to apply to
                                a special casethe will of the late Hon. H. L. Ellsworth.
                            Mr. STILES. Only in part. The law now provides only for the contest
                                of domestic wills. If a person dies out of the State, and his will
                                be brought into the State, there is no provision for contest, but in
                                compliance with the provisions of the law of the State where the
                                testator died. If the rules were suspended, I should move to refer
                                the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary.
                            The rules were suspended by yeas 69, nays 63; and then without
                                further action.
                            The House (at 11 o'clock,) adjourned till Monday 2 o'clock, P. M.
                            
                        
                    
                    

                    

                        IN SENATE.
                        
                             MONDAY, JANUARY, 17, 1859. 
                        
                         The hour having arrived for the special order, it being the
                            consideration of the Governor's Message - 
                        On motion by Mr. McLEAN, the Senate went into Committee of the
                                Whole.
                        The PRESIDENT pro tem, called Mr. Mc-Lean to the
                            Chair.
                        After some time spent therein - 
                        The committee rose, and the Chairman reported the adoption of sundry
                            resolutions, referring various portions and recommendations in the
                            message to appropriate committees, which were concurred in. 

                        
                            BILLS ON THE SECOND READING.
                            Mr. Cravens' (S. 1) to amend the law granting divorces. Read and
                                referred to the Judiciary Committee.
                            Mr. Wallace's (S. 2) regulating the election of United States
                                Senators. Read and referred to a select committee of five.
                            Mr. Studabaker's (S. 4) to amend an act for the valuation and
                                appraisement of real property and the collection of taxes, the
                                election of township assessors, &c. Read a second time and
                                ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. Bennett's (S. 5) to amend an act to regulate the interest on
                                money. Read and referred to the Committee on
                                    Finance.
                            Mr. Slack's (S. 6) to provide for the safe keeping of the public
                                moneys of the State, and prescribing the duty of the State Treasurer
                                in relation thereto, was read the second time, and,
                            On motion by Mr. WALLACE, 200 copies were ordered to be printed.
                            Mr. Tarkington's (S. 7) to prohibit the issue of unauthorized Bank
                                notes, &c.r was read the second time, and referred to the
                                    Committee on Banks.
                            Mr. Hamilton's (S. 9) for the creation of townships, election of
                                trustees, &c., was read twice, and referred to the
                                    Committee on Township Business.
                            Mr. Fisk's (S. 10) to regulate and restrain the sale of spirituous
                                liquors, &c., was read the second time, which was referred to a
                                select committee of one from each Congressional District.
                            Mr. CONNER wished the bill to go to the Committee on
                                    Temperance, that they could examine the different
                                bills on the same subject, and report a bill embracing the best
                                provisions contained in the different bills.
                            Mr. STEELE hoped the gentleman from Wabash would withdraw his motion
                                to refer his bill to the Temperance Committee, as
                                this bill's author [Mr. Fisk] was in favor of a license law. He [Mr.
                                Steele] was in favor of that kind of law, provided we could not pass
                                something better in the shape of Senator Hill's bill. He earnestly
                                hoped that this bill might go to a select committee. Let them
                                perfect a bill of that kind, and then let the genuine temperance men
                                from their committee perfect their's, and if we can not pass one, I
                                do hope we may make the other a law before we adjourn.
                            Mr. CONNER withdrew his motion, and Mr. Fisk's motion prevailing - 
                            The PRESIDENT pro tempore made the committee to
                                consist of Messrs. Carnahan, Heffren, Crane, Fisk, Kinley, Blair,
                                Steele, Wallace, Weir, Hamilton and Murray.
                            Mr. LINE submitted instructions to the Committee on County and
                                Township Business, to which was referred bill (S. 9) to strike out
                                one trustee wherever it occurs, and insert three; and also that they
                                may hold four meetings in the year.
                            The debate on Mr. Line's instructions was resumed and was
                                participated in by Messrs. Tarkington, Line, Studabaker, Wagner,
                                Williams, Anthony and Murray.
                            Mr. TARKINGTON offered an amendment to the instructions, that a
                                committee report a bill giving the Board of County Commissioners
                                jurisdiction of the locating, opening, re-opening of roads; the
                                appointment of supervisors when not elected the appointment of one
                                trustee for each township, who shall discharge the duties that the
                                inspectors of election, overseers of the poor, and fence viewers did
                                under the revised laws of 1843.
                            Mr. JOHNSTON offered an amendment to the amendment, to the effect
                                that the committee be instructed to confer with the
                                    Committee on Education, and that the
                                committees report separate bills.
                            The amendments were accepted by Mr. LINE, and the instructions were
                                adopted.
                            On motion by Mr. MARCH, the order of business was suspended, and
                                messages from the House were taken up.
                            A Joint Resolution that a committee of two  on the part of the Senate, be
                                appointed to act with three on the part of the House, to examine the
                                books, vouchers, &c., of the Agent of State and Trustees of the
                                State Prison was taken up and concurred in by consent.
                            Mr. Bobbs' bill (S. 11) was read and laid on the table; the House
                                having proposed a bill similar in its provisions.
                            Mr. Jeffries' bill, (S 12,) making the taking of unlawful interest a
                                misdemeanor, and prescribing punishment therefor, was passed the
                                second reading, and referred to the Committee on
                                    Finance.
                            Mr. Turner's bill, (S. 13) to amend certain provisions of the law in
                                relation to swamp lands, coming up on the second reading - 
                            On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the rules were suspended, by a vote of yeas
                                36, nays 1; the bill read the second time by its title, and referred
                                to the Committee on Swamp Lands.
                            Mr. BENNETT offered a resolution, that the Door-keeper be directed to
                                distribute documents equally among members, which was adopted.
                            Mr. WAGNER introduced a bill, (No. 59,) supplemental to an act to
                                provide for a general system of common schools, &c., which was
                                passed the first reading.
                            The Senate adjourned. 

                        
                    
                    


                    

                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
                        
                             MONDAY, JANUARY, 17, 1859. 
                        
                        
                            INSANE ASYLUM.
                            Mr. EDWARDS stated that the Superintendent of the Insane Asylum had
                                advised him that more copies of his report was demanded of him than
                                he was usually supplied with, and that he asked now for 3,000
                                copies. He therefore moved that 5,000 copies be printed for the use
                                of the Superintendent, in addition to the 3,000 copies required by
                                law.
                            The motion was agreed to.
                            Mr. Stinson and Mr. Hancock had leave of absence on account of ill
                                health.
                            Mr. SCOTT presented the petitions of many citizens of Laporte county
                                recommending such amendment of the law in relation to landlord and
                                tenant as shall make the landlord's claim for rent a lein on all the
                                personal property of the tenant, without relief from valuation and
                                appraisement laws; which being read, he moved that it be referred to
                                the Committee on Judiciary, but - 
                            On the motion of Mr. GIFFORD, it was referred to the
                                    Committee on Rights and Privileges.
                            Mr. HALL, of Grant, presented tho petition of sundry citizens of
                                Grant county, praying for the enactment of a law to rid community of
                                the evils of intemperance, which was read and referred to the
                                    Committee on Temperance.
                            Mr. BRANHAM presented the petition of J. P. Drake and M. G. Bright,
                                praying relief as the securities of Alien May, from his alleged
                                liabilities; which was read and referred the  Committee on
                                    the Judiciary.
                            
                        
                        
                            DEPUTY AUDITORS AND TREASURERS.
                            Mr. BAIRD, from the Committee on the Judiciary,
                                returned the resolution instructing them to inquire into the
                                propriety of enacting a law prohibiting deputy auditors from acting
                                as deputy treasurers, and deputy treasurers from acting as deputy
                                auditors, with the expression of opinion that legislation on the
                                subject is inexpedient.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. SCOTT, from the Committee on Judiciary,
                                returned the resolution, directing them to enquire into
                                constitutionality of the forms and precedents found in the Statutes
                                of 1852 both civil and criminal, and reported a motion for the
                                indefinite postponement of the resolution.
                            The report was concurred in. 

                        
                        
                            PUBLIC BUILDINGS.

                            Mr. SCOTT, from the same Committee, returned Mr. Ritter's bill (8) to
                                preserve public buildings and prescribing penalties for unlawfully
                                occupying the same, reported the same back, recommending that it be
                                indefinitely postponed.
                            Mr. RTTTER said he had introduced that bill at the request of many
                                citizens of the State. The law now punishes for injuries to public
                                buildings as for trespass and damages, This bill would make such an
                                act a misdemeanor and punish it accordingly. He considered a law
                                could hardly be passed of so little importance that would please the
                                people more than this.
                            Mr. COLGROVE. The offenses in the bill amounted to nothing more than
                                trespasses, and the committee thought the laws on that subject were
                                ample, if executed; and if not executed, it was perhaps useless to
                                have any law on the subject.
                            The report was concurred in. 
                        
                        
                            HORSE THIEF DETECTING SOCIETIES.

                            Mr. COLGROVE, from the Judiciary Committee, to
                                which was referred the resolution referring so much of the
                                Governor's Message as relates to companies formed for the purpose of
                                detecting horse theives and other felons, reported that said
                                committee have had the same under consideration, directed him to
                                report a bill and recommend its passage and accordingly - 
                            The Judiciary Committee's bill (No 68) to repeal
                                the act authorizing the formation of companies for the apprehension
                                of horse theives and other felons and defining their powers,
                                approved March 9, 1852, was reported and passed the first
                                reading.

                        
                        
                             UNAUTHORIZED BANK PAPER.
                            Mr. COLGROVE, from the fame committee, returned Mr. Martin's bill
                                (12) to prevent the issuance and circulation of unauthorized paper
                                currency, and to prescribe penalties for issuance and failure to redeem all such
                                currency, without amendment, and with a recommendation that the same
                                do pass.
                            The bill was, accordingly, ordered to be engrossed, and then - 
                            On the motion of Mr. MARTIN, it was considered as engrossed, read and
                                passed the third and last reading in the House of Representatives,
                                by yeas 76, nays 0. 
                        
                        
                             DIVORCE LAW.
                            On motion of Mr. JOHNSON, it was

                                            of so amending the divorce law as to require both
                                            parties to have residence in the Slate at least twelve
                                            months previous to the time of application for divorce,
                                            and report by bill or otherwise.

Gilpin for such services.

                                                Committee be instructed to report a bill
                                            repealing so much of the law for the collection of the
