                            The House then took a recess till 2 o'clock.
                        
                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                            WOMAN'S RIGHTS.
                            Mr. PROSSER submitted a resolution inviting Senators, instanter, into
                                joint convention to been informed that ladies from my county have
                                hear the petition of women, pursuant to a concurrent resolution, for
                                that purpose, adopted last Friday, and that seats be prepared for
                                them on the right of the Speaker's Chair.
                            A VOICE. That's impossible.[The inner tiers of
                                seats were already occupied by ladies.]
                            Mr. KEEFER. I propose to amend, so as to provide seats in the
                                galleries
                            The SPEAKER. The amendment is out of order.
                            The resolution was adopted.
                            A call of the House was demanded, but objection being made, the House
                                refused to order a call.
                            Mr. TURPIE. Mr. Speaker, I move that theHouse resolve into Committee
                                of the Whole to hear this petition.
                            The SPEAKER. The motion of the gentleman can not be entertained. The
                                order is that the petition shall be heard in joint convention of the
                                two Houses.
                            Mr. DAVIS. Will this appear on the Journal?
                            The SPEAKER. The Convention for hearing the petition will appear on
                                the Journal.
                            The Senators now appeared in the Hall, and the President called the
                                Convention to order.
                            The PRESIDING OFFICER. Gentlemen of the Senate and House of
                                Representatives : In pursuance of a resolution adopted by both
                                Houses, you are now convened for the purpose of hearing a portion of
                                the Ladies of Indiana on behalf of themselves and their rights.
                            Mr. DAVIS. This is a very grave and important matter, and it seems to
                                me that we ought to have positions favorable to hearing and
                                understanding everything upon which we are called to act. A number
                                of Senators and others here are in a position that we can neither
                                see nor hear.
                            Mr. Senator BENNETT. There is a great deal of wisdom in that body (of
                                the Senate,) and it ought to be provided for
                            .Mr. DAVIS. I have to request that room be made especially for the
                                Senator from Vigo as the only bachelor in that body. [Laughter.]
                            Mr. EDWARDS. I object to that, on the part of my Senator.
                            The PRESIDING OFFICER. The hour having arrived, appointed for the
                                purpose of hearing the petition on behalf of the ladies, if those
                                entrusted with the matter are present, they will now proceed.
                            Mr. Senator SLACK. (Standing forward in the front aisle with Mr.
                                Senator McLean.) The Senator from Vigo is present. [Cheers and
                                laughter.]
                            Mr. McLEAN. Mr. President, I am overwhelmed. [Cheers and laughter
                                continued.]
                            Mr. CLEMENTS. I move that we proceed. I understand that this memorial
                                is to be read by the ladies themselves.
                            The PRESIDING OFFICER. That is the order If the ladies are present, a
                                place will be made for them at this table.
                            A VOICE. The gentleman from Wayne can tell who is
                                to read.
                            Mr. AUSTIN. I am not able to inform the Convention. I have had no
                                interview with any of the ladies expected to appear here. I have
                                arrived in the city, who are expected to present that petition, but
                                I presume they are not now in the House.
                            Mr. EDWARDS. I suggested the Senator from Wayne, who introduced the
                                resolution calling this joint convention. [Consent.]
                            Mr. AUSTIN. If my recollection serves me, half-past 2 was the hour
                                appointed for the presentation of the petition.
                            The PRESIDING OFFICER. The Chair is informed that that is the
                                hour.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY. 2 o'clock is the time. It was fixed on my motion.
                                [Sensation.]
                            Mr. COLGROVE. I understand that the ladies who are to present this
                                petition will be present in a few minutes.
                            Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren. During this interval, it has been suggested
                                that the best looking bachelor address the assembly. [Vociferous
                                cheers and cries for "Nebeker""Nebeker, of Warren."
                            Mr. NEBKKER. Gentlemen cannot be well informed. I am not a bachelor.
                                I had reference particularly to the gentleman from Vigo. [Cheers and
                                cries for "Edwards."]
                            Mr. EDWARDS. I waive my pretentions for the gentleman from Warren to
                                give him an opportunity to exhibit his personal beauty, [Laughter
                                and cries again for "Nebeker," which subsided under the hammer from
                                the Chair.]
                            Mrs. Thomas, Mrs. Birdsall and Mrs. Cook, ladies of Wayne county, now
                                came forward and took seats at the Speaker's table.
                            The PRESIDING OFFICER introduced Mrs. Thomas to the Convention.
                            Mrs. THOMAS said: Permit me, friends, to say a word before reading
                                our petition. Brothers and sisters, we have not come here to exhibit
                                ourselves as a show to our brothers of the General Assembly. We have
                                come here feeling deeply the need of that which we petition of you;
                                and I beg of you to receive us as becomes our cause and your
                                position in this place. Gentlemen, we now read to you our petition,
                                as representatives of the women of the State of Indiana.
                            The petition was read in a few plain words - asking the General
                                Assembly to advance the women of the State to the same rights of
                                property now enjoyed by men; and for such an amendment of the
                                Constitution as shall confer the right or suffrage upon women.
                            An address in writing was then read to the Convention by Mrs. Thomas
                                - reasoning at length upon the subjects of the petition, and
                                stating, amongst others things, that the petition was signed by
                                nearly a thousand residents of the State, and that the number would
                                have been tens of thousands, but for the lack of effort to circulate
                                it. It was, properly, the petition of the ladies of Wayne county.
                                When Mrs. T. had concluded - 
                            
                             The PRESIDING OFFICER introduced to the Convention - 
                            Mrs. BIRDSALL, who read a very clear and logical plea in behalf of
                                the right of suffrage in womanand its exercise in this Stateif it
                                should be her pleasure.
                            Mrs. COOK followed in an extemporaneous address on the subject of
                                Temperance - making allusion to the unchivalric remark of one of the
                                orators of the State Temperance Convention yesterday, to this
                                effect: "We will hold the ladies' bonnets whilst they shall fight
                                the doggeries." Nevertheless, the lady was willing to strive in the
                                good work, but it was hinted how much more effectual would be the
                                work of the enfranchised woman in the cause of Temperance.
                            Mr. Senator STEELE submitted a resolution, which was adopted, to the
                                effect that the foregoing addresses of Mrs. Thomas and Mrs.
                                Bird-sail be spread upon the journals of the two houses.
                            Mr. DAVIS. if we are to have resolutions here, it were as well to
                                introduce bills and pass them.
                            Mr. Senator TURNER submitted the following:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the publishers of the
                                            papers of this city, and all other papers friendly to
                                            the cause of Woman's Rights, be respectfully requested
                                            to publish these proceedings, together with the
                                            addresses.

                                    
                                
                            
                             The PRESIDING OFFICER. Gentlemen of the Convention, you have now
                                given your attention to the petition which has been read on behalf
                                of the women of the State. You can go no further now, though there
                                may be material matter in this petition for your future
                                deliberation. The Senators will, therefore, now retire to their
                                chamber.
                            So the joint convention was dissolved.
                            The SPEAKER called the House to order.
                            Mr. DAVIS and Mr. LAWHEAD moved adjournment.
                            The SPEAKER, still calling to order, did not entertain the
                                motion.
                            Mr. MURRAY moved a call of the House, which was refused.
                            The SPEAKER. The Door keeper will clear the aisles and lobbies.
                            A VOICE. They never will clear as long as the
                                ladies remain.
                            On the motion of Mr. MURRAY, the House resolved itself into a
                                Committee of the Whole- Mr.MURRAY in the Chairand took up the
                                consideration of the woman's rights petition; and after three
                                minutes spent therein, the committee rose, and the Chairman reported
                                a motion, that the further consideration of the subject be
                                postponed, and that it be made the special order for Friday, two
                                o'clock. P. M., and that the Committee of the
                                    Whole be discharged.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, moved a recess of half an hour; but - 
                            On motion of Mr. DOBBINS, at half past three o'clock - 
                            The House adjourned. 

                        
                    
                    
                    

                        IN SENATE
                        
                             THURSDAY, JANUARY 20, 1859. 
                        
                        
                             WOMAN'S RIGHTS.
                             Mr. JOHNSTON moved to expunge from the journal the resolution
                                adopted by the joint convention, of yesterday, ordering the
                                recording of the addresses of Mrs. Thomas and Mrs. Birdsall. On
                                motion by Mr. BEESON, this motion was tabled - yeas 26, nays 15.
                            
                        
                        
                            PETITIONS.
                            By Mr. STUDABAKER, from Wells county, on the improvement of stock,
                                which was referred to the Committee on
                                    Agriculture.
                            By Mr. JENNINGS, from Johnson county, on temperance, which was
                                referred to the Temperance Committee. 
                        
                        
                            ATTORNEY GENERAL.
                            Mr. WEIR offered the following resolution, which was adopted: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, the Attorney General be
                                            requested to inform the Senate the reasons why the suit
                                            in Floyd Circuit Court, in favor of the State vs.
                                            Newland, was dismissed, and why the same was not
                                            attended to by him.
                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. MARCH offered the following, which was adopted 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the Attorney General be
                                            requested to report to the Senate the number and name of
                                            the cases in which he has been employed, or in which he
                                            has given a written opinion in the discharge of his
                                            official duties, during the last and present term of his
                                            office.
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                             TEMPERANCE.
                             MR. STEVENS offered the following, which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the Committee
                                                on Temperance be requested to inquire into
                                            the expediency of incorporating into any bill they may
                                            report, a provision that all liquors sold by any person,
                                            under the provisions of such bill, shall not be drank in
                                            or about the house where sold.
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                            CONSTABLES.
                             Mr. THOMPSON offered the following, which was adopted. 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the Committee
                                                on County and Township Business be
                                            directed to inquire into the expediency of requiring
                                            Constables to file their official bonds with the
                                            Treasurer of the township in which they are elected,
                                            respectively.
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                            ABANDONED ROADS.
                             Mr. ODELL offered the following, which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        WHEREAS, There are a number of plank,
                                            turnpike, gravel and M'Adamized roads in this State,
                                            that have been suffered to get and remain out of repair
                                            for an unreasonable length of time: And Whereas, there
                                            are many of such roads that have been partially
                                            abandoned: Therefore, be it - 
                                        Resolved, That the Judiciary Committee
                                            be requested to inquire into the expediency of
                                            introducing a bill to provide the mode and manner by
                                            which the rights of the owners of such roads may be
                                            declared forfeited; and that they report by bill or
                                            otherwise.
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                             ROAD LAW.
                            Mr. SHOEMAKER offered the following, which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the Committee on
                                                Roads be requested to inquire into the
                                            expediency of revising the road law and of printing and
                                            binding in pamphlet form, ten thousand copies thereof,
                                            for the use of Supervisors, and report by bill or
                                            otherwise.
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                            BANK TAX.
                            Mr. WEIR offered the following:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That it is the sense of this
                                            Senate, that the law should be so amended as to require
                                            the Bank of the State of Indiana to pay corporation
                                            taxes.
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. HAMILTON moved ics reference to the Committee on
                                    Banks. He said he would prefer that it be made a
                                resolution of inquiry, but he should favor such a proposition. 
                             Mr. GOODING wished to bring the Senate to a direct vote upon the
                                simple question, ought banks to be exempt from corporation taxes? He
                                presumed every honorable Senator was ready and willing to take
                                grounds upon this question. Let us settle it this morning without
                                referring it to a committee.
                            Mr. BENNETT was willing to vote for a law of the kind contemplated in
                                the resolution, providing a committee report that it is expedient,
                                but he was not prepared to vote for the resolution, as imperative as
                                it is.
                            Mr. McLEAN would vote for a resolution of inquiry upon the subject,
                                but he held the Batik charter to be a contract made by the
                                Legislature as agent of the people of the State; the people were the
                                principal, and the principal is bound by the acts of the agent.
                            Mr. WEIR sustained his resolution in a few remarks. He thought the
                                Legislature unquestionably had the power to amend this act so as to
                                make the banks pay corporation taxes.
                            Mr. HEFFREN thought the passage of this resolution would have no
                                effect, unless the law proposed to be enacted should be consented to
                                by a majority of the President and Directors of each branch.
                            Mr. WEIR made an ineffectual motion to lay the reference motion on
                                the tableyeas 20, nays 23.
                            Mr. STUDABAKER moved to amend the motion to refer by substituting the
                                Judiciary Committee instead of the Committee on
                                    Banks.
                            Mr. HAMILTON accepted the amendment.
                            Mr. STEELE would say, as a member of the Committee on
                                    Banks, that he was distinctly in favor of the
                                proposition, and has always been.
                            Mr. MARCH thought it was not very material to which committee the
                                resolution was referred. He trusted there would be no hasty action
                                in the passage of the resolution, although he was in favor of the
                                proposition. He was opposed to taking any action at this time which
                                would recognize the validity of this bank charter.
                            Mr. WAGNER said this was a resolution of expediency, and he thought
                                it should go to the Committee on Banks. He moved
                                to amend the the motion to refer so that it shall go to the
                                Committee on Banks.
                            Mr. GOODING wanted to say one thing, in order that the anti-bank men
                                of the Legislature may not be caught napping. He had no doubt these
                                bank men would be glad to make a compromise with us to bring in a
                                bill amending the charter, and thus making us acknowledge the
                                legality of that institution. He was in favor of cutting it up by
                                the roots and throwing it out into outer darkness. This bank charter
                                is nothing more nor less than a law which any Legislature may
                                repeal.
                            Mr. STEELE thought that this last declaration of the Senator from
                                Hancock, [Mr. Gooding] was a montrosity.
                            Mr. BOBBS thought the charter was good, and that it was managed
                                fairly.
                            On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, the resolution and pending amendments
                                were laid on the table.
                        
                        
                             EMPLOYEES OF THE SENATE. 
                            Mr. WILLIAMS offered the following, which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,Resolved, That in the opinion
                                            of the Senate, the Secretaries and Door keepers should
                                            be required to report the number and names of their
                                            assistants, as required in a former resolution adopted
                                            by the Senate.
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                             ORDER OF BUSINESS.
                             Mr. ANTHONY offered a resolution rearranging the order of business,
                                which lies over one day under the rules.
                        
                        
                            SWAMP LANDS.
                            Mr. MILLER offered a resolution, which was adopted, that the
                                    Swamp Land Committee inquire into the
                                expediency of transferring the Swamp Land business to the care and
                                control of the Auditor and Treasurer of State, now performed in the
                                several counties, for the purpose of the speedy settlement and
                                winding up of the same, and authorizing the purchase of swamp lands
                                at the offices of the Auditor and Treasurer of State.
                        
                        
                            EMPLOYEES OF THE SENATE.
                            Mr. RICE, from the Committee on Finance, to whom
                                was referred a resolution of the Senate, in relation to the
                                allowance of claims in the specific appropriotion bill, &c.,
                                reported the following resolution, and asked its adoption by the
                                Senate, viz:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the officers of the
                                            Senate report to the Finance
                                                Committee all purchases and items of
                                            account, made by them, at least once a week; also the
                                            numbers and names of all appointees and for what service
                                            appointed; and that all claims whatsoever, held by any
                                            person, be presented to said committee at least ten days
                                            before the adjournment of the Legislature, except such
                                            as may accrue within the list ten days of the session,
                                            and that no account presented by an employee shall be
                                            allowed, unless the person employing him certify the
                                            number of days the claimant served, the kind of service
                                            he did, and that he was necessarily employed.
                                    
                                
                            
                            The resolution was adopted by consent.
                        
                        
                             COMMON PLEAS JURORS.
                            Mr. McLEAN offered a resolution, which was adopted by consent,
                                directing the Committee on the Organization of
                                    Courts to inquire into the expediency of abolishing
                                the regular panel of jurors for the Court of Common Pleas, and that
                                they draft and report a bill to that effect if it be deemed
                                expedient.
                        
                        
                            DEAF AND DUMB ASYLUM.
                            Mr. LINE submitted the following, which was adopted by consent:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        WHEREAS,The Superintendent of the
                                            Institution of the Deaf and Dumb did give a public
                                            exhibition of the progress of the pupils placed in said
                                            institution, for the accommodation of the members of the
                                            General Assembly; and WHEREAS, Many
                                            of the members of the General Assembly did attend said
                                            exhibtion, in which they did witness with a degree of
                                            State pride, the progress in intellectual improvement
                                            which the pupils were making in said institution;
                                            therefore,
                                        Resolved, That we do, with full
                                            confidence, recommend to the tax-payers of Indiana, the
                                            capability of accomplishing the highest anticipations of
                                            the public, in the education of our unfortunate mutes,
                                            and that we do, with an abiding confidence, recommend to
                                            all parents in the State, who may have mute children,
                                            their duty to place said muteg in said institution, for
                                            the purpose of obtaining such intellectual training as
                                            shall qualify them for usefulness in after life.

                                ORDERS OF THE DAY.
                                 The PRESIDENT pro tempore announced the order
                                    of the day - being the consideration of Mr. Conley's bill (S.
                                    42) providing for the repeal of the charter of the Bank of
                                    Indiana. A motion was made to refer it to a select committee (of
                                    five); an amendment was proposed referring it to the
                                        Committee on Banks, aud a further
                                    amendment that it be referred to the Judiciary
                                        Committee- the question being upon the latter
                                    motion - 
                                On motion by Mr. TARKINGTON, it was laid on the table.
                                On motion by Mr. GOODING, the amendment was also laid on the
                                    table.  Mr. TARKINGTON made
                                    an ineffectual motion to lay the bill and pending motion on the
                                    tableyeas 13, nays 26.
                                And then the motion was agreed to and the bill accordingly
                                    referred to a select committee of five.

                                    Finance.

                                        Committee.
                                Mr. Cobb's bill (S. 47) to repeal an act providing for the
                                    protection of wild game, approved February 26, 1859, coming up -

                             AFTERNOON SESSION.
                             Griffin's bill (70) appropriating $8,000 to the Swamp Land Fund to

                                    on Swamp Lands.

                                Corporations.
                            Mr. Johnson's bill (73) to enable indigent persons to rent land, was
                                referred to a select committee of five, which the Speaker makes to
                                consist of Messrs. Johnston, Harney of Boone, Harney, Fordyce and
                                Robinson.
                            Mr. Jones' bill (74) to prohibit the circulation of a less
                                denomination than five dollars(a fine of ten dollars)was referred to
                                ihe Comittee on Banks.
                            Mr. Black's bill (75) to regulate interest on money, was referred to
                                the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY moved to reconsider the vote just taken, on the
                                reference of Mr. Jones' bill to prohibit small notes, to enable him
                                to move that it be referred to a committee of its friends.
                            Mr. Hamilton of Boone, would insist that the bill should go before
                                the Standing Committee.
                            Mr. PARRETT would exclude small bills of other States - reciprocate
                                the action of the States of Ohio and Kentucky in this respect.
                            Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, considered the bill ought not to have any
                                friends. The Illinois law for this purpose was disregarded.
                            Mr. TEBBS alleged that the small bills law was disregarded in the
                                State of Ohio.
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, had himself: passed Indiana small bills in
                                the State of Ohio: &c., but had no objection to the bill going
                                to a select committee.
                            Mr. JONES. This bill was not after the Ohio and Illinois laws. It was
                                a law which had worked well in Missouri, Louisiana, Mississippi and
                                Virginia.
                            Mr. CLEMENTS desired to reconsider.
                            The reference of the bill was recommended, and Mr. Hamilton, of
                                Boone, had leave to with draw his motion.
                            Mr. CLEMENTS made an ineffectual motion to refer to the Judiciary
                                Committee; and then the bill was referred to a select committee,
                                which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Jones, Dougherty,
                                Turpie, Blythe and Hunter.
                            Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's, bill (76) to amend the Divorce law, was
                                referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
                            Mr. Massey's bill (77) to revise the Supervisor's act, was referred
                                to the Committee on Roads, with instruction (by
                                Mr. Dougherty) "to amend the first resolution, so that supervisors
                                shall receive for compensation a credit for working the roads one
                                year." Also (by Mr. Hamilton, of Boone) so that "each voter shall
                                vote only for the supervisor in the Road District where he
                                resides."
                            Mr. Edward's bill (78) to regulate Insurance Companies not
                                incorporated by the State of Indiana, was referred to the
                                    Committee on the Judiciary.
                            Mr. Stanfield's bill (79) requiring the county from which a charge of
                                venue is taken to pay expenses of such trial, was considered and
                                ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. Dobbins' bill (80) to provide sites for houses of refuge and a
                                Board of Commissioners, was referred to the Committee on
                                    Benevolent Institutions.
                            Mr. Hunter's bill (81) to prevent the retail of spirituous and
                                intoxicating and malt liquors, was referred to the
                                    Committee on Temperance .
                            
                            Mr. Mellett's bill (82) to regulate practice in certain cases
                                appealed to the Supreme Court, was referred to the
                                    Committee on the Judiciary.
                            Mr Shields' bill (83) to amend the 7th section ol the act to

                            Mr. Cavin's bill (85) for the relief of Peter Shultz, was referred to

                            Mr, Smith of Miami's bill, (89) to amend the 3d section of the

                                    on Corporations.
                            Mr. Parks' bill (90) for the election of county prosecuting

                            Mr. Brotherton's bill (91) to provide for the transfer of certain
                                cases from the Common Pleas and Justice Courts, was referred to the

                                    Justice.
                            Mr. Hancock's bill, (92) to amend the section 18 of the act of May 6,
                                1852, for the more uniform mode of doing township business, was
                                referred to the Committee on County and Township
                                    Business.
                            Mr. Colgrove'sbill (93) to amend the sections 6 and 7 of the Divorce
                                act of May 13, 1852, was referred to the Committee on the
                                    Judiciary.
                            Mr. Firestone made an ineffectual attempt to adjourn.
                            The House, then, (at 4 o'clock) reconsidered, and adjourned. 
                        
                    
                    


                    

                        IN SENATE.
                        
                             FRIDAY, JANUARY 21, 1859. 
                        
                        The journal of yesterday was read.
                        The PRESIDENT pro tempore announced Senators Wagner,
                            Wallace, Steele, Murray, March, Carnahan and Line as the committee on
                            the joint resolution (H. R. 8) on the subject, of agriculture and a
                            geological survey of the State
                        The PRESIDENT pro tempore, also, makes Senators Conley,
                            March, Weir, Wagner and Heffren, the committee authorized to be
                            appointed yesterday afternoon, and to which was referred Mr. Conley's
                            bill (S. 42) providing for the repeal of the charter of the Bank of the
                            State of Indiana. 
                        
                            PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
                            Mr. HILL presented a memorial from the yearly meeting of the Society
                                of Friends residing in parts of Indiana, Ohio and Iowa, held at
                                Richmond, praying for the repeal of that portion of our laws which
                                denies to colored persons the right to testify as witnesses in any
                                cause in which a white person is a party in interest.
                            Mr. SLACK moved that it lie upon the table, but withdrew the motion
                                at the instance of several Senators.
                            Mr. MARCH was surprised at the motion of the Senator. He thought it
                                would be well to let negroes testify, and that there was no danger
                                in allowing juries to determine as to the credibility of their
                                testimony.
                            Mr. SLACK was willing to extend courtesy to any reasonable extent,
                                but he thought the people of Indiana were almost as a unit upon the
                                subject of that petition, and that it would be a waste of time to
                                consider the matter. He therefore renewed his motion to lay upon the
                                table.
                            This motion was rejected - yeas 10, nays 27.
                            On Mr. HILL'S motion the paper was referred to the Committee on
                                    Rights and Privileges.
                            Mr. HAMILTON presented a petition from H. P. Ayres, praying for the
                                erection of an Asylum for idiotic and imbecile persons, accompanying
                                a resolution directing the Committee on Benevolent
                                    Institutions to inquire into the expediency of
                                erecting such an Asylum.
                            The resolution was adopted by consent, and the petition referred to
                                the same committee.

                        
                        
                            REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                            Mr. CONNER, reported from the Judiciary Committee
                                his bill, (S. 17) providing for the partition of real estate, and
                                for laying the same out into lots and out-lots, and recommended its
                                passage.
                            The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed for
                                the third reading.
                            Mr. McLEAN, from the same committee, reported back Mr. Brown's bill,
                                (S. 29) to exempt personal property from sale on execution,
                                recommending its indefinite postponement.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. MARCH, from the same committee, reported back Mr. Conner's bill,
                                (S. 1) to amend the 6th, 7th, 12th, 19th and 20th sections of the
                                Divorce law, approved May 13, 1852, and providing for opening
                                decrees in the cases therein specified, with an amendment, and
                                recommended its passage.
                            Mr. HAMILTON moved to concur with an amendment that no divorced party
                                shall be permitted to marry for two years after the granting of a
                                divorce had by publication. He was opposed to fill divorces except
                                in cases of adultery.
                            Mr. BENNETT and Mr. CONNER opposed the amendment.
                            On Mr. HEFFREN'S motion, the amendment was laid on the table.
                            Mr. STUDABAKER said the law ought not to permit a recision of the
                                marriage contract to be opened up. He proposed to concur with an
                                amendment so that the question of alimony may be opened up but not
                                the question of recision of matrimony.
                            On Mr. HAMILTON'S motion, this amendment was laid on the table.
                            
                            Mr. MURRAY contended that we had no right to pass a law opening up
                                decrees that have been heretofore granted. He moved to strike out so
                                much of the original bill as refers to cases pending, and insert an
                                amendment to the effect that cases pending and commenced by bona
                                fide residents, shall not be affected by this act.
                            On motion by Mr. WEIR this motion was laid on the table.
                            The amendment proposed by the committee was adopted.
                            Mr. MURRAY moved to strike out from the 6th section the words
                                "heretofore or." He was standing up against his own individual
                                interest as a lawyer, when he advocated an amendment of the divorce
                                law
                            Mr. MARCH offered the amendment because frauds heretofore enacted
                                under the present Divorce law could not be remedied.
                            The amendment was adopted.
                            Mr. BLAIR and Mr.WALLACE made ineffectual efforts to amend, and then
                                - 
                            The bill was ordered to be engrossed, for a third reading.
                            Mr. WILLIAMS, from the Committee on Agriculture,
                                reported a bill (No. 94) amending section 6 of an act for the
                                encouragement of Agriculture, approved February 17, 1852, which was
                                passed to the second reading.
                            [This bill changes the time of annual meetings of the State Board,
                                and allows to district societies a delegate-]
                            Mr. HILL, from the same committee, to which was referred a resolution
                                in relation to young bulls, bucks and boars running at large,
                                reported that further legislation on the subject is unnecessary.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. BEESON, from the same committee, to whom was referred resolutions
                                concerning the holding of fair grounds by agricultual societies,
                                reported that the said committee deem further legislation upon this
                                subject as unnecessary.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            And the Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock.
                        
                        
                             AFTERNOON SESSION.
                            The LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR [Hon. A. A. Hammond] appeared in the Chair
                                for the first time during the present session. 

                            
                                 UNITED STATES SENATORS.
                                Mr. WALLACE, from a majority of the select committee of five, to
                                    which was referred his bill (S. 2) regulating the choosing of
                                    United States Senators by the General Assembly, specifying time,
                                    place and mode of such choosing, providing for the designation
                                    of such Senators by the people, reported the same back with a
                                    recommendation that it pass.
                                Mr. MURRAY and Mr. STUDABAKER opposed the provisions of the
                                    bill.
                                Mr. ANTHONY moved to postpone the further consideration of the
                                    bill till Wednesday next, 2 o'clock P. M.
                                Mr. WALLACE spoke in favor of the changes proposed in his
                                    bill.
                                Mr. HEFFREN made an ineffectual motion to indefinitely postpone -
                                    yeas 21, nays 26.
                                And then Mr. Anthony's motion was agreed to. 
                            
                            
                                THANKS.
                                Mr. WILSON offered a resolution of thanks to the Hon. J. R.
                                    Cravens for the able and impartial manner in which he presided
                                    over the Senate during the absence of the Hon. A. A.
                                    Hammond.
                                The resolution was adopted by consent. 
                            
                            
                                DOCUMENTS.
                                 Mr. HARGROVE offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing
                                    the Door-keeper to procure and distribute certain documents in
                                    the hands of the printer. 
                            
                            
                                BANKS.
                                Mr. HEFFREN offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing
                                    the Committee on Banks to inquire into the expediency of
                                    amending the present assessment law, so as to require banks to
                                    be assessed upon the amount of bonds deposited in the Auditor's
                                    office, and upon their circulation, also upon the entire amount
                                    of currency, gold and silver on hand, on the 1st day of January
                                    of each year. 
                            
                            
                                ADJOURNING OVER.
                                Mr. WIER offered a resolution, which was rejected, that when the
                                    Senate adjourn, it adjourn to meet on Monday, at 2 o'clock, P.
                                    M. 
                            
                            
                                ORDERS OF THE DAY.
                                 Mr. ANTHONY'S resolution of yesterday, with reference to the
                                    order of business, was now adopted. It is as follows: 
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Rosolved, That the 53d rule of the
                                                Senate be so changed as to read as follows: The
                                                daily order of transacting business, shall be as
                                                follows, viz: 1st. Reading and correcting the
                                                journal of the preceding day. 2d. Introduction of
                                                petitions, memorials, and remonstrances. 3d. Reports
                                                from Standing Committees. 4th. Reports from Select
                                                Committees. 5th. Bills. 6th. Orders of the day. 7th.
                                                Resolutions of the Senate. 8th. Joint
                                                resolutions.

                                        
                                    
                                
                                 On motion by Mr. MURRAY, 100 copies were ordered to be printed.
                                
                            
                            
                                TRUSTEES OF ASYLUMS.
                                 Mr. STEVENS offered a resolution, which was adopted, requesting
                                    the Committee on Benevolent Institutions to
                                    inquire into the expediency of limiting the meetings of Trustees
                                    of State Asylums to one every three months, unless by special
                                    call of Superintendent. 
                            
                            
                                PUBLIC PRINTING.
                                Mr. ANTHONY offered a preamble and resolution, stating that the
                                    present law by which the public printing is done is
                                    unnecessarily high, and directing the Committee on
                                        Printing to report a bill amending the laws
                                    reducing the prices.
                                The resolution was adopted.
                            
                            
                                TAXES ON NEGROES.
                                Mr. KINLEY offered a resolution, which was adopted, instructing
                                    the Committee on Education to inquire into
                                    the expediency of providing by law for the assessment of taxes
                                    for school pur poses on people of color, and applying the funds
                                    to the education of the colored persons of the State in separate
                                    schools. 
                            
                            
                                 JUSTICES OF THE PEACE.
                                Mr. McCLURE offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing
                                    the Committee on Education to inquire into
                                    the expediency of so amending an act approved March 1, 1855,
                                    entitled an  act to amend
                                    the 21st section of an act prescribing the duties of Justices of
                                    the Peace in State prosecutions, approved May 29, 1852, as not
                                    to require said Justice of the Peace on the first Monday in
                                    January and July, to make returns to the Treasurer of his county
                                    of fines and fees unclaimed when they have no such moneys, and
                                    when the amount on hand will not justify the expense of making
                                    such returns. 
                            
                            
                                KANSAS AND OREGON.
                                Mr. TURNER offered a joint resolution (No. 7) directing our
                                    Senators and Representatives in Congress to vote for the
                                    admission of Kansas and Oregon into the Union at as early a day
                                    as possible.
                                Mr. WALLACE was in favor of the resolution, but it did not go far
                                    enough. He moved to lay it on the table for the present.
                                The motion was agreed to. 
                            
                            
                                PRINTING OF THE JOURNALS.
                                Mr. HEFFREN offered a resolution, which was rejected, directing
                                    the Secretary of the Senate to deliver the journal of the extra
                                    session to the proper officer, according to law. 
                            
                            
                                TEMPERANCE
                                Mr. GOODING introduced a bill (S. 95) to regulate and restrain
                                    the sale of spiritous and intoxicating liquors, which was passed
                                    the first reading.
                                On motion by Mr. GOODING the rules were suspended and the bill
                                    read a second time - yeas 35, nays 7and referred to the
                                        Committee on Temperance. 
                            
                            
                                 FROM THE HOUSE. 
                                A message was received from the House of Representatives,
                                    announcing the adoption by that body of the following
                                    resolution:
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Resolved, That the Door-keeper be
                                                directed to contract with A. E. Drapier & Son
                                                for five hundred copies of ''Brevier Legislative
                                                Reports" of the Proceedings and Debates of the
                                                present General Assembly, after the style of their
                                                reports of the proceedings of the late extra session
                                                in the "Legislative Sentinel"said reports to be made
                                                up from the columns of some daily newspaper printed
                                                in the town of Indianapolis, and laid upon the desks
                                                of members as fast as they shall complete sixteen
                                                pages in double newspaper column; provided the cost
                                                of the same shall not exceed one dollar per copy,
                                                the Senate adopting a similar resolution.
                                        
                                    
                                

                            
                            
                                TEMPERANCE.
                                Mr. HEFFREN introduced a bill (S. 96) to regulate and restrain
                                    the retailing of spiritous liquors and for the suppression of
                                    evils arising therefrom, which was passed the second
                                    reading.
                                On motion by Mr. HEFFREN the rules were suspendedyeas 42, nays
                                    2the bill read the second time by title and referred to the
                                        Committee on Temperance.
                                Mr. TARKINGTON introduced a bill (No. 97) to prevent the
                                    retailing of spiritous and intoxicating liquors, &c., which
                                    was read through the first time.
                                On motion by Mr. GOODING [Mr. Tarkington in the chair,] the bill
                                    was read the second time by title - yeas 41, nays 1.
                                On motion by Mr. TURNER it was referred to the 
                                        Committee on Temperance.
                                Mr. ROBINSON introduced a bill (No. 98) to regulate and restrain
                                    the sale of spiritous and intoxicating liquors, which was read
                                    through.
                                The rules were suspended - yeas 37, nays 1 the bill read the
                                    second time by title and referred to the Temperance
                                        Committee.
                            
                            
                                WILD GAME.
                                 Mr. CONLEY introduced a bill (No. 99) to provide for the
                                    protection of wild game, which s passed to the second reading.
                                
                            
                            
                                TOWNSHIP BUSINESS.
                                 Mr. WALLACE introduced a bill (No. 100) providing for a more
                                    uniform mode of doing township business, which was read through
                                    and passed to the second reading. 
                            
                            
                                ASSESSMENT OF PROPERTY.
                                Mr. JOHNSTON introduced a bill (No. 101) to authorize County
                                    Treasurers to assess property which may be omitted by assessors,
                                    and to legalize assessments heretofore made by treasurers, which
                                    was passed the first reading.
                                Mr. WILSON introduced a bill (No. 102) to amend the 3d section of
                                    an act to establish Courts of Common Pleas, which was passed to
                                    the second reading.
                                And then the Senate adjourned.

                                resolution.
                            Mr. RITTER complained that his proposition to allow the
                                    Committee on Public Expenditure a Clerk,
                                which would only cost the State some $60, for the purpose of finding
                                out how some ten thousand dollars have been taken from the Treasury,
                                had been just voted down by gentlemen who were now proposing to
                                expend a thousand dollars for taking reports perfectly useless to
                                our constituents; and they were determined to persist in this, and
                                wear out the patience of the House until they should obtain it; an I
                                when we stand up and oppose their resolution, they tell us we spend

                            On motion by Mr. AUSTIN, it was resolved that the Auditor of State be
                                requested to send in his report for the year 1858. 
                        
                        
                            KANSAS.
                            Mr. SHIELDS submitted a resolution to the effect, "that that part of
                                the English bill known as the population clause, discriminating as
                                it does in favor of a Constitution conceived in fraud, born in
                                perjury, and baptized by a wholesale violation of principle, should
                                be repealed, and that we respectfully request all persons in
                                Congress from the State of Indiana to vote for its repeal."
                            Mr. DAVIS. If the gentleman will make it a joint resolution and
                                strike out the toploftical language, I will vote for it.
                            Mr. SHIELDS acquiesced.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY proposed to amend by striking out the repealing
                                portion, and inserting words to the effect that the Territory of
                                Kansas be admitted as a State, without regard to population,
                                whenever she applies with a Republican Constitution.
                            Mr. GIFFORD. We have heretofore passed a resolution to nearly the
                                same effect. 
                            Mr. MERRIFIELD moved to lay the resolution and amendment on the
                                table.
                            Mr. MURRAY. Which is the Democratic side of this question.
                                [Laughter.]The House refused to lay on the table, by yeas 34, nays
                                51and the question recurred on Mr. Dougherty's amendment
                                modified.
                            Mr . SHIELDS. I accept the amendment as additional matter.
                            Mr.DOUGHERTY explained his views at length, and his position on this
                                question before his constituents. His modification was by way of
                                substitute.
                            Mr. GIFFORD also defined his position to this question - insisting
                                that there was no urgency for action.
                            Mr. MELLETT moved to lay the amendment on the table. 
                            
                            The motion was agreed to - yeas 49, nays 40.The previous question was
                                demanded and ordered on the adoption of the original resolution, and
                                pending its force - 
                            Mr. RITTER desired to amend the phraseology.
                            Mr. DAVIS and others objected, insisting that the phraseology ought
                                to remain, because the House had refused to amend.
                            The vote resulted - yeas 49, nays 29, as follows: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Boxley,
                                            Branham, Brotherton, Cavins, Clark, Colgrove,
                                            Collier,Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Edwards, Fordyce,
                                            Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Hush, Hamilton
                                            of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Harrison, Hunter,
                                            Jeffries, Johnston, Jones, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller,
                                            Murray, Martin, Nebeker of Vermilllon, Nebeker of
                                            Warren, Parks, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Scott,
                                            Sherman, Shields, Smith of Miami, Stiles. Thompson of
                                            Elkhart, Treadway, Waterman, Whetzel, Whiteman, Wildman,
                                            and Mr. Speaker - 49.
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Bowman,Carr, Claypool,
                                            Clayton, Clements, Dobbins, Early, Eastham, Firestone,
                                            Gifford, Hancock, Hartley, Jordan, Kelly, Kempf, Lewis,
                                            McLain, Merrifieid, Nelson, Parrett, Prosser,Shockley,
                                            Shull, Snyder, Stanley, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs,
                                            Thompson of Madison, Usrey and Wood - 29.
                                    
                                
                            
                            Messrs. Black, Blythe, Boyd, Davis, Dougherty, Durham, Major, Massey,
                                Newton, Turpie, Wheeler and perhaps others, being present, and
                                refusing to vote.
                            So the resolution was rejected for want of a constitutional
                                majority.
                            Mr. COLGROVE. Is the resolution subject to be called up again?
                            The SPEAKER. Yes, by a majority.
                            Mr. DAVIS submitted a joint resolution to the following effect:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,&c. That our Senators in
                                            Congress be instructed, and our Representatives be
                                            requested to vote for the admission of Kansas into the
                                            Union as a State, without regard to the population, as
                                            soon as the people thereof shall desire to come in under
                                            a republican constitution, adopted by a majority of the
                                            voters of said Territory.
                                        Resolved further,That the Governor be
                                            requested to forward a copy of the foregoing joint
                                            resolution to each of our Senators and Representatives
                                            in Congress.

                                words: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        
                                             "Believing that she now has, or
                                                will have, before the people can form a constitution
                                                and apply for admission, a population sufficient to
                                                entitle her to admission under the English
                                                bill."
                                        
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. DAVIS moved to lay the amendment on the table.
                            Mr. MELLETT-the bill and the amendment.
                            Mr. DAVIS and Mr. JORDON demanded the yeas and nays, which
                                resultedyeas 47, nays 41, as follows: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Austin, Bowman, Boxley,
                                            Brotherton, Clayton, Clements, Colgrove, Comstock,
                                            Cotton, Davidson, Early, Eastham,Edwards, Fordyce,
                                            Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush. Hamilton of Boone,
                                            Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Jeffries, Kempf, McLain,
                                            Major, Mansfield, Miller, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion,
                                            Nebeker of Warren,-Parks, Prosser, Ritter, Robinson,
                                            Rynerson, Scott, Sherman, Smith of Miami, Snyder,
                                            Stiles, Sullivan, Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway, Turpie,
                                            Whetzel, Whiteman, and Wildman - 47.
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Blythe, Boyd, Branham,
                                            Carr, Cavins, Clark,Claypool, Collier. Davis, Dobbins,
                                            Dougherty, Durham, Firestone, Gifford, Gregory, Hartley,
                                            Johnston, Jones, Jordan, Kelley, Lawhead, Lewis,
                                            Massey,Mellett, Merrifield, Murray, Nelson, Newton,
                                            Parrett, Row, Shockley, Stanley, Summers, Tebbs,
                                            Thompson of Malison, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Wood and
                                            Mr. Speaker - 41.

                            Mr. DOUGHERTY submitted a joint resolution to the following
                                effect:
