                            The bill (S. 116) with reference to the time of holding courts in 21

                            The bill (S. 8) to amend the act concerning real property, of May 6,

                                Divorce Act of May 13,1852.
                            The bill (S 107) to authorize assessors and deputies to administer
                                oaths - 
                            Were severally considered and passed the second reading.
                            Mr. DOBBINS, by consent, from the Committee on the
                                    Organization of Courts, returned the bill (30) to
                                repeal the act establishing courts of conciliation, approved June
                                11, 1852, recommending its passage.
                            The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be
                                engrossed.
                            The Senate amendments to Mr. Martin's bill (12) to prevent the
                                issuing and circulation of unauthorized bank paper, were severally
                                read and considered, and on motion by
                            Mr. STANFELD, the subject was referred to a select committee; which
                                the SPEAKER makes to consist of Messrs. Stanfield, Martin and
                                Blythe.
                            On motion by Mr. MANSFIELD it was ordered that the Door-keeper be
                                requested to enquire why the resolution ot the House requiring the
                                printing of the State Teachers' Committee report has not been
                                complied with.
                            On motion by Mr. SHERMAN, by consent, his bill (118) to provide
                                penalty for banks failing to pay deposits or reedeem their bills on
                                presentation, was considered on the second reading and referred to a
                                select committee of five, which the Speaker makes to consist of
                                Messrs. Sherman, Davis, Mellett, Harney and Branham.
                            Mr. MURRAY, by consent, submitted a joint resolution, on the subject
                                of the Wabash and Erie Canal.
                            Mr. BLYTHE. This was a very important subject. He apprehended that
                                some of us at least, are not prepared to take definite action in
                                regard to it at this time. He was informed by the papers and
                                othewise, that there are now being held along the line of that
                                canal, sundry public meetings upon the subject, and he preferred to
                                await the expression of public sentiment. He was unwilling now to do
                                anything which might be construed as estopping the General Assembly
                                from future action in this matter. He desired to move to lay the
                                resolution upon the table, because he regarded it as premature.
                            Mr. MURRAY. The resolution, he believed, embodied the opinion of
                                nine-tenths of the people of the State. It was adopted by a meeting
                                of citizens residing on the line of the Canal. That opinion had been
                                heretofore expressed by  both
                                political parties in terms that could not be misunderstood; and he
                                desired now, in obedience to the wish of his people, to give that
                                expression herethat we are opposed to taking back the Canal and
                                standing responsible again for that Canal debt.
                            Mr. BLYTHE was just as determinedly hostile to taking back the Canal
                                and reassuming those bonds as the gentleman. He was in no wise
                                favorable to that course. But should we say now, we will not! The
                                act of taking back was not all. He had heard of an accommodation - a
                                mode of adjustment of the difficulty. If there was a necessity for
                                it, he might be willing to vote for the resolution at the proper
                                time; but not under a threat of the trustees, &c. It was
                                manifestly the part of prudence to delay this action to wait for
                                expressions of the views and opinions of the people at other points
                                along that Canal Lafayette, Terre Haute, Evansville - the latter
                                point being most interested, and having done most for that work.
                                There had been a public meeting on this matter in Evansville, and a
                                committee of consider ite men had been appointed to report upon it
                                at another meeting, to be held next Tuesday.
                            Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, concurred with Mr. Blythe. Masterly
                                inactivity was our policy now in this matter.
                            Mr. EDWARDS also coincided with Mr. Blythe. He had heretofore
                                introduced a resolution against the State taking back this Canal,
                                and he should not change this declaration. But there were questions
                                in connection with this interest which demanded deliberation, and he
                                should vote to lay the resolution on the table.
                            Mr. DAVIS. Though these bond-holders have no claims on the State, yet
                                he thought it best to delay, but would rather not vote to lay on the
                                table. He would prefer a reference to a select committee.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY. To lay on the table might place members in an
                                equivocal position. He moved to postpone till the second Friday in
                                February.
                            Mr. DAVIS would prefer to have the resolution in a little different
                                language. He was willing to require the select committee to report
                                it back on a certain day. He wanted to get rid of the preamble.
                            Mr. CLAYPOOL. His county was deeply interested in this matter. It was
                                the desire of his people that we should not take hasty action. He
                                moved to refer to a select committee of five.
                            Mr, MURRAY seconded this motion. He was willing - but there were
                                interests in the State outside of this Canal.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY'S motion was agreed to, and the resolution was
                                postponed.
                            Mr. TURPIE submited a resolution, which was adopted, to the effect,
                                that the Committee on Education inquire into the
                                expediency of providing by law, that the voters of each school
                                district shall have the employment of their teachers, and the
                                management of their school houses, instead of leaving these to be
                                controlled by the township trustees. 
                        

                        
                            TRUST FUND BORROWERS
                            Mr. JEFFRIES, by consent from the Committee on the Sinking
                                    Fund, returned Mr. Harrison's bill (59) to extend time
                                to the borrowers from the trust funds, recommending its passage.
                            The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be

                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, from the Committee on Swamp

                                oppropriation for the Calumet Ditch, with a verbal amendment, with a

                            The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be

                            The report was concurred in, the amendment adopted, and the bill

                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                            

                                 REVISION AND AMENDMENT OF THE STATE
                                    CONSTITUTION.
                                The SPEAKER announced the special order of the consideration of
                                    Mr. Davis' bill (No. 1) to provide for a Constitutional
                                    Convention, and the amendment of Mr, Hunter, to change the
                                    number of delegates to "one from each Congressional District and
                                    two for the State at large," which was proposed to be amended by
                                    Mr. Shull to this effect: "The said convention shall be composed
                                    of one hundred members, which shall be apportioned as by law
                                    provided for the representation in the House of
                                    Representatives."
                                Mr. DAVIS. It could not so much matter as to who should make the
                                    constitution, since it was to be submitted to the people for
                                    their ratification. Too large a number of delegates was the
                                    great difficulty in the Convention of 1850, and men still
                                    remember the cost of that convention.
                                Mr. SHULL replied. It was not the expense of a convention that
                                    should come in question here. But the people could be hardly
                                    fairly represented with less than the delegation he had
                                    proposed. Fifty members, or thirteen members would never satisfy
                                    a constituency of 200,000 voters.
                                Mr. DOUGHERTY moved the indefinite postponement of the bill. This
                                    was the first question to be decidedwhether we were to have a
                                    convention at all. No petition had come up for this object. The
                                    press had not demanded it but in a very few instances. It had
                                    not been demanded by either of the leading political parties.
                                    But if we were to have convention,he was in favor of the
                                    amendment of Mr. Shull Let us have a convention of men coming
                                    from the people. The gentleman from Monroe had told us that the
                                    present Constitution was adopted in convention and ratified by
                                    the people, without reflection. Well, if "in the multitude of
                                    counsellors there is safety," he would submit, if 150 members
                                    were five months in producing a State Constitution without
                                    reflection, how long would it require thirteen members to
                                    produce a Constitution with reflection? But then did the people
                                    want a new Constitution? No amendment had yet been made to our Constitution, rickety
                                    as it was alleged to be - and he admitted its defects. Even the
                                    fanaticism of Know Nothingism, when it came into these halls in
                                    1855, did not venture to lay hands upon it for amendment. He
                                    prefered the mode of amendment provided for in the Constitution
                                    itself. In this way propositions for amendment could be
                                    presented singly for the ratification of the people - an
                                    advantage of which we could not - agree with the allegation
                                    either that the constitution was rickety, or that it was adopted
                                    by the convention and ratified by the people without reflection.
                                    He rehearsed some distinguished names in that convention, and
                                    recommended the House to indulge in a little reflection on the
                                    pending question. He could not think the people of Indiana were
                                    disposed to tear up their Constitution every seven years.
                                Mr. Speaker GORDON felt that he was instructed by his people on
                                    this question. They regarded revision of the present
                                    Constitution, by means pointed out in the Constitution itself,
                                    as impracticable. He read the constitutional provision for
                                    amendment, to show how long it would require to get a single
                                    modification through requiring the concurrence of two General
                                    Assemblies before any question of amendment could be submitted
                                    to the people: Competition for priority generally defeated these
                                    propositions before the Legislature; for, if we agree at this
                                    session upon an amendment, and recommend it to the next General
                                    Assembly, that General Assembly can recommend no other amendment
                                    until they shall have rejected ours, or shall agree upon it,
                                    concur in recommending it to the people, and the people
                                    themselves shall have passed upon it. Did the convention desire
                                    to eternize their work? If there were no better reason, this
                                    were a good one for the call of another convention. He regarded
                                    the old Constitution as wiser than the present. There were fewer
                                    conflicting decisions under it than under the present, because
                                    the provisions of the present Constitution were themselves
                                    conflicting. It was a legal hotch-potch, involving the people in
                                    continual anxiety as to what their Constitutional rights are and
                                    how far the" can be maintained. This was true as to the
                                    questions of legislation on the subject of temperance, and
                                    especially in our legislation with reference to common schools -
                                    to build up that magnificent scheme of education which Game from
                                    the minds of the framers of the first Constitution, and which
                                    should be open and free to all, from the primary school to the
                                    university. The present Constitution was ratified because it
                                    contained provisions demanded by the people beforehand. In all
                                    fairness of argument, he considered that fifty men could agree
                                    on any important proposition very much sooner than 150 men -
                                    perhaps in one-third of the time. He was opposed to the number
                                    proposed by the gentleman from Monroe. He would have a number
                                    sufficient to represent the wishes of the people fairly. Fifty
                                    would be sufficient, though so restricted a number might cut off
                                    many of us small-fry politicians; and in this he was most
                                    willing to resign his claims to worthier hands.
                                Mr. JORDAN declared his opposition to this bill. He was not
                                    unwilling to allow to the people the exercise of their sovereign
                                    rights ; but he alleged his belief that the people did not
                                    demand another constitution. The people of Indiana knew their
                                    rights, and could assert them. Had they petitioned for this
                                    bill? Had the press declared for it? He had not heard of such a
                                    desire, except around the capital, where there might be a few
                                    interested hotel keepers. He examined the proposed points of
                                    constitutional amendment. The desire to exclude foreign born
                                    citizens from the polls had no place, but in the hearts of the
                                    lingering, unlamented remains of the Know Nothing party. The
                                    Maine Law faction were clamoring for constitutional amendment.
                                    We heard this announced in the late State Temperance Convention.
                                    The peculiar "friends of freedom" also desire itto give them a
                                    fresh opportunity to clamor for the rights of the black race.
                                    But there was a graver reason in the alleged conflicting
                                    provisions of legislation and court decisions under the present
                                    constitution. But this difficulty was more attributable to our
                                    legislation, perhaps, than to the constitution. It was necessary
                                    that the constitution should be understood by men taking upon
                                    themselves the functions of legislation. Even our
                                        Committee on Ways and Means, in the
                                    course of the extra session, to far forgot the constitutional
                                    provision, that no bill shall embrace more than one subject, as
                                    to report a bill with four distinct subjects. He regarded the
                                    constitutional mode of amendment the safest and best. He alleged
                                    that he could hardly regard this as any better than a mere
                                    interested partisan movement against the Democratic party. He
                                    showed the inequality of representation which would result from
                                    apportioning one delegate to each Senatorial district, and gave
                                    examples.
                                Mr. KEMPF. His bill was to make the law correspond with the good
                                    old Jeffersonian doctrine, as it exists in the naturalization
                                    laws of this country.
                                Mr. DAVIS disclaimed the intimation that this bill was the
                                    bantling of political partisanship, and alleged his conviction
                                    that it was demanded by the people at large. But if it were not,
                                    there could be no harm done. It would be quietly voted down.
                                If it was desired by the Temperance and Free-soil parties, they
                                    were right on the question of a a convention, if on nothing
                                    else. He reiterated his objections to the present rickety
                                    concern - running minutely into legislation so far as almost to
                                    destroy itself. The court decisions were fairly taken, he
                                    believed, on the school laws, but with this Constitution in the
                                    way, it would be impossible to build up that magnificent system
                                    of education contemplated in the first Constitution of Indiana
                                    He criticized and deprecated the constitutional provision
                                    requiring every bill here to be read through three times -
                                    together with that system of amendments of laws, swelling out
                                    our Acts of Assembly to four times the size of all the Gospels -
                                    and swelling our journals beyond all reasonable bounds. Then in
                                    regard to the act for the compensation of Common Pleas Judges,
                                    under that Constitution they all must receive $800and yet his
                                    Democratic friend here would insist that such a rickety concern
                                    can not be touched by the people, unless they come up here and
                                    humbly petition us for the privilege of doing  so. He accorded this bill as the
                                    people's right. Was the gentleman afraid of his people's
                                    decision? Look at the thousands this Constitution has cost our
                                    courts, and yet gentlemen say we ought to pause - consider,
                                    before we permit our masters to express their will upon this
                                    question. He was not strenuous about the number of delegates in
                                    the convention. That was a minor matter. If the people were
                                    satisfied with the Constitution why were our tables here every
                                    session so loaded with propositions to amend - ?propositions,
                                    however, which could rarely succeed on account of the
                                    legislative difficulties which the Constitution prescribes. It
                                    seemed to him a question which could not have two sides - could
                                    not have a partisan bearing.
                                Mr. GIFFORD should not treat this as a party question. He was
                                    willing the popular expression should be had; but he regarded
                                    the constitutional provisions for amendment as ample. He
                                    defended that mode of amendment, and was unwilling to give it up
                                    until it should be fairly tried. It had not yet been tested. He
                                    admitted the inefficiency of the school system, but neither had
                                    the Legislature been sufficiently diligent in this important
                                    matter.
                                Mr. AUSTIN. Did the gentleman from Harrison intend to allege that
                                    every friend of this bill were hostile to the foreign born,
                                    citizens of the State? Did he wish to use these citizens for
                                    political purposes? His use of these people were perhaps not
                                    unworthy of being placed by the side of that proposed by the
                                    gentleman from Franklin yesterday, when he desired their mortal
                                    remains in the potter's field, to remain subject to the
                                    dissecting knife of students in medicine, for anatomical
                                    purposes. [Laughter.]
                                Mr. DOBBINS opposed the bill and replied to some of the
                                    objections to the Constitution,submitted by Mr. Davis. He
                                    deprecated the disposition and the tendency to change our
                                    organic law. It might do for Mexico but not for the proud State
                                    of Indiana. But if the bill pass, there should be at least a
                                    hundred members in the proposed convention He regarded it,
                                    however, as premature. He could not think the people required
                                    it.
                                Mr. MELLETT. Opposition to change was a good argument for this
                                    bill. For we could not have permanency under this Constitution.
                                    How many laws in that book of Statutes but were subject to
                                    constitutional objections? He spoke of economy. This
                                    Constitution had given to the Common Pleas Judges $40,000 a year
                                    more than the representatives of the people intended to give
                                    them. He gave an instance of the gentleman from Martin, alleging
                                    that the Supreme Judges have a right to practice law in the
                                    inferior Courts, because that right is extended to every citizen
                                    of good moral character. He saw no force or applicability in it
                                    at the time; but he had just learned that grave Senators in the
                                    other end of the Capitol had so held by a majority this morning.
                                    But it was true that more than half of our decisions were
                                    connected with questions of constitutional construction, &c.
                                    The people wanted a plain, simple Constitution, under which
                                    there could be had simple, compact and intelligible legislation.
                                    He deprecated ail partisan connection with this question. A good
                                    law was equally good for an American, a Republican and a
                                    Democrat. He desired the people to decide this question for
                                    themselves at the ballot-box where they might be removed from
                                    the influence of political leaders. He believed it was demanded
                                    by the people.
                                Mr. BAIRD should oppose this bill all through. The thing was not
                                    so much as heard of in his county. He admired the adroitness of
                                    the gentleman from Floyd, seeking support for his bill on all
                                    sides - from temperance men and hard money men. The gentleman
                                    had objected to the provision requiring that laws shall be
                                    general and uniform. Would he go back to the confused system of
                                    local legislation which induced this constitutional provision.
                                    Now that we understand this constitution and legislating under
                                    it, it would be certainly unwise to throw it aside for a new
                                    one. He admitted its defects, but we were through with these
                                    tribulations, and he was opposed to putting the ship of State at
                                    sea again.
                                Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone. This question was not mooted before his
                                    people. He was opposed to change in this manner. He found the
                                    constitution full of objections and discrepancies. He knew that
                                    the argument that the constitution had cost the people $100,000
                                    was used in favor of its adoption. How should we now cure its
                                    defects? A constitution coming from a convention was to be taken
                                    as a whole- Would it not be better to suffer present ills till
                                    we can amend it in the mode the constitution points out? He
                                    answered many objections to the constitution, and defended the
                                    provisions restricting hasty legislation. Still he admitted the
                                    necessity of changes in the constitution. He knew the people
                                    desired them. Let us submit the desired amendments. Let the
                                    candidates for the next Legislature canvass them two years
                                    hence, and thus we can, in time, cure the defects complained
                                    of.
                                Mr. Speaker GORDON was one of those disposed to defend the right
                                    of revolution. Our fathers had provided for a peaceable process
                                    of revolution. A private individual could, under this principle,
                                    originate a proposition that might become law, even the organic
                                    law of the land. Such a revolution was demanded now, and might
                                    be brought about, he believed, by this bill. He represented no
                                    class, as the hotel-keepers, who he believed, were not always
                                    best paid by those who represented the people here. He
                                    complained of the defectiveness of the constitutional provision
                                    for the apportionment of representation, by which it could be
                                    shown that no Legislature has been legally convened here since
                                    that of 1855. He was in favor of a change to annual sessions of
                                    the Legislature. He was also in favor of a constitution that
                                    would enable us to pass wholesome election laws. He examined the
                                    present law, admitting whole shoals of emigrant voters for want
                                    of the constitutional power to fix some time to constitute a
                                    residence. He was for a provision prescribing a term of time for
                                    residence. He was also for a registration law. It was the
                                    deepest treason to violate the rights and the sanctity of the
                                    ballot box. He also would have a change of the provision in
                                    reference to  the amendment
                                    of laws. The Legislature of 1853 passed 155 acts, and 42
                                    chapters of the 155 of their acts were unconstitutional for one
                                    reason alone. Then in 1857, there had to be a reprint of 25 of
                                    their 66 chapters of acts, which so far doubles the cost of the
                                    public printing. This was an inevitable result of section 2 of
                                    the 4th article of the Constitution, requiring the amended
                                    clause in the bill to be set forth at length. He was for
                                    amendment of the Constitution on the subject of schools. He
                                    objected to the iron bedstead uniformity of that provision.
                                    Nothing could be done anywhere in the State in advance of the
                                    progress of the darker portions. He would have the tallest lead,
                                    and let those who were willing close the files of progress. He
                                    wanted a change also for temperance legislation. It had been
                                    said that the world was taught by three preachers - the Fogy -
                                    the Man of the Present - Man of the Good Time a coming; and it
                                    was true that the latter always left the Conservative to fall
                                    into the grave of the Fogy. Every age was in advance of that
                                    which has gone before. He would give full swing and the utmost
                                    liberty to every civil division in the State.
                                Mr. DOUGHERTY now insisted on his motion for indifinite
                                    postponement - and the yeas and nays being demanded, were
                                    ordered and taken thereon, resulting - yeas 305 nays 47as
                                    follows: 
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            YEAS - Messrs. Baird, Bowman,
                                                Clayton, Clements, Tobbins, Dougherty. Durhavn,
                                                Early, Edwards, Firestone, Gifford, Hamilton of
                                                Boone, Hancock, Harney, Johnston, Jordan, Kelley,
                                                Lewis, Major, Massey, Martin, Nelson, Prosser,
                                                Shockley, Shull, Smith, of Perry, Snyder, Sullivan,
                                                Thompson of Madison, Wood - 30. 
                                            NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Blythe,
                                                Boyd,Boxley, Branham, Brotherton, Carr, Cavins,
                                                Clark, Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Duvoll, Fordyce,
                                                Gregory, Griffin, Hall, of Grant, Hall, of Rush,
                                                Hamilton, of Wayne, Harrison, Hunterr, Jeffries,
                                                Jones, Kempf, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Murray,
                                                Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker, of Warren, Newton,
                                                Parks, Power, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson,
                                                Scott, Sherman, Smith, of Miami, Stanfield, Stiles,
                                                Thompson, of Elkhart, Turpie, Whetzel, Whiteman, Mr.
                                                Speaker - 47. 
                                        
                                    
                                
                                So the House refused to postpone; and then at 5:10 o'clock -
                                    adjourned. 
                            

                        
                    
                    
                    
                        IN SENATE.
                        
                            
                                SATURDAY, JANUARY 29, 1859.
                            
                        
                        On motion by Mr. WEIR the reading of the journal of yesterday was
                            dispensed with.
                        Mr. SLACK, by leave, offered the following resolution, which was adopted,
                                nomine contradicente:
                        
                        
                            
                                
                                    Resolved,That when the Senate adjourn, it
                                        will adjourn to met Monday at 2 o'clock P. M. 
                                
                            
                        
                        
                            APPRAISEMENT OF REAL ESTATE.
                            Mr. TARKINGTON, by leave, introduced a bill (No. 162) to amend
                                sections 6, 8, 9 and 14 of an act to provide for the appraisement of
                                real estate, approved December 21, 1858; also defining the duties of
                                appraisers, deputy appraisers, and the Auditor of State.
                            On motion by Mr. TARKINGTO the rules were suspended - yeas 34, nays
                                0, and the bill read by title only, the first and second time.
                            On motion by Mr. LINE the bill was referred to a select committee of
                                one from each Congressional District, which is made to consist of
                                Senators Tarkinsrton. Shoemaker. Anthony, Line, Kinley, Jennings,
                                McLean, Conner, Turner, Hendry and Murray.

                            WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
                            Mr. WALLACE, by leave, offered a joint resolution (No. 10) as
                                follows: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Be it resolved by the General Assembly of
                                                the State of Indiana, That the General Assembly
                                            of the State of Indiana has no power under the
                                            Constitution to purchase the Wabash and Erie Canal; and
                                            that if it had the power it would be impolitic, unwise
                                            and injurious to the best interests of the people of the
                                            State to purchase said Canal or assume any control over
                                            the same, directly or indirectly. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. CONNER urged its reference to the Committee on Canals
                                    and Internal Improvements, and made a motion to that
                                effect.
                            After brief remarks by Senators Line, Steele, Hamilton, March,
                                Wagner, Murray and Johnston - 
                            Mr. WALLACE moved to lay the motion of reference on the table.
                            The motion was rejected by yeas 19, nays 23.
                            The question then recurring upon the motion to refer to the
                                    Committee on Canals and Internal
                                Improvements, the yeas and nays were demanded, and being
                                ordered and taken, resulted - yeas 25, nays 15 - as follows : 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Beesou, Bobbs,
                                            Carnahan, Conner, Craven, Culver, Green, Hamilton,
                                            Hargrove, Heffren, Hill, Jones, Kinley, McLean, March,
                                            Murray, Odell, Rice, Slack, Steele, Studabaker,
                                            Tarkington, Thompson, Wagner and Weir - 25.
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Anthony, Bennett,
                                            Blair, Brown, Cooper, Gooding, Jennings, Johnston, Line,
                                            Lomax, O'Brien, Robinson, Wallace, Williams and Wilson -
                                            15.
                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. BOBBS, when his name was called, said his constituents are
                                adverse to acting on the subject of this Canal; he was opposed to
                                voting over and over again upon the same kind of a resolution, but
                                he would vote for the reference proposed.
                            Mr. CARNAHAN, when his name was called, said: He had voted on several
                                occasion for a resolution precisely similar to this, and he occupied
                                the same ground now; but in giving a vote to refer he did not
                                consider that would pledge him to any recommendation or bill which
                                the committee might report.
                            Mr. CRAVEN, when his name was called, said, he should vote for the
                                reference, but did not wish to be understood as being opposed to the
                                resolution, for he should vote for it when it came up.
                            Mr. HEFFREN, when his name was called, said: He, like the Senator
                                from Posey, [Mr. Carnahan,] had voted for similar resolutions time
                                and again. He did not propose to take it back, but as Senators seem
                                desirous to have it referred, he did not know that it would hurt the
                                passage of it, and was willing to vote for the reference. Any man
                                that would vote for the taking back of the canal ought to be burned
                                in effigy in every decent neighborhood in the State.
                            Mr. RICE, when his name was called, said he was as much opposed as
                                any Senator to the retrocession
                                of the Wabash and Erie Canal, and would not vote for any such
                                proposition; yet he was in favor of the reference of the resolution.
                                He was opposed to the passage of a resolution couched in the
                                language of the one offered by the Senator from Montgomery [Mr.
                                Wallace.] In the event of the abandonment of the canal by the
                                Trustees, he would be in favor of the Legislature authorizing
                                companies to take charge of that work for the purpose of keeping it
                                up.
                            Mr. ROBINSON, when his name was called, said: I had always been his
                                understanding that this canal had passed out of the hands of the
                                State and had gone to the company holding the bond?, and that it now
                                belonged to and was controlled by that company.
                            Mr. STEELE, when his name was called, said: He stood here committed
                                agaiust the taking back of this canal or the reissuing of one cent
                                of the bonds of the State on its account, because it has been
                                transferred. Like the Senator from Marion [Mr. Bobbs] he was opposed
                                to passing resolutions of this character over and over again every
                                day of the session. He did not wish to charge the Senator from
                                Montgomery [Mr. Wallace] with offering resolutions for buncombe, but
                                if there ever was one he thought this was of that description.
                            Mr. WALLACE, when his name was called, said: He was pledged against
                                the retrocession of the canal. The Senator from Fountain [Mr. Rice]
                                and himself canvassed that county, and both pledged the people that
                                they would oppose any measure that had in contemplation the taking
                                back in any shape or form of this canal. When he was pledged against
                                a thing, he went square through. Whether he came back to this place
                                again or not, never would he put himself in favor of taking back
                                that canal or assuming any control over it. He held that the
                                citizens of Montgomery county had as much interest in this subject
                                as the citizens of any county through which that canal runs. If
                                there should be an act passed assuming the control of it, it would
                                involve an outlay of money, and the people of Montgomery county
                                assisted in replenishing the public treasury as well as other
                                counties of the State. He w[?]shed to place himself upon the record
                                as against the taking back of the canal or assuming any control over
                                it whatever.
                            Mr. WEIR, when his name was called, said: If he had any idei that
                                voting for this reference committed him to the taking back of the
                                canal, either directly or indirectly, he should not so vote.
                            So the motion prevailed, and the resolution was referred to the
                                    Committee on Canals and Internal
                                Improvements.
                            And then the Senate adjourned.

                             INDIANA STATE BOARD OF COLONIZATION. 
                            Mr. FORDYCE, from the Committee on Public Expenditures, reported the
                                expression of opinion, that the subject of the accounts of the Board
                                of Colozination demand immediate legislation and a bill (170)
                                repealing existing laws on the subject of colonization, and
                                providing for another Board(appropriating $8,500 for colonization
                                purposes)which bills were severally passed the first reading.
                            The following report was submitted in connection with the latter
                                bill:
                            The Committee on Public Expenditures, having
                                examined the accounts of the Board of Colonization, believe their
                                condition demands immediate legislation, and for the purpose of
                                laying before the General Assembly that condition, submit the
                                following report:
                            By the act of 1852, the Governor, Auditor and Secretary of State
                                were, ex officio, constituted the State Board of
                                Colonization, and five thousand dollars were appropriated for
                                colonization purposes, three thousand of which were to be used for
                                the purchase of land in Africa, to be called the Indiana Colony, and
                                which was to be divided into one hundred acre lots, for each negro
                                who emigrated from this State to Africa. Such emigrants were also to
                                receive fifty dollars each, if needing aid, to pay expenses for the
                                voyage to that country.
                            By the act of 1853, five thousand dollars were appropriated for that
                                year, and a like sum for 1854, for the purpose of colonization.
                            These sums make an aggregate approprirtion of $15,000.The
                                expenditures have been as follows: 





                            
                                FOR 1853. 
                                
                                    
                                        Names and for what purposes.
                                    
                                    
                                        Amount.
                                    
                                
                                
                                     Jas. Mitchell remitted to Am. Col. Society..... 
                                     $1,000 00 
                                
                                
                                     Bird Webster allowed him as emigrant.......
                                     20 00 
                                
                                
                                    Jas. Mitchell, salary as Agent or Secretary...
                                     170 00 
                                
                                
                                     Jas. Mitchell, salary as Agent or Secretary.....
                                    150 00
                                
                                
                                     Jas. Mitchell paid to Treas. of Am. Col.
                                        Society...
                                    2,000 00
                                
                                
                                    Total for 1853.........................
                                    $3,340 00
                                
                            

                            
                                FOR 1854.
                                
                                    Jas. Mitchell, salary as Agent...........
                                    $150 00
                                
                                
                                     " To colonize negroes...........
                                    250 00
                                
                                
                                     " Salary as Agent..............
                                    143 12
                                
                                
                                     " Salary as Agent............
                                    150 00
                                
                                
                                    A.H. Brown, printing....................
                                    120 17
                                
                                
                                     Total for 1854.................................
                                    $767 25
                                
                            
                            
                                FOR 1855.
                                
                                    Jas. Mitchell, salary as Agent for 1 month.....
                                    $50 00
                                
                                
                                    T.A. Mills, salary as Agent..................
                                    250 00
                                
                                
                                     " " " .................
                                    100 00
                                
                                
                                     " " ".................
                                    200 00
                                
                                
                                     " " " and map of Africa.. 
                                     158 00
                                
                                
                                    Delzell & Tyler, binding reports............... 
                                     9 25
                                
                                
                                     Total for 1855..........................
                                    $767 25
                                
                            
                            
                                FOR 1856.
                                
                                    Jas. Mitchel, salary as Agent during Constitutional
                                        Convention
                                    170 00
                                
                                
                                    Jas. Mitchell, allowance by State Board.......
                                    68 00
                                
                                
                                    Total for 1856.........................
                                    $238 00 
                                
                            
                            
                                FOR 1857.
                                
                                    T.A. Mills, salardy as Agent................
                                    $ 66 00
                                
                                
                                    Jas. Mitchell, traveling expenses...............
                                     100 00
                                
                                
                                     " salary as Agent...............
                                    200 00
                                
                                
                                     " " " .................
                                    200 00
                                
                                
                                    Total for 1857...............................
                                    $566 00
                                
                            


                            
                                FOR 1858.
                                
                                    Jas. Mitchell, salary as Agent..............
                                    $ 66 00
                                
                                
                                     " " " ...............
                                    300 00
                                
                                
                                     " " " ...............
                                    150 00
                                
                                
                                     " " " ................
                                    150 00
                                
                                
                                    Total for 1858...........................
                                    $800 00
                                


                            
                            
                                
                                    Aggregate appropriations..............
                                    $15,000 00
                                
                                
                                    Aggregate expenditures...............
                                     6,499 54 
                                
                                
                                    Leaving unexpended.........................
                                    $8,500 46
                                
                                
                                    Of the expenditures, there are for emigration..
                                    $3,245 00 
                                
                                
                                    For the Secretary........................
                                     3, 025 00 
                                
                            

                            These accounts show that since early in the year 1854 no expenditure
                                has been made to colonize negroes, and that the salary of the Agent
                                is almost equal to the expenditure for colonization purposes proper.
                                This is extraordinary, and demands an examination into the causes
                                which have led to this inaction on the part of the Board of
                                Colonization, and the payment of the Agent for so long a period when
                                nothing was doing.
                            The law of 1852 contemplated the purchase of land for a separate
                                colony, to be called the Indiana Colony. Governor Wright addressed
                                letters to Governor Roberts of Liberia in 1853, asking to be allowed
                                to purchase land at Grand Cape Mount. This was objected to, because
                                Liberia contemplated settling the same place, and "was opposed to
                                transferring it to any State for the exclusive use and benefit of
                                its emigrants; that the granting of one hundred acres to each
                                emigrant would engender jealousies on the part of emigrants from
                                other States; that ten acres was sufficient for an ordinary sized
                                family; and that compact settlements were necessary to protect
                                colonies from the treachery of the natives." In answer to these
                                objection. Governor Wright stated to Governor Roberts, that "the
                                Board desired a location for a settlement in order to benefit its
                                emigrants, and that public sentiment in our State required practical
                                results and the clear evidences of the utility of the appropriations
                                made, which could best be done by founding a settlement and
                                fostering it."
                            Subsequently Liberia commenced a settlement at Grand Cape Mount, and
                                desired the cooperation of our State making it a place of common
                                settlement. It would appear that the Board was divided on this
                                question; another Agent, Mr. Mills, was chosen, who favored the
                                joint settlement.
                            Whilst the correspondence between Governor Wright and Governor
                                Roberts was going on, the Board of Colonization employed Mr. McKay,
                                a colored man, and of good repute, to act as their Agent in this
                                State to pursuade the colored people to emigrate. He went to Liberia
                                also, in order to procure all needful information. Through these
                                efforts thirty-three colored persons in 1853 were induced to emi
                                grate, and to aid them, the above three thousand dollars were placed
                                with the American Colonization Society, which superintended their
                                transportation. Mr. McKay, after his return from Africa, continued
                                as the Agent of the Board, and in 1854, fourteen other emigrants
                                left the State. But one report has ever been made by the Board to
                                the General Assembly, and from those made by Mr. Mitchel, their
                                Agent, it would seem that the Board desired to act in co-operation
                                with the American Colonization Society, and abandon all idea of a
                                separate settlement for the emigrants from our State. The result of
                                this change of policy is thus alluded to by Mr. Mitchell, in his
                                report of February 1857:
                             " During the period that the plan of a settlement at Grand Cape
                                Mount was kept before our people of color, seventy-four moral and
                                worthy emigrants went from this State to Liberia, hut the moment Mr.
                                Mills abandoned that plan, emigration stopped, and McKay, our
                                colored agent, much against my will, resigned his commission and
                                refused to act for the Board; nor could he be much blamed, seeing
                                his feelings were so much enlisted in the original plan."
                            Since this difficulty occurred in 1854, nothing has been done by the
                                Board that your committee can ascertain, and the Agent or Secretary,
                                Mr. Mitchell, has made occasional reports, and some correspondence,
                                of no definite character, has been had with the Governor of Liberia
                                and others.
                            Why this inaction on the part of the Board of Colonization, your
                                committes can not determine, unless it is to be found in the
                                organization of the Board itself. The State officers, ex officio, constitute it, and they are elected to their
                                respective offices, without the least regard to their opinions on
                                the subject of Colonization. They may be earnestly enlisted in it,
                                or they may be coldly indifferent to it, or hostile to it. They are
                                subject to be changed every two years, and, hence, there is no
                                responsibility. No enterprise can be successful that is not placed
                                in the hands of its friends; and hence, your committee believe that
                                the aw is so defective that no reasonable expectation of success be
                                hoped for under it.
                            Governor Wright well understood the public sentiment of our State,
                                when he declared that it required practical results, and clear evidences
                                of the utility of the appropriations made. The practical results
                                which the foregoing expenditures exhibit are very unsatisfactory. If
                                the Board determined to remain inactive, it was their duty to
                                relieve the treasury from the salary of the Agent, who was useful
                                when active operations were carried on. The people will not submit
                                that their money shall go to useless officers instead of to the
                                purposes for which their appropriations have been made.
                            Your committee believe that public sentiment is in favor of granting
                                public aid to colored persons of the State needing it, who may
                                desire to emigrate to Liberia, in accordance with the requirements
                                of the Constitution They,therefore, report the following bill to
                                economically give such aid, and to repeal the existing laws on
                                Colonization, under which so much useless expenditure has been made, 
                            J. RITTER.
                            THOS. GIFFORD. 
                             Mr. PARKS moved an order for printing 200 copies of the Report.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY could see no necessity for printing.
                            The motion was lost.

                                118) to compel the payment of deposits and bank issues, and Messrs.
                                Stiles and Brotherton were appointed in their places.
