                        IN SENATE.
                        
                             MONDAY, JANUARY 31, 1859. 
                        
                         The PRESIDENT pro tem, announced the special orderit
                            being Mr. Wallace's bill (S. 2) regulating the choosing of United States
                            Senators by the General Assembly, specifying the time and manner, place,
                            &c., and providing for their designation by the people.
                        Mr. HEFFREN moved to strike out from the enacting clause and insert an
                            entire substitute. He was in favor of some law that would make it
                            obligatory upon the Legislature to elect the officers that it is made
                            their duty to elect, but he believed the plan proposed in the bill under
                            consideration to be impracticable. He thought any law contrary to the
                            one requiring the Legislature to choose United States Senators would be
                            null and void; and believed the Legislature had the only power, under
                            the Constitution ot the United States to choose Senators in the Federal
                            Legislature. He looked upon the proposition to permit the people to
                            designate who should be so elected, as in effect taking away from the
                            Legislature of Indiana the power vested in them; and denying to them the
                            exercise of a right clearly belonging to them and to them alone. But why
                            should gentlemen come in here and ask to strike down the principle that
                            has stood for more than three-quarters of a century? Were this bill to
                            pass and become a law, and were he to become a candidate, (as he would
                            not) to represent the people of Washington and Harrison counties in the
                            Senate again, and every county in the State except those two (which
                            there is no possibility of their doing) should designate Republicans for
                            that office, he would suffer his right arm to be torn from its socket,
                            and his tongue to cleave to the roof of his mouth before he would
                            support them.
                        Mr. WALLACE said that the newspapers of the State in noticing the
                            provisions of this bill had grossly misrepresented it. The papers have
                            said that the bill made it obligatory upon the Legislature to elect the
                            men whom the people may designate at the ballott-box. Such was not the
                            case; but he thought that honorable gentlemen would listen to the voice
                            of the people of the whole State - they would feel themselves
                            responsible to the expressed will of the people, and bound to respect
                            the general voice of the State when they came to the election of the
                            United -States Senators. He then proceeded to answer the declerations of
                            the Senator from Washington, [Mr. Heffren,] that the bill was
                            unconstitutional and impracticable; urging in opposition to these, many
                            arguments in favor of the adoption of the bill under consideration.
                        [A message from the House announced the passage by that body of Mr.
                            Heffren's bill (S 116) fixing the time of holding courts in the 2d
                            circuit: also, the bill (H. R. 11) to amend section 21 of an act to
                            provide for the reorganization of County B oards, and to allow
                            commissioners to levy a tax of not less than one-tenth of one per
                            cent.]
                        Mr. BENNETT. Like the two Senators whc have spoken, he believed there was
                            no question to come before this Legislature that the people of the State
                            were so anxious to have settled. Each party have now played out the game of staving off Senatorial
                            elections, and it is to be hoped we will now go to work and pass a law
                            so that hereafter there will be no trouble in a matter of this kind. No
                            State in the Union has been so disgraced in that matter of electing
                            United States Senators, as the State of Indiana. He was in favor of the
                            bill under consideration if it could be carried out practically. He
                            believed that the people should have the right of even electing the
                            President of the United States by a direct vote. Like the Senator who
                            first spoke, he would not vote for any Democrat for the office of United
                            States Senator even if the people of the State should so designate. He
                            would not vote to carry out the will of the people of the State? but
                            would be governed only by the people who sent him here. He believed in
                            the doctrine of popular sovereignty, but also believed that it could be
                            run so far as to lead to anarchy.
                        Mr. ANTHONY. There are some things in this bill, which look well, but he
                            stood opposed to it. He deprecated the disposition to throw all power
                            into the hands of the people. Every election thrown into their hands
                            hereafter, will distract their attention from matters which are of much
                            more vital importance to them, and render them the more unfit to elect
                            their immediate representatives and officers.
                        Mr. WEIR moved to lay the amendment on the table.
                        The motion was rejected - yeas 13, nays 33.
                        Mr. HEFFREN insisted that the Constitution of the United States expressly
                            says that the United States Senators shall be elected by the
                            Legislatures of the several States - thus vindicating the sovereignty of
                            the individual States. He could not consent to a law that would trample
                            under foot the will of the members of the General Assembly. The
                            substitute proposed by him needed perfection, and ii it should be
                            adopted, he hoped it would be referred to a committee for that
                            purpose.
                        Mr. GOODING regarded the bill of the Senator from Montgomery, (Mr.
                            Wallace,) as doomed. He preferred the original bill, but thought the
                            substitute the next best. We are but the servants of the people, not
                            their masters, and why need we fear to let the people say who are their
                            choice for the highest office in their gift. The people send us here to
                            cast their votes and carry out their wishes, and he knew no surer way to
                            ascertain their sentiments than through the ballot-box. The people of
                            Indiana would do as well as their servants in the election of United
                            States Senators; and they are always to be trusted in the selection of
                            their servants. He who is afraid to trust the people is a weak
                            Democrat.
                        Mr. CONNER moved that the bill and pending amendment, be referred to the
                                Committee on the Judiciary.
                        Mr. MARCH moved an amendment to the amendment, by striking out from the
                            enacting clause and inserting a new bill. He was in favor of the
                            principle indicated in the original bill Nothing that served to
                            strengthen the tower of the people would undermine the foundation of
                            this Government. Legislators represent the majesty and sovereignty of
                            the State; he knew no better way to understand the people than to hear
                            from them through the ballot-box; and if an act of this kind were
                            passed, he had no idea members in this Hall or in the other end of the
                            Capitol would disregard the wish of the people of the State so
                            expressed. He was opposed to joint conventions of the two Houses of the
                            General Assembly for electing these officers, and he hoped that a
                            proposition would be adopted for the election by Concurrent vote. The
                            amendment to the amendment proposed by him, was the bill passed by the
                            Legislature at the extra session, with the exception of the emergency
                            clause, and the section which directs the certifying of election, and
                            punishment for neglect of the same. He withdrew his substitute.
                        Mr. HEFFREN withdrew his substitute, and moved indefinite postponement of
                            the bill
                        Mr. WALLACE was sorry to see a disposition to crush his bill? He had
                            hoped that in after years he would have the privilege of designating at
                            the ballot-box his choice for United States Senators; but when he
                            proposes this he is kindly told that it is demagogical. This is the last
                            session he ever expected to sit in this body-but wherever the records of
                            the session of '57, Of the extra session or of this session show his
                            vote on an act passed, or on a resolution or any vote of his, among them
                            all there was not one which he would look back to with more satisfaction
                            than that which he would give on this proposition, and not one whose
                            failure he would more deeply and sincerely regret.
                        Mr. STEELE could see no necessity for this law. He would vote for a joint
                            resolution embracing a proposition, contained in the bill, but he could
                            not vote for the bill. He charged that this bill was introduced for
                            buncombe.
                        Mr. WALLACE replied to this charge at some length - repudiating and
                            disclaiming any such motive.
                        Mr. WEIR was in favor of the proposition of the Senator from Montgomery
                            [Mr, Wallace] because he believed it to be right and constitutional. All
                            power was in and rested with the people, a no act was done by any
                            Senator without his first thinking how the people of the State would re
                            gard it. In every measure in which the people are interested, Senators
                            should do what they can to promote it. He did not admit it as a new
                            doctrine. If the people were to designate their choice for United States
                            Senators, he should vote to carry out that designation.
                        The motion to indefinitely postpone was rejected by yeas 20, nays 24.
                        Mr. HEFFREN offered his substitute, again, as an amendment to the
                            bill
                        Mr. WALLACE moved to postpone the matter till Monday next at 2
                            o'clock.
                        The motion was agreed to.
                        Mr. CONNER, by leave, offered a resolution, which was adopted, calling
                            for certain information concerning the financial affairs of the Insane
                            Asylum.
                        On motion by Mr. MARCH, the bill (H. R-67) respecting the execution of
                            wills, what may be devised, &c., was taken from the table, and read
                            through.
                        
                         On motion by Mr. SLACK, the rules were uspendedyeas 46, nays 0the bill
                            read the cecond time by title, and referred to the Judiciary
                                Committee.
                        On Mr. HEFFREN'S motion, his Cuba joint resolution was made the special
                            order for 2 o'clock next Thursday week.
                        On motion by Mr. WAGNER, his bill (85) toprovide for a general system of
                            common schools, &c., was taken up, and without reading, referred to
                            the Committee on Education,
                        [A message from the House announced the passage by that body of joint
                            resolutions, directing our Senators and requesting our Representatives
                            to use their influence (H. R. 1) to secure the passage of a law giving
                            bounty land to soldiers of 1842, and (H. R. 18) to abolish the franking
                            privilege.]
                        The bill (H. R. 11) to amend the act for the organization of county
                            boards, approved June 17, 1852, was read.
                        On motion by Mr. MARCH, the rules were suspended - yeas 42, nays 2 - the
                            bill read a second time by title, and referred to the Committee
                                on County and Township Business.
                        And then the Senate adjourned. 


                    
                    
                    

                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
                        
                             MONDAY, JANUARY 31, 1859. 
                        
                        
                            COURT TIMES IN THE SECOND CIRCUIT.
                            Mr. DAVIS, (by consent,) from the select committee on that subject
                                returned the bill (S. 116) fixing the times of holding the Circuit
                                Courts in the Second Judicial Circuit, and recommended its passage;
                                and the same was considered and passed the third and last reading,
                                by yeas 67, nays 4. 
                        
                        
                            COUNTY TAX LEVY.
                            Mr. CAVINS asked for a suspension of the order of business to enable
                                him to move to take up his bill (H. R. 11) to amend the 21st section
                                of the act for the organization of County Boards, of June 17, 1852,
                                so that the Commissioners shall not be compelled to make a levy of
                                more than 10 cents on the hundred dollars, instead of 25 cents, for
                                the liquidation of county bonds, and to have the same considered now
                                on its third reading. He stated the emergency for the passage of
                                this bill in his own county.
                            The motion was agreed to, and the bill was taken up and passed the
                                final reading in the House of Representatives, by yeas 71, nays 2,
                                with an amendment of title by Mr. STANFIELD, viz: adding these
                                words: "so as to allow the Commissioners to make a levy of not less
                                than 1-10th of one per cent."
                            On motion by Mr. DAVIS, it was ordered that his bill (1) be made the
                                special order for Thursday, two o'clock.
                            Mr. STANFIELD, from, the Committee on the
                                    Judiciary, returned Mr. Shull's bill (41) to amend the
                                9th section of the act providing for the election of Circuit Court
                                Clerks, of May 7, 1852, with the expression of opinion that further
                                legislation on the subject is unnecessary, and a recommendation that
                                the bill be indefinitely postponed.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. BROTHERTON, from the Committee on Courts of
                                    Justice, returned Mr. Griffin's bill (25) to amend the
                                10th section of the Justices' act of May 19, '52, recommending that
                                it be laid on the table, as in the opinion of the committee further
                                legislation on that subject is inexpedient.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. STANFIELD, from the same committee, returned Mr. Parks' bill (90)
                                providing for the election of County Prosecuting Attorneys; &c.,
                                alleging that, as the Constitution requires prosecutions in the
                                Circuit Court shall be prosecuted by the Circuit Prosecutor, it
                                would be inexpedient to have a prosecutor for each county, and
                                therefore they recommend that the bill be indefinitely
                                postponed.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. BROTHERTON, from the same committee, to whom the subject had been
                                referred, reported a bill (No. 171) declaring it to be a misdemeanor
                                for any Clerk of the Circuit Court to refuse to issue writs arid
                                summonses when properly demanded, &c.,which was passed the first
                                reading.

                                certified copy of this resolution to each of our Senators and

                            The report was concurred in, the amendment adopted, and the joint

                            The report was concurred in.

                             So the House refused to concur.
                            Mr. PARKS moved to recommit the report, with instructions to report a
                                bill.On motion by Mr. BOYD, the subject was referred to a select
                                committee, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Boyd,
                                Turpie, Scott, Sullivan and Mellett.
                            Mr. DURHAM, from the same Committee, returned the resolution for
                                amendment of the law so as to require moneys to be expended for the
                                improvement of roads in the district where collected, and reported
                                their opinion that such legislation is inexpedient.
                            Mr. KEEFER demanded the yeas and nays on the question of
                                concurrence.
                            Mr. MURRAY. The money delinquent never comes back; but it goes to the
                                county by a general distribution, which is unequal, and matter of
                                complaint among the people.
                            Mr. PROSSER. The fault is in the officers not in the law. The law
                                plainly requires the Supervisor to expend this money within the
                                district.
                            Mr. MURRAY. The delinquent money is turned over to the County
                                Treasurer, and distributed as I have stated.
                            Mr. PROSSER read from the Acts of 1855, page 93.
                            Mr. PARKS. That did not respect the delinquent money, &c. He
                                moved that this matter be referred to the Select
                                    Committee, under Mr. Boyd's motion.
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush, and Mr. KEEFER, desired the law amended so as to
                                make the money certainly applicable where it has been collected. Mr.
                                Parks' motion was agreed to.
                            Mr. MURRAY proposed instructions: that the Select
                                    Committee report a provision, "amending the law so as
                                to compel the proper county officers to return all delinquent road
                                tax money of the several road districts in the county, to th.e
                                district to which it belongs."
                            The instructions were agreed to.
                            Mr. DURHAM, from the same Committee, returned the resolution as to
                                amendment of the laws, so as to require the two days labor to be

                            Mr. EARLY, from the Committee on County and Township

                                issue and put into circulation any such paper.

                                ordered that the Clerk acquaint the Senate therewith.

                            COMMON SCHOOLS.
                            By Mr. BOWMAN, which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            WHEREAS, The Constitution of the
                                            State of Indiana has made it the imperative duty of the
                                            General Assembly to provide, by law, for a general and
                                            uniform system of common school, wherein tuition shall
                                            be without charge, and equally open to all; and
                                        WHEREAS, The inefficiency of the
                                            present system is a subject of general complaint
                                            throughout the State, arising in part from the depleting
                                            process to which the funds have been subjected as they
                                            passed through the State treasury for the purpose of
                                            equalization and general distribution, and
                                        WHEREAS, By such means the people have
                                            been deceived in the paying of interest and taxes for
                                            the support of schools, and their children have been
                                            deprived of the benefit of the proceeds thereof, to the
                                            amount of upwards of $186,000, as shown by the late
                                            report of the Auditor of State. Therefore,
                                        Resolved, That the Committee
                                                on Education be requested to inquire into
                                            the expediency of so amending the present school law, as
                                            to require the entire annual income of the common school
                                            funds to be distributed and paid out each year, for the
                                            support of common schools, and for "no other purpose
                                            whatever," together with such portion of the
                                            undistributed surplus now in the State Treasury, as may
                                            be compatible with the interests of the State and the
                                            Constitutional rights of her children 
                                    

                                
                            
                        
                        
                            WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
                            By Mr. MILLER, which was rejected: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        WHEREAS,The Trustees of the Wabash and
                                            Erie Canal have signified in their report to the
                                            Legislature, that it is the intention of the bond
                                            holders to abandon the working of said canal, and
                                         WHEREAS, By the action of said
                                            Trustees in dischargingnearly all the employees along
                                            the line of said canal,they in a manner confirm, that
                                            supposed intention,therefore, be it
                                        Resolved, That the said Trustees be and
                                            the same are hereby requested to inform this House, at
                                            their earnest convenience, what may be their exact
                                            intentions with reference to said canal.

                            FILING CONSTABLES' BONDS.
                            By Mr. MURRAY, which was rejected:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the Committee on
                                                the Judiciary be instructed to report a
                                            bill amendatory of the law in regard to the filing of

                                            Township Trustees. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            By Mr. MASSEY, which was rejected:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the committee on
                                                fees and salaries be instructed to inquire
                                            into the expediency of amending the present law so as to
                                            allow Jurors, who may live more than seven miles from
                                            the county seat, the sum of one dollar and fifty cents
                                            per day, and mileage. 
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                            ORDER OF BUSINESS.
                            By Mr. ROBINSON, which, being a proposition to amend the rules, lies
                                over one day: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That from and after the
                                            adoption of this resolution, the orders of the day shall
                                            take precedence of resolutions and the introduction of
                                            bills.
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                            POSTAGE.
                            Mr. KEEPER submitted a joint resolution (No. 18) instructing our
                                Senators, and requesting our Representatives in Congress, to vote
                                against any increase of letter postage, and also to vote for a bill
                                to abolish the franking privilege; which was considered and adopted,
                                by yeas 58. nays 17; and it was ordered that the Clerk acquaint the
                                Senate therewith. 
                        
                        
                            ADMISSION OF KANSAS.
                            Mr. CAVINS submitted the following joint resolution (No. 19:)
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, &c., That our Senators in
                                            Congress be instructed, and our Representatives
                                            requested, to vote for the admission of Kansas into the
                                            Union as a State, whenever she shall apply to Congress
                                            therefor, with a constitution Republican in form,
                                            consistent in its provisions with the Constitution of
                                            the United States, and adopted by the vote of a majority
                                            of her people, fairly expressed, without regard to what
                                            shall be the opinion of her people on the subject of
                                            slavery, and without regard to her population. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. KEEFER. We have already passed a resolution like that.
                            Mr. MURRAY. Just like it, only a little better.
                            The SPEAKER. The Chair does not understand that such a resolution has
                                been passed.
                            Mr. JORDON moved to lay it on the table, which was lost - yeas 24,
                                nays 40.
                            Mr. MURRAY proposed to amend by striking out all that part of the
                                resolution which relates to slavery.
                            Mr. CAVINS. That was the very question he desired to have a vote on
                                by the Republicans of this House, and it was for their benefit he
                                had offered the resolution. It was Republican doctrine, as he
                                understood it. It was assumed by Judge Morton in the last
                                Gubernatorial contest. Judge Morton took the position that the
                                people have a right to shape their own institutions. The later
                                platform of Indiana Republicans had one of its points to the same
                                effect. His object was to wipe out that record which some of the
                                Republicans of this body made the other day on the resolution of the
                                gentleman from Morgan [Mr. Dougherty.]
                            The SPEAKER. There was no record made on that resolution.
                            
                            Mr. CAVINS. There was a record made on that resolution in the
                                Sentinel, if no where else and it was a correct record. Now, I want
                                to know if the Republicans of this House are going to stand up to to
                                at resolution, and to the platform we adopted last March; or whether
                                they prefer to act with those who would establish new tests, and
                                drive out of the party those who have hitherto stood firm and
                                foremost in the contest. He hoped they would not now refuse to
                                recognize the very doctrine which was announced all over the State
                                by every candidate we elected to Congress last fall, &c.
                            Mr. JEFFRIES was on the record as a Republican - against Kansas
                                coming into the Union as a slave State.
                            Mr. MURRAY. In 1820 that Territory was dedicated to freedom by Henry
                                Clay and his compeers; and in 1854, the Missouri Compromise, which
                                so dedicated if, was stricken down by Stephen A. Douglas. For this
                                reason he was firmly opposed to Kansas coming into the Union as a
                                slave State. He did not cringe to any principle permissive of
                                Kansas' admission as a slave State.
                            Mr.BAIRD If that joint resolution was not Republican in doctrine,
                                then he was not a Republican. But it was Republican. He was in favor
                                of popular sovereignty. The Democrats went a little farther, and
                                professed squatter sovereignty, &c. The mistake of the
                                Democratic party was in the declaration that Congress have no power
                                to legislate on the subject of slavery, yet they may delegate that
                                power to the Territorial Legislature. Judge Taney had decided
                                against that, &c.
                            Mr. RITTER desired to amend, it in order, by adding these words: "And
                                it is hereby expressed as the opinion of this House, that the people
                                of a Territory have the right to exclude slavery during the time
                                they are in territorial condition." He was as much opposed to
                                slavery as any man. No Republican nor any man of any party pretended
                                to hold, that when the people of a Territory came to make a State
                                Constitution, they could" not decide the question of slavery; but he
                                desired to be clear,very clear in. this expression, and to admit
                                this power to the people before that. He never had advocated any
                                other doctrine. He wished now to go upon the record us he had stood
                                before the people. But still he was opposed to Kansas coming in with
                                slavery at any time for the reason alleged by the gentleman from
                                Elkhart, &c.
                            Mr. JORDAN submitted the following substitute: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the harmonious
                                            Republican party be permitted to hold a caucus to-night
                                            at early candlelighting for the purpose of reorganizing
                                            their forces. 
                                    
                                
                            
                             The SPEAKER. It is not in order.
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush, supported the resolution; defining his position
                                thereon, which had suffered no change from the beginning - in favor
                                of popular sovereignty. He never could fear that Kansas would be a
                                slave State.
                            Mr. POWER defined his position to the question, speaking at length of
                                its aspects in his county, and what the Democracy claimed in 1849.
                                If Kansas came with a Constitution republican in form, he was in
                                favor of her admission, with or without slavery.
                            Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, criticised the course of the Democratic party
                                and the Administration and their position to the question ot popular
                                sovereignty. That principle would not do for the Democracy. It was
                                an eternal principle of right. He never heard it contradicted until
                                it was repudiated by the Buchanan Democracy.
                            The SPEAKER announced the question to be on the amendment of Mr.
                                Murray, and the yeas and nays were demanded and ordered.
                            Mr. AUSTIN. He should never vote for this or any other resolution for
                                the admission of Kansas as a slave State. He had been consistently
                                and remained firmly opposed to the extension of slavery, and he gave
                                reasons. He was for the amendment.
                            Mr. BRANHAM demanded the previous question, and under its force the
                                amendment was rejected, by yeas 12, nays 54; and the resolution was
                                adopted by yeas 51, nays 10 - as follows: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Baird, Blythe, Boyd,
                                            Branham, Cavins, Claypool, Claypool, Collier, Cotton,
                                            Davis, Dobbins, Dougherty, Durham. Duvol, Edwards,
                                            Firestone, Fordyce, Gifford, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of
                                            Rush, Harney, Harrison, Hartley, Hunter, Jones, Keefer,
                                            Kelly, Lewis, Mansfield, Massey, Martin, Nebeker of
                                            Warren, Nelson, Newton, Power, Prosser, Ritter, Row,
                                            Scott, Sherman, Shockley, Shull, Smith of Miami, Smith
                                            of Perry, Stanfield, Stiles, Thompson of Madison,
                                            Whetzel, Wood and Mr. Speaker.- 51.
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Boxley,
                                            Brotherton, Clark, Hamilton of Wayne, Jeffries, Mellett,
                                            Murray, Parks and Thompson of Elkhart - 10. 
                                        Present and not voting - Messrs,
                                            Jordon, Kempf, Robinson, Treadway and Turpie. 
                                        Paired off - Messrs, Davidson, Johnston
                                            and Wheeler.
                                    
                                
                            
                             So It was ordered, that the Clerk acquaint the Senate with the
                                passage of the joint resolution.
                            On motion by Mr. STANFlELD, Mr. Davis had leave of absence till
                                Thursday.
                            Mr. HUNTER made an ineffectual motion for a night session;and then - 
                            The House (at 5:12 o'clock) adjourned. 
                        
                    
                    
                    

                        IN SENATE.
                        
                             TUESDAY, February 1, 1859. 
                        

                        Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee returned the
                            bill (H. R. 67) supplemental to an act prescribing who may make a will,
                            the effect thereof, what may be devised, &c., approved May 31, 1851,
                            recommending its passage.

                        The report was concurred in, the bill considered as engrossed, read the
                            third time, and finally passed the Senate by yeas 40, nays 0.

                        Mr. STEELE, by leave, presented a petition from sundry citizens of Parke
                            and Fountain counties, praying for the levying of a tax to assist the
                            bondholders in keeping up the Wabash and Erie Canal, which was referred
                            to the Committee on Canals and Internal
                            Improvements.

                        Mr. TARKINGTON, from the Committee on Education,
                            returned his bill (62) for the relief the Indiana University, providing
                            for the sale its lands [19,040 acres] &c., recommending passage.
                        Mr. WEIR thought there should be passed providing for the gradual sale of
                            these lands, which would be a great deal better for the  interests of the University, than the
                            present proposition to sell at once.
                        Mr. GOODING hoped the bill would not pass. He desired that a sufficient
                            amount of the land should be sold to meet the immediate liabilities of
                            the University; but was not willing that the door should be opened for
                            the sale of the entire amount of lands belonging to the University.
                        Mr. McLEAN hoped the bill would pass. The bill provides that the lands
                            shall be appraised, and sold for the full appraised value. He had
                            sufficient confidence in the Board of Trustees to say they will not sell
                            all the lands unless they can sell them for a fair price, and only so
                            much of the same as will meet the demands of the University.
                        Mr. CARNAHAN. If the Trustees had made a report showing the financial
                            condition of the University, he might vote for the bill, but as the case
                            stood he was opposed to putting this power into their hands without
                            knowing the actual condition of the affairs of the University.
                        Mr.TARKINGTON. This bill simply provides for the sale of such portions of
                            the lands as will meet the demands of the University; to be sold for a
                            part cash in hand and the balance on a credit of ten years at seven per
                            cent interest. He proceeded at some length to explain and set forth the
                            condition of the University at the Present time, urging as a matter of
                            necessity for the well-being of the institution the immediate Passage of
                            the bill.
                        Mr. WEIR thought the Trustees should have made a report to the
                            Legislature at this time in order that members may vote understanding
                            for the relief of the University, even if the law did - not require them
                            so to do. The Legislature - was entitled to a report, and should not go
                            it blind by voting for this relief without some information upon the
                            subject- what the necessities are, the cost of the building, amount of
                            lands owned by the University, how situated, &c., &c.
                        Mr. WAGNER thought the bill ought to pass for various reasons. He would
                            be in favor of selling the land and paying off the debts with the
                            principal, but that can't be done, the debts must be paid by the
                            interest accruing from the amount received by the sale of these lands.
                            The Board claim they ave the right to sell without the authority of the
                            Legislature, and that being the probability, he thought it right,
                            proper, and prudent, that we should pass this bill at this time. The
                            lands are being sold and until the debt is paid off.
                        Mr. WALLACE confessed it to be all darkness to him, but thought this bill
                            substantially the same as the one offered in the session of '57. Before
                            he voted for a bill of this kind he would like to have a report showing
                            the debts of the Institutions, it's financial condition, &c. The
                            bill proposes to strip the University of some 19,000 acres of land, and
                            that was a poor way to increase the endowment of the University. He
                            regarded the Institution as nothing more than a county seminary, and
                            expressed himself in favor of keeping these lands for the purpose of
                            building a University that would be an honor to the State, and would
                            compare somewhat with the Institutions for the Blind, Deaf, and
                            Dumb.
                        Mr. TARKINGTON replied with some feeling to the insinuations cast against
                            this State University at Bloomington - declaring that it had flourished
                            without money, built a beautiful college building at a cost of $15,000,
                            and increased its number of students from 45 to 175 students, within a
                            few years. Unless some provision of the kind proposed in this bill be
                            made at this session by the Legislature, these lands will all be
                            frittered away before the next session o! the General Assembly.
                        Mr. WILLIAMS thought the Senator from Brown [Mr. Tarkington] had given a
                            true history of the affairs of the University. If for no other reason he
                            would vote for the bill, in order to get these lands settled and
                            cultivated.
                        Mr. WALLACE had a conversation this morning with one of the Trustees, who
                            said he lad neither read the bill nor knew of any of the provisions in
                            it.
                        Mr. MARCH trusted the Senate would concur in the report, and before the
                            bill comes up on its passage Senators could inform themselves about the
                            bill.
                        Mr. BOBBS. If there were any other means to defray these debts than by
                            the sale of these lands, he would vote against the bill, but as he knew
                            of no other way, he should vote for it.
                        Mr. CARNAHAN did not wish to urge a facious opposition to this bill. At
                            first, he was under the impression that a large portion of these lands
                            were under cultivation, and thus a source of revenue to the University,
                            and that a number of students were pay students; but as this appears to
                            be a mistake, he felt disposed to favor the bill, at least he should
                            vote for a concurrence in the report.
                        The report was then concurred in, and the bill ordered to be
                            engrossed.
                        Mr. RICE, from the Committee on Education, to which
                            was referred a communication from Prof. Mills, on the subject of the
                            school law of Indiana, returned the same and recommended the printing of
                            500 copies.
                        The report was concurred in.
                        Mr. McLEAN, from the same committee, returned a joint resolution upon the
                            subject of distributing such schools funds as may arise from icts of the
                            Legislature, recommending favorable action thereon.
                        The report was laid on the table.
                        Mr. HEFFREN, from the same committee returned Mr. Lomax's bill (S. 39) to
                            amend the law regulating the election of Clerks of Circuit Courts,
                            approved June 7,1852, recommending its passage.
                        The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                        Mr. STUDABAKER, from the Committee on Corporations,
                            returned Mr. Bobbs' bill (S. 71) to incorporate the Indiana School of
                            Practical Science, recommending that it be laid on the table, because of
                            its being in conflict with sec. 13, art. 9, of the State
                            Constitution.
                        The report was concurred in.
                        Mr. WILLIAMS, from the Committee on Roads, returned a
                            resolution giving the County Commissioners power to levy a tax for the
                            making of turnpike, gravel and other highways upon  petition from citizens therefor,
                            recommending indefinite postponement of the subject.
                        The report was concurred in.
                        Mr. WEIR, from the Committee on the State Prison, returned his bill (122)
                            supplemental to a Prison act of March 3, '55, with an amendment
                            providing that the act should be read to the convicts occasionally, and
                            recommending its passage.
                        The report was concurred in, and the amendment adopted.
                        [A message from the House announced the passage of a joint resolution (H.
                            R. 19) instructing our Senators, and requesting our Representatives in
                            Congress to vote for the admission of Kansas into the Union without
                            regard to population, slavery, &c ; also the concurrence of that
                            body in the Senate amendments to the shin plaster bill (H. R. 12) and
                            the addition of a section ]
                        Mr. GOODING proposed to amend so as to provide that when a prisoner has
                            been sentenced for life, he shall be discharged at the end of twenty-one
                            years' service, provided his conduct shall be good during the time of
                            said service.
                        Mr. HEFFREN and Mr. BENNETT opposed the amendment.
                        Mr. GOODING sustained his amendment, and quoted authorities in
                            justification of the proposition.
                        [A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of Mr.
                            Heffren's bill (S. 116) fixing the time of holding Courts in the 2d
                            Judicial Circuit; also, Mr. Green's bill, (S. 3) attaching the counties
                            of Hamilton, Hancock, Madison, Tipton and Howard to the 7th Judicial
                            Circuit.]
                        Mr. STEVENS expressed himself as in favor of the adoption of the
                            amendment proposed.
                        Mr. MARCH concurred in the belief "that the criminal law should be
                            inflicted for the purpose of reformation and to keep community from
                            crime. He proposed an amendment to the amendment, adding the words: "and
                            shall give satisfactory evidence of change of conduct."
                        Mr. SLACK was opposed to the amendment.
                        Mr. WALLACE referred to the advantages of the criminal on trial, and
                            spoke in opposition to the amendments proposed.
                        Mr. HARGROVE moved to lay the amendment on the table.
                        Mr. CARNAHAN moved to amend by laying the bill and pending amendments on
                            the table.A division of the question being called for, the amendment and
                            the amendment to the amendment were severally laid on the table.
                        The question recurring upon laying the bill on the table, it was not so
                            laid.
                        The bill was then ordered to be engrossed for a third reading.
                        Mr. STEELE, from the Committee on Banks, returned Mr.
                            Tarkington's shinplaster bill, (S. 7) recommending that it lay on the
                            table.
                        The report was concurred in.
                        Mr. GOODING, from the Committee on Temperance,
                            returned Mr. Tarkington's temperance bill, (S. 97) recommending that it
                            lie upon the table, and reporting a substitute therefor.
                        The report was concurred in, and the substitute being bill (No. 163,) an
                            act regulating the sale, giving or bartering away of spirituous and
                            intoxicating liquors, &c., lies upon the table until it comes up in
                            the orders of the day.
                        Mr. WILLIAMS, from the Committee on County and Township Business,
                            returned a resolution of inquiry requiring constables to file their
                            official bonds, and reported legislation upon the subject as
                            inexpedient.
                        The report was concurred in.
                        Mr. TARKINGTON, from a select committee, returned his bill (S. 142) to
                            amend sections 5, 8, 9 and 14 of the appraisement act, approved December
                            26, 1858, defining the duties of appraisers and their deputies and the
                            Auditor of State, recommending its passage.
                        The report was concurred in, the bill considered as engrossed, read a
                            third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 37, nays 6. 
                        Mr. FISK, from a select committee, returned his temperance bill (10) with
                            sundry amendments recommending its passage.
                        The report was concurred in, and a motion that the bill and pending
                            amendments be laid on the table, was lost by yeas 19, nays 21.
                        Mr. SLACK moved an amendment, striking all that requires the payment of
                            money for license.
                        Mr. WAGNER was opposed to all license in any shape or form whatever. He
                            thought it a moral and social evil - wrong in all its bearings. He would
                            vote for this amendment, and whenever the question comes up directly,
                            would always vote for no license. He hoped to have an opportunity to
                            vote for a bill which will prohibit the existence of these hell-holes,
                            and yet not contemplating the licensing and authorizing these things to
                            exist. He could not consent to license the increase of the amount of
                            crime by selling the right to commit crime; for in that the State became
                            a partner in the commission of that crime.
                        Mr. WEIR was opposed to any license system, but was willing to compromise
                            on a small license law. When he concluded - 
                        The Senate took recess till 2 o'clock. 
                        
                             AFTERNOON SESSION. 
                            The special order for this hour [2 o'clock] being Mr. Wallace's joint
                                resolution (S. 5) instructing our Senators and requesting our
                                Representitives in Congress to vote for the admission Kansas into
                                the Union whenever the people demand it. [ It is printed in page 81
                                of these Reports.]
                            Mr. HAMILTON moved to postpone the resolution till the 7th of
                                January, 1860.
                            On motion by Mr. COBB, this motion was laid on the table.
                            Mr. GOODING desired a vote at once, and without any polly-foxing.
                            Mr. WALLACE proceeded to urge the adoption of his resolution in a
                                speech of an hour, during which he took occasion to animadvert upon
                                the published remarks of the Hon. James Huges, delivered at a public
                                meeting in the Hall of House of Representatives on the 24th of
                                November last.
                             [A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of
                                the bill (H. R. 67) supplementary 
                        
                        
                    
                    
                
                
                
                    BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
                    BY ARIEL & W. H. DRAPIER.
                    
                        Vol. II.
                        INDIANAPOLIS, FEB. 4, 1859.
                        No. 8.
                    
                    
                        
                            plementary to an act prescribing who may make a will? what may be
                                devised, &c. ]
                            Mr. HEFFREN offered a substitute for the resolution [the joint
                                resolution on this subject introduced by him during the extra
                                session and laid on the table.]
                            Mr. GOODING moved to by the substitute on the table.
                            The motion was rejected - yeas 17, nays 18.
                            On a motion to lay the original resolution on the table, the yeas and
                                nays were demanded, and being ordered and taken, resulted - yeas 25,
                                nays 15 - as follows: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEASMessrs. Beeson, Bennett, Blair,
                                            Bobbs, Brown, Carnahan, Conner, Craven, Cuver, Fisk,
                                            Green, Hargrove, Heffren, Hendry, Hill, Kinley, Line,
                                            Lomax, McClure, March, Slack, Steele, Stevens,
                                            Tarkington and Thompson - 23. 
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Cobb, Gooding,
                                            Hamilton, Jennings, Johnston, Jones, Miller, Murray,

                                            and Wilson - 13.
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. BLAIR, when his name was called, said there were some things in
                                the resolution which he approved, but for,the purpose of getting at
                                the legitimate business before us, he would vote "aye."
                            Mr. CARNAHAN explained. The condition of the State of Indiana was
                                more important to him than that of Kansas, and that we may get clear
                                of this question, he would vote "aye."
                            Mr. HEFFREN (in explanation) was opposed to the resolution simply
                                from the fact that it repudiates the provision in the English bill
                                which requires that, Kansas shall have 93,430 inhabitants before it
                                can be admitted into the Union. He would not vote for the taking in
                                of any State until it shall have a sufficient population to entitle
                                it to a Representative in Congress.
                            Mr. MILLER, explained he had not examined the resolution, and should
                                vote "no," because he was not sufficiency informed to vote
                                otherwise.
                            Mr. SLACK, (in explanation) said: With many of the sentiments in the
                                resolution, in the abstract, he concurred; but believing, as he did,
                                that they were introduced here for buncombe, that speeches on it
                                were intended for buncombe, that the whole thing was for buncombe,
                                and that we have business that might be more profitably attended to
                                than this, he should vote for laying the resolution on the
                                table.
                            Mr. STEELE explained. The Senator who last spoke made his speech
                                precisely and tittered his sentimtents - he therefore voted as that
                                Senator did. He voted "aye."
                            Mr. WEIR, (in explanation.) The resolution did not go hardly as far
                                as he would like to have it; but as far as it did go he believed it
                                expressed the doctrines of the Republican party, and for that reason
                                he should vote against laying them on the table.
                            So the resolution was laid on the table.
                            The amendment was also laid on the table.

                        
                        
                             LICENSE LAW. 
                            The PRESIDENT pro tempore now announced the
                                consideration of Mr. Slack's amendment to the amendment of the
                                select committee to Mr Fisk's temperance bill (S. 10) pending at the
                                time of the recess, viz: to strikeout all of the bill that requires
                                the payment of money to procure license.
                            Mr. MURRAY was in favor of a thorough temperance law, and should so
                                vote as long as he lived. He had always voted for sound temperance
                                laws, whenever he had the opportunity; and wanted no better
                                monumental inscription over his grave than that in 1855 he voted for
                                the prohibitory liquor law.
                            Mr. LINE for the purpose of having a test vote as to whether the
                                Senate is in favor of a license law or not, moved to lay the
                                amendment to the amendment on the table.
                            On this motion the yeas and nays were demanded, and being ordered and
                                taken, resulted yeas 26, nays 18as follows: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Carnahan, Cobb, Craven,
                                            Culver, Fisk, Gooding, Green, Hamilton, Hargrove,
                                            Jennings, Jones, Kinley, Line, McLcan, Miller, Murray,
                                            OdeII, Rice, Robinson, Studebaker, Tarkington, Turner,
                                            Wallace, Weir, Williams and Wilson- 26.
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Beeson, Bennett, Blair,
                                            Brown, Conner, Heffren, Hendry, Hill, Johnston, Lomax,
                                            McClure, March, Shoemaker, Slack, Steele, Stevens,
                                            Thompson and Wagner - 18. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. BEESON, when his name was called, said: He was opposed to the
                                principle of license by the Legislature, but if he could get nothing
                                better he might vote for a license law.
                            Mr. BENNETT (in explanation) was opposed to a license law, but if we
                                have one he believed a man should pay well for it.
                            Mr. COBB (in explanation) was opposed to the license system, and
                                would much prefer a law without that provision, but as he was under
                                the impression that we can not pass a law unless it has a provision
                                in it authorizing the issuing of licenses, he should vote to lay the
                                amendment to the amendment on the table.
                            Mr. CRAVEN (in explanation) was against license or no license, but if
                                the question was between free license and pay license he would favor
                                pay license.
                            Mr. CULVER (in explanation) was in favor of a stringent liquor law,
                                and if we can not get a
                                prohibitory liquor law, he was willing to take the next best thing
                                and vote for the pay license system.
                            Mr. GOODING (in explanation) had no scruples in voting for any good
                                law license or no license, pay or no pay. He was in favor of the
                                best thing he could get, and was not going to "strain at gnats and
                                swallow camels," upon this question, neither. He should keep on
                                voting for temperance bills until we pass one. If we adopt a license
                                system he would prefer putting the tax high, say from $100 to
                                $1,000. But unless the members of this Legislature were willing to
                                concede a little, he predicted we would adjourn and go home and
                                intemperance would run riot yet two years longer. He wanted to
                                cripple, if he could not kill this thing. The vote which he would
                                now give would be no test of what he would vote for hereafter.
                            Mr. HEFFREN (in explanation) would vote for no bill that contains a
                                provision to make a man pay for a license. He thought that, instead
                                of selling out licenses we had better go to work and pass laws
                                preventing the sale of these poisonous compounds and drugs. If we
                                had good, cure liquors, and those only, there would not be half so
                                many snakes in men's boots.
                            Mr. McLEAN, in explanation, would vote for no law that had
                                incorporated in it a pay license provision - (he cared not how high
                                that license may be, even were it high enough to amount to a partial
                                prohibition(unless he voted for it as a dernier resort. He was
                                satisfied the people demanded a license law.
                            Mr. MARCH, in explanation, was opposed to the whole system of
                                licenses, especially pay licenses. If the sale of intoxicating
                                liquors is entitled to the same protection of any other pursuit, we
                                have no right to impose a tax upon one business which we don't upon
                                another. A license law protects the liquor seller against the force
                                of pubic opinion.
                            Mr. MILLER, in explanation, would vote for any good temperance bill,
                                with or without license
                            Mr. SLACK, in explanation, believed if liquor selling be a legitimate
                                business, that we had no right to impose restrictions upon it which
                                we do not impose upon any other business. If it is not a legitimate
                                business, and only evil results flow from it, we should abolish it
                                altogether.
                            Mr. STUDABAKER, in explanation, said the vote he should give would be
                                no index of the votes he should give hereafter. He desired to see a
                                temperance law passed, and should vote for any law he believed to be
                                constitutional that his vote would secure.
                            Mr. TURNER, in explanation, said he should not make this a test
                                question. He was opposed to the whole license system, and could not,
                                under any considerations, vote to license the traffic in ardent
                                spirits. He looked upon it as an unjust, disreputable and unhallowed
                                traffic, and could not vote to make the State a partner in that
                                nefarious traffic. If we are to have a license law, he was disposed
                                to have a pay license system, not that he believed the public
                                Treasury would be benefitted thereby, for he believed it would be a
                                curse to participate in the traffic, but because it would operate as
                                a check upon individuals engaging in it.
                            Mr. WEIR, in explanation, was opposed to any pay for license, but if
                                we are compelled to have a license law, he thought it should be as
                                low as possible. He did not consider this as a test vote, and should
                                vote hereafter whichever way he thought best.
                            So the amendment to the amendment lies on the table.
                            The question recurring upon the amendments proposed by the committee,
                                viz: to make the license not less than $25 nor more than $250 - 
                            On motion by Mr. COBB, "$25" was stricken out of the amendment and
                                "$50" inserted in lieu thereof.
                            Mr. KINLEY moved to amend by striking out all that part of the bill
                                relating to license.
                            On motion by Mr. WEIR, this proposition to amend was laid on the
                                table by yeas 23, nays 20.
                            Mr. GREEN moved to amend by striking out "$250" and inserting
                                $1,000.
                            This motion was laid on the table by yeas 23, nays 22.
                            Mr. MURRAY proposed to amend the 7th section as follows:
                            " Every person who shall be found intoxicated and making a
                                disturbance, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and on
                                conviction thereof, shall be fined in any sum not less than two
                                dollars nor more than ten dollars."
                            The amendment was adopted.
                            Mr. BEESON moved to strike out from tin enacting clause and insert a
                                new bill.
                            On motion by Mr. WALLACE, the substitute was laid on the table by
                                yeas 25, nays 18.
                            Mr. WILLIAMS proposed an amendment, compelling the person to
                                designate the place where the liquor is to be sold. Pending whichThe
                                Senate adjourned.
