                             RESOLUTIONS. 
                            By Mr. RICE: which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the Committee
                                                on Banks inquire into the expediency of
                                            passing a law requiring the holders of the paper of the
                                            free banks of the State, which have gone into
                                            liquidation, and whose assets are now, or may come, into
                                            the hands of the Auditor of State to present their notes
                                            to said Auditor for redemption within a limited and
                                            specified time, and after the lapse of that time the
                                            said Auditor be authorized to pay over to the persons
                                            entitled thereto, any surplus remaining in his hands,
                                            after redeeming the notes aforesaid, and within the time
                                            limited by law, &c., and that they report by bill or
                                            otherwise.
                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. STEELE offered the following, which was adopted: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the Joint
                                                Standing Committee on Public Buildings, be
                                            instructed to inquire into the expediency of making an
                                            appropriation for the construction of an artesian well,
                                            for the better protection of the Insane Hospital from
                                            destruction by fire; and also, for lighting the same
                                            with gas; and report by bill or otherwise.

                                        Resolved, That the Judiciary
                                                Committee be instructed to inquire whether
                                            there is any law authorizing the heirs of decedant
                                            estates after the administration is closed, to Institute
                                            suit for the recovery of claims in favor of the estate
                                            filed as desperate, and in absence of such law whether
                                            it is expedient or not to confer said power upon heirs
                                            at law, with leave to report by bill or otherwise.

                                taken from the files.
                            On Mr. HEFFREN'S motion the Senate refused to concur in the House
                                amendment.
                            And then the Senate adjourned.

                                            EDITOR SENTINEL - Dear Sir:
                                        
                                        You have me recorded in the Sentinel, in Friday's

                                            voted against the motion to lay Mr. Jordan's motion to
                                            reconsider the vote by which the canal petition was

                                            ask this correction.

                        IN SENATE.
                        
                             MONDAY, February 7, 1859. 
                        
                        Mr. HENDRY, from the Committee on Elections, returned
                            Senator Hargrove's bill (44) to change the time for the election of
                            members of Congress, recommending passage.
                        Mr. LOMAX submitted a report by a minority of the same committee,
                            dissenting from the recommendation of the majority, and holding that the
                            provisions of the bill are unconstitutional.
                        The majority report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be
                            engrossed. 
                        
                            UNITED STATES SENATORS.
                             The PRESIDENT pro tempore announced special order
                                for this hour, [2 o'clock] being Mr. Wallace's bill (2) regulating
                                the manner of choosing of United States Senators. The question being
                                on the adoption of Mr. Heffren'substitute - 
                            Mr. HEFFREN explained his substitute. It proposed that, after ten
                                ballots by both houses and they do not agree by a majority vote,
                                then it shall become the duty of both branches of a Legislature to
                                proceed instanter, in the Hall of the House of Representatives, to
                                the election of Senator or Senators; and the person or persons then
                                receiving a majority of the votes of the General Assembly shall be
                                declared duly elected.
                            Mr. WALLACE made an ineffectual motion to lay the substitute proposed
                                on the tableyeas15, nays 25.
                            Mr. MURRAY demanded the previous question, and there was a second,
                                and the main question was ordered.
                            The substitute was agreed to by yeas 25, nays 16, as follows:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs, Beeson,
                                            Blair,Carnahan,Conley,Culver, Fisk, Hamilton, Hargrove,
                                            Heffren, Hill, Line, Lomax, McClure, McLean, Miller,
                                            Murray, O'Brien, Odell, Shoemaker, Slack, Steele,
                                            Stevens, Studabaker, Tarkington and Williams - 25.
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Anthony, Brown, Cobb,
                                            Conner, Cravens, Gooding, Hendry, Jennings, Johnston,
                                            Kinley, March, Robinson, Thompson, Wagner, Wallace and
                                            Wilson - 16.
                                        REFUSING - Mr. Bobbs.

                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. ANTHONY, when his name was called, said he did not vote against
                                the amendment because he was opposed to it in principle, but because
                                he preferred the other plan. He considered it as next best to the
                                original bill.
                            Mr. GOODING, in explanation, had but very little objection to the
                                amendment, and if the bill were to fail, he would take up with the
                                amendment.
                            Mr. HENDRY, in explanation, was opposed to joint conventions of the
                                General Assembly, and did not think they were ever contemplated by
                                the Constitution. He could not understand how you could make a
                                Legislature out of the fifty members of the Senate and the one
                                hundred members of the House when assembled together. He voted
                                against the proposition.
                            Mr. MARCH, in explanation, was opposed to any plan of election by
                                joint convention.
                            Mr. WALLACE, in explanation, preferred the bill infinitely to
                                anything in the substitute. 
                            So the amendment was substituted for the bill.
                            Mr. MARCH moved to amend the bill by striking out the fourth section
                                - that cont lining the proposition for a joint convention of the
                                Assembly after the tenth ballot.
                            On motion by Mr. ODELL, the bill and pending amendment were referred
                                to a select committee of five, which is made to consist of Sena- tors Odell, Heffren, March,
                                Murray and Johnston.
                        
                        
                            REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                            Mr. HENDRY, from the Judiciary Committee, returned Senator McClure's
                                bill (135) to provide for issuing fee bills and executions against
                                sureties for costs on suits brought against non-residents;
                                recommending indefinite postponement. The report was concurred
                                in.
                            Mr. ANTHONY, from the same committee, returned Senator Blair's bill
                                (127) to amend sections 8, 25 and 26 of an apportionment act
                                approved May 14, 1852, recommending passage. The report was
                                concurred in, the bill ordered to be be engrossed.
                            Mr MARCH, from the same committee, returned his bill (117) admitting
                                all parties to a suit to be witnesses, with one or two exceptions,
                                recommending its passage.
                            Mr. HEFFREN was opposed to concurring in the report.
                            Mr. GOODING sustained the bill, and argued concurrence in the report.
                                He could desire it were made plain in the bill that no negro should
                                have the right to testily against a white man.
                            Mr. MURRAY offered the following as an amendment to the first
                                section:
                            
                                "Providing this section shall not be
                                    considered as rendering competent as witnesses any Indiana,
                                    mulattoes or negroes, or persons having one eighth negro
                                    blood."
                            
                            Mr. GOODING, to that amendment had no objection.
                            Mr. CONNER objected to the clause prohibiting Indians from testifying
                                as witnesses. He had some forty Indian constituents who werehighly
                                educated, and he did not like to see them classed with negroes.
                            Mr. MARCH had no objection to the amendment. He thought no white
                                person should be denied the privilege of coming into court and
                                testifying as a witness, even if he were a party to the suit, and
                                hoped the bill would pass.
                            Mr. CONNER offered the following as an amendment to the
                                amendment.
                            
                                "Provided further, that in all cases where
                                    either the plantiff or the defendent, by reason of any legal
                                    disability,shall not be allowed to testify; then and in that
                                    case, the opposite party shall not be allowed to testify."
                            
                            Mr. MURRAY offered his amendment not because he was in favor of it in
                                the abstract. When the question comes up to remove the incompetence
                                of negroes to testify, he would try to meet it in a manner to
                                satisfy himself and his constituents. He would then show the gross
                                injustice that frequently occurs to the community by reason of that
                                provision denying colored persons the right to testify. 
                            Mr. WALLACE made an ineffectual motion to lay the amendment to the
                                amendment on the table.
                            Mr. HEFFREN made an ineffectual motion to lay the bill and pending
                                amendments on the table-yeas 19, nays 24.
                            Mr. MURRAY accepted of the amendment his amendment. The amendment was
                                then adopted.
                            Mr. WALLACE hoped the bill would not pass. The law has been for many
                                hundred years that party to a suit shall be a witness in the case;
                                but that law has been modified, and he was satisfied with the law as
                                it now stood. If both parties are permitted to swear, why not put
                                them on the jury. He could not see the philosophy between allowing
                                them to appear as witnesses and allowing them to be upon the
                                jury.
                            Mr. MARCH contended there was a good deal of difference.
                            The bill was then ordered to be engrossed, by yeas 22, nays 21.
                            Mr. BLAIR, from a select committee, returned Senator Bobbs' bill (49)
                                fixing the time of holding courts in the Fifth Judicial Circuit,
                                recommending its passage. The report was concurred in and the bill
                                read the second time by title.
                            On motion by Mr. BLAIR, the bill was considered as engrossed, read
                                the third time and finally passed the Senate - yeas 44, nays 0.
                            Mr. TARKINGTON, from a select committee, returned the petition from
                                the city of Madison, praying for the repeal of the 9th section of an
                                amendment to their city charter, recommending the adoption of an
                                accompanying bill, (No. 171} to repeal section 9, of an act to
                                reduce the law incorporating the city of Madison, approved January
                                15, 1849.
                        
                        
                            NEW PROPOSITIONS.
                            The following bills were introduced and severally passed the first
                                reading:
                            By Mr. CRAVENS, (172) to fix the time of holding Circuit Court in the
                                First Judicial Circuit.
                            On motion by Mr. TARKINGTON the rules were suspended - yeas 42, nays
                                0the bill read the first and second time by title, and finally

                            By Mr. CONLEY, (176) to amend sections 8 and 10 of the Justices' act
                                approved June 9, 1852.
                            By Mr. O'BRIAN, (177) to amend section 1 of an act regulating weights
                                and measures, approved June 9, 1852.
                            By Mr. SHOE MAKER, (178) providing for the election and appointment

                            REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                             By Mr. TURPIE - Judiciary - returning Mr.
                                Edwards' (135) relative to granting letters of administration
                                without filing a bond, when such is the will of the testator, with
                                an amendment:
                            Add, after the word "notwithstanding," in the first section, the
                                following:"Provided any person interested in said estate, may, at
                                any time by filing objections in writing with the clerk, granting
                                the said letters without bond or security, require said executor or
                                executrix to give as in other cases; and thereupon no letters shall
                                be issued until the bond be first given; and if the same be issued
                                already, they shall thereupon be forthwith revoked and set aside,
                                and letters testamentary or of administration with the will annexed
                                shall be issued as in other cases."
                             The amendment was adopted, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                            By Mr. DAVIS - Judiciary - returning his bill
                                (139) amedatory of sec. 9, chap. 4, Part First of the Revised
                                Statutes of 1852(with reference to bailable officers)recommending
                                its passage.
                            The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                            By Mr. Baird - Judiciary - returning Mr. Park's
                                bill (146) to amend sec. 364 of the Practice act of June 18,
                                1852(dismissal of debtors in vacation)recommending that the same be
                                laid the table.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            By Mr. TURPIE - Judiciary -  returning , Black's
                                bill (146) to amend sections 18 and 19 of the Justices' act of May
                                29, 1852, with the expression of opinion that legislation on the
                                subject is inexpedient.
                            The bill was laid on the table.
                            By Mr. COLGROVE - Judiciary - return Mr.
                                Stanfield's bill (176) to amend sec. 19 of the Practice act of June
                                18, 1852, recommending its passage.
                            The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                            By Mr. DAVIS - Judiciary - returning Mr. Black's
                                bill (149) amendatory of the act concerning the partition of land,
                                of May 20,1852-(the 11th and 18th sections thereof)recommending
                                passage.
                            The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                            By Mr. BLYTHE - Judiciary - returning Mr, Davis'
                                bill (142) to authorize County Commissioners to make allowances to
                                indemnify the owners of property destroyed, &c., under the
                                administation of the liquor law of 1855, recommending passage.
                            Mr. DAVIS said: Under the operation of what is called the temperance
                                bill, the officers of the law in many cases have seized and
                                destroyed property. They have been sued, and recoveries lave been
                                had against them; and now it remains to be seen whether those men
                                who honestly executed what they thought to be the law, shall be sold
                                out of house and home for so doing, without remedy. I can give a
                                case in my own county, where a party honestly thinking he had a
                                right o do so, seized a quantity of wine. The wine, from simply
                                removing it at that season of the year, was destroyed. Suit was
                                instituted, and recovery was had of some $500. Now it remains or us
                                to-day to say, whether it would be right o compel that poor
                                constable, or his securities to pay that $500, I very respectfully
                                submit, sir, that it would not. The bill does not make it impulsory
                                upon the commissioners to make the allowance. If they should think
                                it right, on examination of the whole question, they may do it in
                                the exercise of their discretion. I submit that this is only even
                                handed justice. I might go further and say, the State or the constituted authorities should
                                pay it. That would be nearer right. If a man is to be bankrupted for
                                executing the jaw, how long will it be before we may not be able to
                                find a man willing to execute the law? The bill was ordered to be
                                engrossed.
                            By Mr. TURPIE - Judiciary - returning the bill (S.
                                30) to provide for the transfer of certificates of the State of
                                Indiana, providing for the registry of the same, to prevent the
                                fraudulent issue thereof, &c., together with Mr. Smith, of
                                Perry's, amendment thereto, providing additional rules regulating
                                the transference of said stock of the State amending the bill, by
                                striking out all fifth line of the 4th section, and recommending-its
                                passage; and recommending that it's amendment be laid on the
                                table.
                            The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to a third reading
                                to-morrow.
                            By Mr. DAVIS - Judiciary - returning Mr. Cotton's
                                bill (137) authorizing the transfer of real property by married
                                women under 21 years of age, recommending indefinite postponement.
                                The report was concurred in.
                            BY Mr. BAIRD - Judiciary - returning Mr. Mellett's
                                bill (86) to amend section 103 of the criminal practice act of June
                                17, 1852, recommending indefinite postponement.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            By Mr. DAVIS - Judiciary - returning Mr. Hunter's
                                bill (167) to provide for the fees of Sheriffs for conveying
                                convicts to the State Prison, &c., recommending indefinite
                                postponement.
                            Mr. HUNTER stated that this conveying convicts to the State Prison
                                was a standing cheat and fraud upon the State, where there is more
                                than one taken at a time. This bill was to provide only reasonable
                                additional charges, where there is more than one convict going at
                                the same time. It would save $5,000 a year.
                            The report was concurred in; and then the bill was ordered to be
                                engrossed.
