                        IN SENATE.
                        
                             WEDNESDAY, February 9, 1859. 
                        
                         Mr. McLEAN said that he had received through the Post office a pamphlet,
                            entitled "Prophecy Explained" directed to the Chairman of the
                                Judiciary Committee of the State of Indiana He
                            moved its reference to the Judiciary Committee
                            without reading.
                        The PRESIDENT pro tempore entertained the motion, and
                            it was so referred.
                        
                            THE CALENDAR.
                            Mr. HEFFREN moved to dispense with the regular order of business and
                                take up the orders of the day - being bills on their third
                                reading.
                            The motion was agreed to.
                            Mr. Turner's bill (13) to amend the swamp land act approved May 29,
                                1852, [taking the power to appoint Swamp Land Commissioners from the
                                Governor and giving it to the County Commissioners] was read.
                            Mr. WILLIAMS moved to strike out the emergency clause.
                            Mr. TURNER objected.
                            [A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of
                                Mr. Slack's bill (84) fixing the time of holding Common Pleas Courts
                                in Huntington and Wells; also Mr. Beeson'a bill (144) to extend the
                                time of holding Courts in the 13th Judicial Circuit.]
                            Mr. MILLER could not see the necessity of the passage of the bill
                                under consideration. It does not change the law as to the management
                                of the swamp land fund or interest. Now if the gentleman from Lake
                                had introduced or will introduce a bill to put the swamp land
                                interest of each county under the entire control of the respective
                                county boards, I am with him. I will heartily vote for any measure
                                that will give the county boards full control over the swamp lands
                                of their respective counties. I would in fact be glad to see the
                                swamp land matter wound up so far as the State is concerned, the
                                State officers making immediate settlements with the swamp land
                                officers of the several counties, and setting to the credit of the
                                State its dues for expenses as provided by law, then transferring
                                the control of the balance to the counties where it properly
                                belongs. But why make this alteration, so long as the State remains
                                a trustee for the safe keeping, and the State officers the financial
                                agents for receiving and paying out all swamp land funds.
                            Mr. TURNER stated that frauds had been perpetrated under the
                                appointing power of the Governor, which were a burning shame to the
                                State, and he knew the Governor was known to the facts - it could
                                not be otherwise.
                            Mr. ANTHONY and Mr. GOODING expressed themselves in favor of the
                                passage of the bill.
                            Mr. CONNER said if the appointing power was to be used by the
                                Governor to subserve private purposes - for the benefit of relatives
                                - he was prepared to vote for a change of this appointing power.
                            The bill was then finally passed the Senate by yeas 40, nays 8.
                            Mr. Conner's bill (17) for the partition of real estate - allowing
                                County Commissioners to lay off streets and alleys on lands
                                adjoining towns, where any of the owners thereof may be minors was
                                read and finally passed the Senate - yeas 48, nays 0.
                            Mr. Bobbs' bill (170) fixing the time of holding Courts of Common
                                Pleas in Marion county, was read.
                            On motion by Mr. BOBBS, a substitute was adopted; the rules suspended
                                - yeas 45, nays 0 and the bill passed the final reading by yeas 46,
                                nays 0.

                        
                        
                            SPECIAL ORDER.
                            The PRESIDENT pro tempore now announced the special
                                order for this hourMr. Bobb's bill (25) providing for the redemption
                                and purchase of Indiana and other State stocks and United States
                                stocks [by the Sinking Fund moneys] the question being on Mr.
                                Studabaker's substitute providing for the distribution of the
                                Sinking Fund  common school
                                purposes among the several counties of the State - excepting so much
                                as may be necessary to pay the back bonds.
                            Mr. TARKINGTON spoke in favor of the substitute proposed, submitting
                                figures clearly proving to his mind the advantages of the substitute
                                over and above the investment proposed by the original bill.
                            Mr. HENDRY argued that a distribution of this fund as proposed by the
                                substitute was far preferable to the investments proposed by the
                                original bill.
                            Mr. MURRAY thought the investments proposed by the bill would be the
                                means of increasing the school fund $1,000,000 within a few years.
                                He thought the proposition was a fair one, and hoped the Senate
                                would give it due consideration. We have got to keep up the Sinking
                                Fund until 1866, or until these bank bonds are paid, and why not
                                make the profitable investments proposed? He was opposed to the
                                dividing up and frittering away of this fund among the several
                                counties of the State, and was in favor of gradually investing this
                                fund in the stocks of the State.
                            Mr. LOMAX expressed himself in favor of the substitute.
                            Mr. CRAVENS [Mr. Hendry in the Chair] was anxious, ready and willing
                                to appropriate this fund in the way which would tend the most toward
                                the advancement of the interests of the School Fund of the State. He
                                would like to see the fund distributed, but as that was a
                                proposition in his opinion which could not be entertained at this
                                time, the investments proposed by the bill under consideration would
                                certainly be the most secure. This fund can not be distributed until
                                the last bond due on the subscription by the State to the bank shall
                                have been re deemed, and therefore he could not support the
                                substitute of the Senator from Adams, [Mr. Studabaker.]
                            Mr. WAGNER said he should vote for the bill of the Senator from
                                Marion [Mr. Bobbs.] He thought the substitute proposed a continually
                                wasting away of the fund, both principal and interest. He did not
                                think the bill went far enough, yet it would answer for the next two
                                years, when he hoped to be able to vote for a better one. He wanted
                                the whole fund sunk in the debt of the State, the State being
                                responsible for the principal and paying the interest. After 1861 he
                                was in favor of putting every dollar that comes into this fund,
                                above what is needed to pay bonds, directly in the treasury of the
                                various counties of the State to be expended for common school
                                purposes.
                            Mr. TARKINGTON could not see why gentlemen wanted to take this school
                                fund from the Commissioners when it is paying 7 per cent, and invest
                                it in bonds which would pay but 6 percent This Sinking Fund was
                                paying far better under its present management than it would by the
                                bill "under consideration; it is as safe as though it were invested
                                in bonds; and if the substitute to the bill were not adopted, he was
                                in favor of letting the law remain just as it stands.
                            Mr. ANTHONY thought it would be well to dispose of all Sinking Funds
                                belonging to the State in order to clear the lobby of a set of men
                                who were always there trying to get at these moneys. For this and
                                other reasons which he submitted in a twelve minute speech, he
                                favored the substitute of the Senator from Adams.
                            On motion by Mr. WAGNER, the Committee on Benevolent
                                    Institutions had leave of absence for the remainder of
                                the day.
                            And then the Senate took a recess till two o'clock.

                        
                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                            Mr. HILL, by unanimous consent, offered the following resolution,
                                which was adopted, nemine contradicente:

                                            directed to furnish each member and officer with three
                                            dollars in postage stamps to enable them to distribute
                                            public documents. 
                                    
                                
                            

                            
                                WABASH AND ERIE CANAL
                                Mr. LINE, by consent, offered the following preamble and
                                    resolution, which were adopted by consent: 
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            WHEREAS, The Federal Government
                                                did donate to the State of Indiana, a large lot of
                                                land to aid said State in the prosecution of the
                                                Wabash and Erie Canal;
                                            AND WHEREAS, The State of Indiana,
                                                owing to her financial embarrassment, did convey to
                                                her bond holders said Canal, and the lands which had
                                                been donated by the Federal Government, yet unsold,
                                                as a consideration in full of one-half of her State
                                                debt;
                                            AND WHEREAS, The Trustees of said
                                                Canal have announced their intention to abandon said
                                                Canal;
                                            AND WHEREAS, It is uncertain to what extent the State
                                                of Indiana is involved or may become involved, or
                                                liable on account of said abandonment, either to
                                                individuals or to the State of Ohio, in case of said
                                                abandonment; therefore,
                                            Resolved, That a committee of five
                                                be appointed, whose duty it shall be to investigate
                                                the whole affair as connected with the transfer of
                                                said Canal, and report the extent (if any) to which
                                                Indiana is liable, either to individuals as lessees
                                                of water power, or to the State of Ohio, and that
                                                they report to the Senate at as early a day as
                                                practicable; and be it further
                                            Resolved, That for the purpose of
                                                aiding said committee in a full and free
                                                investigation of all the facts in the case that they
                                                have free access to all the public record of the
                                                State touching this matter.
                                        
                                    
                                
                            
                            
                                DISPOSITION OF THE SINKING FUND
                                 The Senate resumed the consideration of the subject pending at
                                    the time of the recess.
                                Mr. STEVENS was in favor of disposing of this fund so that each
                                    county may have the management of a share of it. He objected to
                                    the original bill because he did not believe the people would be
                                    satisfied with it, and that it was a blow against their very
                                    best interests. He did not believe the fund could be better
                                    secured than by loaning it to the counties of the State and
                                    taking mortgages upon real estate at one-half its valuation.
                                Mr. HEFFREN thought the substitute would be impracticable at this
                                    time. He objected to the distribution of this fund until the
                                    plighted faith of the State be redeemed by the taking up of our
                                    bank bonds. As between the original bill and the substitute, he
                                    was in favor of the bill. The best thing we can do is to pass a
                                    law for the redemption of these bonds; and after that, let some
                                    just disposition be made of this fund. He was in favor of that
                                    principle which will most conduce to the interests of the whole
                                    people of the State of Indiana.
                                Mr. COBB thought this fund should be distributed; and he believed
                                    it could be so disposed of,  with as much security as it is now managed. Indeed there can
                                    not be any loss, if the law is carried out providing that no
                                    money shall beloaned on a security of real estate unless it
                                    exceeds in value the amount of money loaned, by one half, and
                                    that no perishable improvements shall be taken into the account.
                                    If this money is vested as provided for in the original bill it
                                    can not subserve the interests of the people to such a degree as
                                    if disposed of as proposed int he substitute. Under the present
                                    law this fund is not equally distributed it seems to be given to
                                    those residing near here, to the exclusion of citizens residing
                                    at a distance from the capital.
                                This objection would be overcome by the adoption of the
                                    substitute proposed.
                                Mr. ROBINSON - between the two propositions submitted for the
                                    disposition of the Sinking Fund - could not see how Senators
                                    could object to he one which proposes the distribution. He was
                                    in favor of letting the people of Indiana have the use of this
                                    $3,000,000 that belonged to them.
                                [A message was received from the House announcing the adherence
                                    of that body to its amendment to the shinplaster bill (H. R.
                                    12.)
                                Mr. HEFFREN, by leave, subsequently made a motion, which was
                                    agreed to, that a committee of conference be appointed on the
                                    part of the Senate, which is made to consist of Senators
                                    Heffren, Tarkington and Kinley.]
                                Mr. BOBBS was heard in a few remarks in reply to arguments urged
                                    by Senators in opposition to his bill.
                                Mr. STUDABAKER was also heard in answer to objections urged
                                    against his substitute for the bill.
                                The further consideration of this subject was informally passed
                                    over on account of the absence of several Senators who desired
                                    to be present when the vote should be taken.
                                Mr. WALLACE, by leave, from the Committee on Military Affairs,
                                    returned his bill (149) for the organization of the militia of
                                    the State, &c., recommending its passage. The report was
                                    concurred in, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                                On motion by Mr. WILSON, the bill (H. R. 23) legalizing the acts
                                    of a Justice of the Peace of Jackson county, to whom a
                                    commission was issued without the affixing of the signature of
                                    the Governor, was taken up, read the first, second and third
                                    time, and finally passed the Senate by yeas 37, nays 1.
                                Mr. ANTHONY, by leave, introduced a bill (182) to abolish the
                                    Court of Common Pleas, &c.
                                Mr. ANTHONY explained the provisions of the bill, as follows:
                                The bill proposes to change the judiciary system by depositing
                                    the power now vested in the Circuit Court and Court of Common
                                    Pleas, .in the Circuit Court and the clerk of that court, giving
                                    the Circuit Court jurisdiction over all manner of litigation,
                                    where the amount involved exceeds $100, and concurrent
                                    jurisdiction with justices, between $50 and $100.
                                It gives to the clerk of the court a limited power in the nature
                                    f the power vested in the surrogate in the State of New
                                    York-giving him power to make settlements with administrators,
                                    and to determine and settle claims in favor of and against the
                                    estates of deceased persons, requiring administrators, executors
                                    &c., to report to him in short, requiring him to settle the
                                    mere business transactions in which the intervention of a court
                                    is not necessary. Where claims and settlements are disputed by
                                    interested parties, it is the duty of the clerk to docket the
                                    case, and it goes to the Circuit Court for settlement there. It
                                    will, of course, require an increase in the number of circuits;
                                    the bill proposes 25, which would make an average of less than 4
                                    counties to each circuit. It increases the salaries of judges to
                                    $1,500 per annum, and provides a tax upon litigants by way of a
                                    docket fee, to pay the expenses of the court. The object of the
                                    bill is to decrease litigation - to remove useless courts, and
                                    consequently useless expenses; to provide a salary sufficient to
                                    secure competent talent upon the Bench, and thereby secure to
                                    the intricate and important matters which often arise in the
                                    settlement of estates, as in civil and criminal litigation, a
                                    just, uniform and enlightened determination, and will prevent
                                    their important interests from being sacrificed to ignorance and
                                    dishonesty, as now too frequently the case; to save to the State
                                    [a large amount of money] and thus relieve the tax-payer of a
                                    part of the onerous burden they are compelled to carry under the
                                    present expensive system of administering the affairs of the
                                    State.
                                On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the rules were suspended - yeas 34, nays
                                    4the bill read the first time by title only, instead of being
                                    read through by sections. It was also read the second time by
                                    title and referred to the Judiciary
                                    Committee.
                                Mr. SLACK, by leave, introduced a bill (183) in relation to the
                                    partition of real estate, which was passed the first
                                    reading.
                                On motion by Mr. MILLER, the bill (H. R. 36) fixing the time of
                                    holding courts in the 9th Judicial Circuit, was taken up, read
                                    the first, second and third time, and finally passed the Senate
                                    - yeas 38, nays 0.
                                Mr. JOHNSTON introduced a bill (184) to amend section 8 of an act
                                    in relation to County Treasurers, approved June 4, 1854, which
                                    was read the first time.
                                On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the bill (H. R. 168) to amend section 1
                                    of an act authorizing road companies to borrow money, and secure
                                    the repayment thereof by mortgage, was taken up; the rules
                                    suspended - yeas 39, nays 0-the bill read the second time by
                                    title and referred to a select committee of three, which is made
                                    to consist of Senators Heffren, Murray and Bobbs.
                                Mr. TARKINGTON introduced a bill (185) providing for the
                                    assessment and taxation of banks, brokers, stock jobbers,
                                    insurance companies, trust companies, and savings institutions;
                                    which was read by title only the first time, under a suspension
                                    of the rules - yeas 38, naye 0.
                                On motion by Mr. TARKINGTON, the bill was read the second time,
                                    laid on the table, and 100 copies ordered to be printed.
                                And then the Senate adjourned.
                                
                            
                        
                    
                    

                    

                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
                        
                             WEDNESDAY, February 9, 1859. 
                        
                        Mr. Hancock had leave of absence till Monday.
                        Mr. MELLETT, from the Committee on Banks, returned Mr.
                            Smith of Perry's bill [188] supplemental to the general banking law of
                            March 3, 1855, providing for additional security, and for the delivery,
                            surrender, exchange or sale of stocks or bonds deposited under said act,
                            recommending passage.
                        The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                        Mr. PARKS, from the Committee on Rights and
                            Privileges, returned petitions for the protection of fish in
                            the lakes - having heretofore reported a bill for that object.
                        The petitions were laid on the table.
                        Mr. MASSEY, from a majority of the same committee, returned Mr. Nebeker
                            of Warren's bill (6) to amend the second section of the act of 7th
                            March, 1857, to authorize new counties, and change county boundaries,
                            recommending that it be laid on the table.
                        Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, submitted a minority report, as follows:
                        Mr. SPEAKER - The undersigned, a member of the Committee on Rights and
                            Privileges of the inhabitants of this State, would respectfully submit
                            to the House of Representatives, his reasons for dissenting from the
                            decision of the majority of said committee in relation to the report
                            just made, on House bill No. 6, entitled "A bill to amend the second
                            section of an act approved March 7, 1857, entitled an Act to authorize
                            the formation of new counties and to change county boundaries."
                        The undersigned has not been able to find any law on any statute book,
                            that furnishes the same facility for a portion of a county to transfer
                            itself, and without notice, and without ascertaining the wish of the
                            voters of one or of the other of the counties to be effected thereby;
                            severing corporations with the wish only of the minority expressed;
                            diminishing or increasing the jurisdiction of county officers;
                            subjecting counties to be added to or diminished to suit the whims of
                            politicians and others; destroying vested rights and deranging land
                            titles.
                        The Constitution will not permit a county that has an area of over four
                            hundred square miles, to be reduced below that quantity; nor a county
                            with less than that quanty to be further reduced.
                        There are in the State thirty-nine counties that have an area of over
                            four hundred square miles, then that number of counties can be effected
                            by a reduction, and as all of these counties are surrounded by other
                            counties to which they may be attached territory, it will be seen that
                            all, or nearly all of the counties are interested in this question. We
                            have not been curious enough to hunt out the exceptions, if there are
                            any. We do not deem it proper that the lines of counties should be
                            changed, without giving the interested parties notice by advertisement
                            in a newspaper or otherwise. Yet the law as it now stands does not
                            require notice of any kind. But your statutes sufficiently guard the
                            rights of the people inroads, so as to require twenty days notice, and a
                            petition to the next session of the board of commissioners; the
                            appointment and view, and report to the next board thereafter; if any
                            objection be made by any one, the board are required to appoint
                            reviewers, whoso duty it is to assess damages and report to the next
                            board. Not so with this.
                        The section of the law proposed to be amended, provides that a majority
                            of the legal voters who shall reside in a territory whose jurisdiction
                            it is proposed to change, may change the same by petition; without
                            consulting the minority of said territory; without giving notice by
                            advertisement; without providing for a view or review of the question,
                            and without providing for the payment of damages. And all of this is to
                            be done too, without giving any means by which the wish of the voters of
                            the county to be effected thereby can be known.
                        An organized county is a corporation. The legal right to dissolve a
                            corporation by a majority only of the disaffected who
                            desire to go out of the corporation is doubted. We think the consent of
                            a majority of the corporators is imperative. If this principle is wrong,
                            why not extend the provisions of the law to States, and to townships? A
                            county can receive territory that may contain one section of land and
                            five votes, if three of said voters should petition for such change.
                            This question does affect the whole county; to
                            illustrate, take the county of Allen, she has a territory of 672 square
                            miles and can be shorn of 272 square miles, which is over one third of
                            her territory. The majority of the whole county voted a stock of
                            $100,000 for railroad purposes. Now if it is legal, is it for one third
                            of the county of Allen, after aiding by their votes to create this debt,
                            to attach itself to one or more of the six counties that touch her
                            borders, without first securing the consent of the remaining two thirds
                            of the county that would yet remain to constitute the county of Allen,
                            and to pay the whole debt, with only two-thirds of her acres upon which
                            to levy a tax; the other one-third having avoid the liability by being
                            attached to other counties?
                        By this law the jurisdiction of county officers may be reduced and their
                            rights curtailed, and that may be done by consulting a majority only of
                            the one third of the territory that to-day constitutes
                            a part of the county of Allen, but to-morrow may be taking the first
                            steps toward dissolution, To illustrate: the Recorder's jurisdiction
                            would be reduced to two thirds of its former area. Territories now
                            attached to counties, the area of which is over four hundred square
                            miles, may avoid the taxes assessed for any purpose. For example, say
                            building a court-house, by attaching itself to another county, by its
                            own action, without the consent of the tax payers of the county
                            interested in said assessment.
                         Therefore, the undersigned would recommend the passage of the bill.
                        R.M. NEBEKER
                        The House refused to concur in the report of the majority.
                        Mr. MURRAY moved to reconsider the vote.
                        Mr. HARRISON replied to the argument for the bill, submitted in the
                            minority report. The bill proposed to amend the existing law so as to
                            allow the whole county to vote on the question of the motion of the
                            people residing on the excess of territory over 400 square miles to be
                            set off, &c., instead of that portion only which maybe desirous of
                            being so transferred, and which may be legally transferred to another
                            county. He would like to hear more of the reasons tor this amendment of
                            the law, which he believed was a mere question of taxation - of the
                            exercise of arbitrary power. Were not local interests to be subserved by
                            this bill?
                        Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, argued that a county is a corporation, and denied
                            the right of a portion thereof to act in any matter affecting the whole,
                            without the consent of the majority. If the principle were good in the
                            case of counties, it would be good in the case of States. Would it be
                            proper for Warren county to vote herself into the State of Illinois? The
                            title of the statute of 1857 should have been, "An act for the purpose
                            of getting people by the ears." He gave an example of the case of the
                            County of Allen. Her people had voted $100,000 for railroad stock; and
                            it was now manifestly unjust to allow one-third of her tax payers to
                            attach themselves to another county, or other counties, and so shirk
                            their part of this responsibility.
                        Mr. DOBBINS had voted against the act of 1857, and still dissented from
                            its principle, which allows the minority thus to relieve themselves from
                            tax responsibilities.
                        Mr. MURRAY It was manifestly the effect if not the object of the bill of
                            the gentleman from Warren, to prevent the change of county boundaries.
                            He replied to the argument of Mr. Nebeker.
                        
                        Mr. FIRESTONE was glad of the opportunity to be able to vote with the
                            gentleman from Warren, and he rehearsed the case of the county of
                            Allen.
                        Mr. CLAYPOOL supported the principle of the bill and gave an example in
                            the history of the desire to change the boundary between Fountain and
                            Warren, to avoid taxation. He had no doubt there would be a change
                            effected ultimately, but he wanted it to be done fairly.
                        Mr. RYNERSON spoke against the bill, and gave an example of the necessity
                            of the application of the provisions of the present law to the desire of
                            a portion of the people of Morgan county to be attached to Putnam.
                        Mr. DOUGHERTY. These speeches disclose the working of self interest. The
                            gentleman from Howard desires a slice from Clinton;and the gentleman
                            from Putnam, a portion of Morgan county. He did not like the present but
                            as between that and the bill of Mr .Nebeker, he preferred the law as it
                            is. He gave examples. He had no doubt that a majority of the county of
                            Morgan, on proper application,would let off to Putnam the Eel river
                            portion, &c.
                        Mr. WHETZEL concurred in the latter sentiment.
                        Mr. SNYDER thought the bill might infringe the Constitution, and for the
                            purpose of reference, he hoped the vote would be reconsidered.
                        Mr. PROSSER moved to lay the motion to reconsider on the table, but
                            withheld the motion for - 
                         Mr. HARRISON, who spoke further in reply to Mr. Nebeker, and Mr.
                            Dougherty. He was interested. A portion of the county of Clinton did
                            desire to come into Howard county. But the gentleman from Warren had
                            admitted his interest in the passage of his bills, &c. Democrats
                            desire that States should shape their affairs in their own way, but here
                            they trampled under foot their own principles, as applied to the people
                            of a county. He gave examples sustaining his position and the justice
                            and wisdom of the existing law. The only question involved, was as to
                            the rights of the people within a given territory.
                        Mr. WHETZEL made an ineffectual demand for the previous question
                        Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, replied to Mr. Harrison, discussing the local
                            question as it affects the people of Fountain and Warren.
                        Mr. NEWTON. Like the gentleman from Howard, he was personally interested
                            here. He wanted a portion of Clinton county, and the people of Clinton
                            did not want to set off that portion. But a bare majority of the portion
                            proposed to be set off were in favor of it, and every man in the county,
                            outside of that portion, was opposed to it. He was a popular sovereignty
                            man, but was not in favor of setting up every township as an independent
                            sovereignty. He reasoned upon the injustice which would result from this
                            detachment of the best portion of his county. He considered that Mr.
                            Nebeker's bill ought to pass.
                        The motion to reconsider was then laid on the table, and Mr. Nebeker's
                            bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                        Mr. PARRETT (by leave) presented the petition of sundry citizens of the
                            counties of Perry and Spencer, for a new county to be formed out of the
                            territory of said counties to be submitted to the voters of said
                            counties at the general election of 1860.
                        Mr. PARRETT referred to the constitutional provision for the proposed new
                            county, stating that he presented the paper (wholly disinterested)
                            simply recognizing the right of petition; and on his motion it was
                            referred to Messrs. Smith of Perry, Jones, Parrett, Davis and
                            Blythe.
                        On motion of Mr. BAIRD, (the orders being dispensed with,) the vote
                            concurring in the Judiciary Committee's report to postpone Mr. Prosser's
                            bill No 37, was reconsidered, and the bill referred to Messrs. Baird and
                            others.

                        
                            SHINPLASTERS.
                             On motion by Mr. STANFIELD, Mr. Martin's bill (12) was taken up, and
                                he explained the amendment he had submitted to the Senate's
                                amendment to said bill, which is to the following effect:
                            Nothing in this act shall be so construed as to permit any person,
                                corporation, &c., other than the Bank of the State and the Free
                                Banks, to issue or put into circulation any such paper.
                            It was not the effect of the amendment to clothe the Bank of the
                                State and the Free Banks with authority to circulate this
                                unauthorized paper, &c. That error of construction came probably
                                from the terms of the title of the bill. That construction might be
                                given to the original bill, and his amendment was to counteract
                                that. He hoped the House would adhere, and that a committee of free
                                conference be had. He desired earnestly to stop these rag mills.
                            The House insisted on the amendment.
                        
                        
                            RECOGNIZANCE OF BONDS.
                            Mr. BROTHERTON moved a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday,
                                rejecting Mr. Stiles' bill (No. 88) to make recognizances to bind
                                the real estate of the securities as well as the principal, from the
                                date thereof.
                            Mr. STILES reasoned on the propriety and necessity of the enactment
                                proposed in the bill.
                            Mr. PARRETT admitted the plausibility of the reasoning, and replied,
                                coming to an adverse conclusion. It would take away the power of
                                giving a recognizance bond from too many persons, and it would fill
                                up the county jails, &c.
                            Mr. STILES spoke again.
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush, supported the provisions of the bill.
                            Mr. PARRETT. The bill might as well go a step further and require the
                                money, to the extent of the bond, to be deposited for the security
                                of its payment. He reasoned at length to show that such a loan would
                                operate oppressively and expensively. It was looking that way and
                                would be a bad law.
                            Mr. PROSSER was for the bill. The man that violated the law should be
                                punished, and if another stepped in to shield him enable him to
                                avoid the sanction of the lawlet his property pay the forfeit.
                            Mr. DAVIS would not punish a man before he is tried. This
                                incarceration for want of bail was no part of the punishment. The
                                law presumes  the innocence of
                                the accused. He had seen nothing of the ill-working of the present
                                law of which Mr. Stiles had spoken. He looked at the practical
                                operation of the bill, &c.
                            Mr. GRIFFIN was in favor of the bill and hoped the motion to
                                reconsider would prevail. Under the present law the surety could
                                convey away his property and avoid the bond after default is made.
                                He gave a case of abuse of this law, which had just come to his
                                knowledge, where property was disposed of before judgment was taken
                                on the bond, &c.
                            Mr. MURRAY was opposed to the bill, because he would not encourage
                                the common impression that a rich man can over-ride the law and
                                baffle the authority of the courts of justice. It would enlarge the
                                sphere of impunity of the man of property.
                            Mr. RITTER. It would be more inconvenient for the attorney to go bail
                                for his client, it were made impossible for him to avoid the payment
                                of the forfeited bond.
                            He thought th property of the bailor should be held from the date of
                                the bond.
                            Mr. LAWHEAD demanded the previous question, and under its force the
                                House refused to reconsider - yeas 25, nays 62, as follows:

                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                            The bill from the Senate (S. 181) was passed the first reading.

                                Pleas Act of May 14,1852, recommending passage.

                                Committee.
                            Mr. MURRRY (by leave) submitted the following: 
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,By this House, the Senate
                                            concurring, that the Door-keeper be and he is hereby
                                            authorized to instruct the publishers of the Brevier Legislative Sentinel to retain
                                            the copies ordered by this House for binding, as was
                                            done for the members thereof at the special session; one
                                            copy of which, when bound, shall be furnished to each
                                            member, and the balance distributed,one to each Township
                                            Library, for the use of the people; and that the members
                                            furnish said Door-keeper with the three copies of Brevier Legislative Reports already
                                            laid on their desks. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. EARLY proposed to strike out that part of the resolution which
                                assigns the Reports to the County Libraries.
                            Mr. MURRAY accepted.
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush. It would be impossible, to furnish the Door-keeper
                                with the number the Reports received. Some of us have sent them
                                off.
                            Mr. MELLETT wanted to know what additional expense this would induce
                                - and spoke generally against the resolution, as leading to any
                                expense already larger than many members intended, who voted for
                                500, when it turns out that the order was for 1,100 copies, costing
                                $1,100. He also asserted that it was not a proper book for the
                                township libraries, &c. It was money thrown away to place them
                                there. 
                            Mr. MURRAY'S object in this was to give to the people reliable
                                information of the proceedings of the Legislature, which he
                                acknowledged would be thrown away unless these Reports were
                                preserved and bound. Every newspaper editor should have a copy. They
                                would prove a valuable source of information through the press. He
                                ventured to suggest to the gentleman that if he continued to be
                                observant ot the future politics of the State he would know whether
                                these Reports can be put to use or not. He would venture to say that
                                the gentleman from Henry could not be able to come before the people
                                for office without these Legislative Reports staring him in the
                                face.
                            Mr. MELLETT. If the gentleman from Elkhart desired ever to come back
                                here, he had better vote to burn these reports, than to preserve
                                them. He [Mr. M.] wanted none of them, beyond the purpose of their
                                daily publication here. He wanted them to become extinct as soon as
                                possible, and he thought gentlemen would agree with him when they
                                found out that the amount to be voted for papers in the
                                appropriation bill would run up to $5,000. He alleged that these
                                reports could not be quoted as authority. They had not been
                                authorized by resolution, and he ventured to say, if they were
                                quoted against the gentleman from Elkhart, he would deny the
                                authority.
                            Mr, MURRAY, [in his seat ] No sir.
                            Mr. MELLETT. We have not bound ourselves by any resolution
                                authorizing the reports: and suppose I deny the authority when they
                                are referred to, how will the gentleman help himself?
                            A VOICE. Go to the Journal.
                            Mr. MELLETT. Yes, to the Journal. That s a much more readable
                                document.
                            Mr. EDWARDS, interposing. If the gentleman objects to having the
                                members of the House bound by the Legislative Reports, why is it
                                that he should not be willing to have the Reports bound by the
                                House? [Laughter.]
                            
                            After further opposition by Mr. Mellett, and propositions to modify

                                account of the copies returned to him, &c.

                                SHINPLASTER BILL.
                                 A message from the Senate by Mr. Senator Heffren, announced the
                                    appointmeet of Messrs'. Heffren, Tarkington and Kinley, a
                                    committee of conference on the disagreeing votes between the two
                                    Houses upon the House amendment to Mr. Martin's shinplaster bill
                                    (12) and requesting the appointment of a similar committee on
                                    the part of the House of Representatives.
                                On the motion of Mr. STANFIELD, the order for this appointment
                                    was taken by consent, and the SPEAKER makes said committee on
                                    the part of the House, to consist of Messrs. Stanfield, Martin
                                    and Blythe.
                                The bill (S. 102) to amend the 3d sec. of the Common Pleas act,
                                    being considered on the second reading - 
                                Mr. MARTIN moved that it be referred to a committee of one from
                                    each Congressional District.
                                Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison, stated that his constituents were
                                    dissatisfied with that provision of the bill which would
                                    disconnect Madison with Hancock.
                                Mr. GIFFORD was in favor of Mr. Martin's motion. The bill would
                                    not suit his people.
                                Mr. CLEMENTS proposed to amend the motion to refer, so as to
                                    refer to one member from each Judicial Circuit, with
                                    instructions to make 22 out of the 44 Common Pleas districts in
                                    the State. This would make the Court of Common Pleas respectable
                                    - enable competent lawyers to take its Judgeships, and it would
                                    save expense.
                                Mr. STANFIELD was satisfied of the practicability of this
                                    suggestionthat it would save at least $10,000 annually.
                                Mr. HAMILTON of Boone, proposed 20 districts, which was agreed
                                    to, and so the instructions were adopted.
                                So the bill was referred to a select committee of one from each
                                    Judicial District, viz: Messrs.  Clements, Hamilton, of Boone, and
                                    others - not announced.
                                Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison, moved that the committee be instructed
                                    to make the counties of Madison, Hancock and Shelby to
                                    constitute one district, which was rejected.
                                Mr. PROSSER proposed instructions to make Green and Owen one
                                    district; Clay and Sullivan one district, &c.; which was
                                    laid on the table.
                                The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the
                                    Auditor of State, responding to a resolution of the House of the
                                    3d inst., embracing statements of the amounts of money audited
                                    in favor of the present Secretary of State and his predecessors;
                                    and the amounts audited and paid to all persons on account of
                                    selecting swamp lands. The total amount of these last sums paid
                                    is $9,052 50.
                                On motion of Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, the communication was
                                    referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.
                            
                            
                                SCHOOL TOWNSHIP CORPORATIONS.
                                 On motion of Mr. STANFIELD, his bill (5) to authorize school
                                    townships, &c., was considered on the third reading.
                                Mr. STANFIELD. By the present law there is no authority for
                                    taking titles to school house lots. The titles are generally in
                                    the trustees. I think it a matter of public policy that
                                    townships should be incorporated, not only as civil townships,
                                    but as school townships; that they should be corporate bodies
                                    for the purpose of taking titles of school house lots in their
                                    corporate name. That would obviate all difficulty about the
                                    death of township trustees, who now hold these titles as
                                    individuals. That is the principal purpose of the bill. Another
                                    purpose is, that, where a school house is not occupied for the
                                    public school, it may be occupied for a private school or any
                                    public meeting under the township authorities. As the law now
                                    is, there can be no legal occupancy of the school houses, but
                                    for the common schools.
                                Mr. DOBBINS suggested a constitutional difficulty. The school
                                    houses might be occupied for religious meetings and church
                                    purposes. There was a constitutional provision, that no person
                                    shall be taxed lor the support of the faith of any religious
                                    denomination.
                                Mr. STANFIELD had that question before him. The provision of the
                                    bill was, to authorize the use of the school house for any
                                    purpose that a majority of the township shall approve,
                                    &c.
                                The bill was passed the final reading in the House of
                                    Representatives - yeas 67, nays 11.
                                The House then, at 4:40, adjourned.

                            HORSE-THIEF DETECTIVES.
                            Mr. HILL, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, to which was
                                referred so much of the Governor's message as relates to an act,
                                approved March 9, 1852, authorizing the formation of companies for
                                the detection and apprehesion
                            
                        
                    
                    
                
                
                
                    BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
                    BY ARIEL & W. H. DRAPIER
                    
                        Vol. II.
                        INDIANAPOLIS, FEB. 15, 1859.
                        No. 11.
                    
                    
                        
                            of horse-thieves, reported a bill (187) to repeal that act.
                            Senator Wagner and Senator Rice expressed themselves as opposed to
                                the repeal of the law referred to.
                            Mr. BOBBS opposed the repeal of the law authorizing the formation of
                                associations for the detection and apprehension of horse-thieves. He
                                was willing to hear from such Senators as had objections to the law,
                                as to their reasons, and if there be abuses practiced under cover of
                                the law, see if they cannot be provided for. The recommendations of
                                the Governor are entitled to receive the consideration of the
                                Senate, but many of his most respectable constituents are opposed to
                                a repeal of the law, and he was here to represent their wishes. He
                                said there were organizations in his county embracing among their
                                members some of our best citizens, who believe they have been
                                enabled to render great service to the community in the protection
                                of their property, in the manner allowed by this law. Some of those
                                have remonstrated against the repeal, and he did not know any of his
                                constituents who are directly interested in the question, who desire
                                the repeal; he, therefore, was opposed to the repeal, and hoped the
                                Senate would not concur in the recommendation of the committee.
                            Senators Heffren and McLean were in favor of the repeal, and cited
                                the cruelties, murders and unrelenting inhumanities perpetrated
                                under this act by those regulators in Noble and Brown counties, as
                                unanswerable arguments in favor of concurring in the report of the
                                committee, and of the immediate passage of the bill recommended by
                                it.
                            Mr. GOODING dissented from the report, holding that the law itself
                                was good, but admitting that it was not properly carried out.
                            Mr. HAMILTON said the people of the region of Noble county for years
                                were under the influence of the greatest set of rascals the country
                                ever produced; but he did not justify the murder spoken of in that
                                county, as committed by the regulators. He was opposed to the repeal
                                of the law.
                            Mr. CONLEY was satisfied gross outrages had been committed under the
                                law, but that was no the fault of the law. The perpetrators of the
                                outrage alluded to as having occurred in Monroe county were composed
                                of the rag-tag and bobtail of the country round about. He did not
                                agree to a concurrence in the report of the committee, and expressed
                                the hope that it would not be made a party test. [Laughter.]
                            Mr. HILL might not vote in favor of the report; he was directed by
                                the committee to make it; had done so, and should not be
                                dissatisfied if the Senate refused to concur.
                            Mr. TURNER was opposed to the repeal of this law.
                            Mr. STUDABAKER moved to indefinitely postpone the consideration of
                                the report.
                            The motion was agreed to - yeas 34, nays 12.
                            Mr. MURRAY, by consent, offered the following resolution, which,
                                under the rules, lies over one day.
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the following additional
                                            rules be adapted for the government of the Senate:
                                        RULE.-Any Senator desiring to give an
                                            explanation of the reasons for his vote upon any
                                            question before the Senate, may do so before the calling
                                            of ayes and nays is commenced, and not after, without
                                            the unanimous consent of the Senate.
                                        RULE.Every Senator shall be limited in
                                            debate to not more than ten minutes at a time, and not
                                            more than twice on the same question.
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. KINLEY, from the Committee on Rights and
                                    Privileges, returned Mr. Garnahan's bill (86) to amend
                                an act regulating marriage, approved March 22, 1852; and Mr. Hill's
                                bill (22) to prevent the inter-marriage of first cousins, &c.;
                                recommending that No. 22 lie on the table, and submitting a
                                substitute for No. 86 providing that all marriages between first
                                cousins or between persons of closer degrees of consanguinity which
                                may hereafter take place in this State, shall be void: and to amend
                                the title so that it shall read "An act to prevent the intermarriage
                                of blood relations."
                            Mr. CONLEY moved to amend by inserting in the proper place the words
                                "second cousins."
                            Mr. CARNAHAN was satisfied with the report of the committee.
                            Mr. GOODING concurred in the spirit of the bill - opposed the
                                marriage of blood relations, but objected to that provision which
                                makes the marriages of cousins void.
                            Mr. MURRAY moved to lay the amendment on the table.
                            Mr. WAGNER moved to amend the motion by laying the whole subject on
                                the table.
                            Mr. BENNETT demanded a division of the question.
                            The amendment proposed by Mr. Conley was laid on the table by yeas
                                29, nays 16.
                            The motion to lay the bill and amendments on the table was rejected -
                                yeas 9, nays 37.
                            Mr. CONNER was not in favor of the marriage of cousins, but proposed
                                to amend as follows:
                            Provided, This act shall not affect marriage
                                contracts now existing between cousins and which have not been
                                consummated.
                            
                             Considerable merriment sprung up upon a conversational debate on
                                this amendment, when - 
                            Mr. CARNAHAN said he was sorry to see sport made of such a grave
                                matter.
                            Mr. CONNER said his amendment was offered in good faith.
                            Mr. CARNAHAN did not doubt that, but referred entirely to the mirth
                                made out of it.
                            Mr. MARCH hoped the amendment would be adopted.
                            Mr. MURRAY was in favor of the provisions of the bill.
                            Mr. HEFFREN was opposed to the amendment.
                            Mr. CARNAHAN moved to lay the amendment on the table.
                            The motion was agreed to by yeas 25, nays 21, as follows:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson,
                                            Bennett, Blair, Bobbs, Brown, Carnahan, Conley, Culver,
                                            Hamilton, Hargrove, Heffren, Jennings, Jones, Kinley,
                                            Line, Lomax, McLean, Murray, O'Brien, Odell, Shoemaker,
                                            Studabaker, Williams and Wilson - 25.
                                        NAYS - essrs. Cobb, Conner, Craven,
                                            Fisk, Gooding, Hendry, Hill, Johnston, McClure, March,
                                            Miller, Rice, Robinson, Slack, Steele, Stevens,
                                            Tarkington, Thompson, Turner, Wagner and Wallace -
                                            21.
                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. LOMAX proposed to amend by inserting in the proper place the
                                following:
                            "Provided, This act shall not take effect till
                                after the first of September, 1859."Mr, STEVENS proposed to recommit
                                with the following instructions:
                            Amend by prohibiting Clerks of Courts from issuing marriage license
                                to first cousins, and attach penalties there for by prohibiting any
                                person from performing marriage ceremonies of parties they know to
                                be first cousins, under penalties, and by subjecting all parties who
                                may apply for or obtain license and marry, who are first cousins, to
                                penalties. 
                            Mr. LINE demanded a division of the question, first upon the
                                proposition to re-commit, and then upon the instructions.
                            Mr. BOBBS said the principles of the bill are right, and the subject
                                was a proper one for legislation, but he was not satisfied that the
                                bill provided the best mode of preventing the evil. Beside this was
                                not so general as seemed to be assumed by gentlemen. Where
                                intermarriages occurred within the relationship of consanguiuity
                                named by the bill, for successive generations, the evil results were
                                manifest and very serious; but such marriages were not frequent in
                                this State, and its evil results are overrated. In older
                                communities, as in the slave States, or others where wealthy
                                arristocracies existed, and class distinctions in society had become
                                established, intermarriages among related families were more
                                frequent, and entailed misfortune upon offspring. If Senators were
                                governed by the statistics furnished by our asylums they were liable
                                to be misled, as the statistics of other nations did not sustain the
                                position.
                            The objections which present themselves to me are that the bill
                                proposes to amend the marriage contract, instead of preventing these
                                within certain degrees of consanguinity. All the parties need to do,
                                is to cross the line into some adjacent State, and have the marriage
                                solemnized there. The law would therefore fail to prevent the evil
                                to be provided against. It seems to me the law ought to provide
                                against the consumption of such marriages by opposing obstructions
                                to them. Prohibit any person from solemnizing marriages within this
                                State, and within the relationship of consanguinity proposed; and
                                any clerk from issuing licenses for such purposes, to parties so
                                related. He favored the suggestion of the amendments of the Senator
                                from Decatur, and would prefer to have the bill go to the Committee
                                of the Judiciary, to be modified and perfected in conformity with
                                these suggestions, and therefore move such recommendation.
                            The report was then referred to the Judiciary
                                    Committee.
                            On motion by Mr. CONNER the instruction were also referred to the
                                same committee.
                            On motion by Mr. WALLACE the committe were instructed to inquire into
                                the expediency of amending so as to make it a part of the affidavit
                                now required for a license, that the parties ar not cousins within
                                the meaning of the statute.
                            Mr. McLEAN, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned his
                                bill (16) to amend the first section of a license act, approved June
                                15, 1852, and for the encouragement of Agriculture, &c.,
                                approved March 7, 1857, recommending its passage. The report was
                                concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
