                                auditor transcripts of such to be read in evidence,and such
                                Conveyances to be valid, with an amendment to the following
                                effect:
                            SEC. 6. Patents for which issued by the United
                                States or by this State, and the certificates of parties to all
                                contracts may be recorded by the recorder of the county in which
                                such land is situated, and the record thereof may be readin evidence
                                with like effect as if such original instrument were produced.
                            The amendment was adopted and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                            By Mr. COLGROVE - Judiciary - returning Mr.
                                Hunter's bill (191) authorizing jurors to be summoned from an
                                adjoining county to try criminal causes in certain cases, and
                                recommending passage. 
                            The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                            By Mr. COLGROVE - Judiciary - returning the bill
                                (S. 17) to provide for the partition of real estate - laying the
                                same out in town lots, without amendment, and recommending passage.
                                The bill was ordered to the third reading.
                        
                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                            The SPEAKER announced the special order, viz: the consideration of
                                Mr. Colgrove's bills Nos 47, 55, 56re-organizing the Circuit Courts
                                giving probate jurisdiction to Clerks of the Circuit Courts,
                                prohibiting them from praticing law, &c.and repealing the act
                                establishing the Court Of Common Pleas.
                            Mr. COLGROVE. The three bills embrace a change in the judicial
                                system, and they are so inseparably connected, that one should not
                                be passed without the others, &c.
                            The House then resolved into Committe of the Whole
                                - Mr. Edwards in the chair - and took up and considered by sections,
                                the bill No. 47.
                            Mr. SHULL moved to amend the first section of the bill, by making the
                                number of the Circuits "20," instead of "30."
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush, proposed "25."
                            Mr. COLGROVE showed that doing away of the Court of Common Pleas,
                                induced as great a saving as was desirable: after that 30 circuits
                                would be necessary.
                            Mr. SHULL. Nothing but retrenchment would satisfy the people, and he
                                saw no retrenchment in this proposition.
                            The amendments were rejected.
                            The first section was then agreed to - affirmative 56, negative
                                32.
                            Mr. MELLETT, for a test, moved indefinite postponement of the
                                bill.
                            Mr. BOYD desired to see the Probate system abolished, but he could
                                not vote for 30 circuits. He never would vote for 30 circuits, so
                                long as the business could be as well done with a less number.
                            Mr. KEEFER was opposed to this whole system of bills. His
                                constituents had a good Common Pleas Judge.
                            Mr. Speaker GORDON spoke to the question of economy as to the number
                                of circuits. The business of his county was never done under the
                                present system. No system was complete which denied the
                                administration and ends of justice. When gentlemen in favor of
                                economy in our judicial system, vote against this on account of its
                                expensiveness, they voted against their own proposition.
                            Mr. COLGROVE was surprised at this hostile demonstration toward his
                                bills. On what he regarded as a test vote, during the extra session,
                                there were 81 affirmatives for this proposition. It was not
                                altogether his proposition. It had been forced in here by the
                                spontaneous demand of the people. He spoke here for the eastern part
                                of the State. He spoke of the importance of a healthy judicial
                                system, and showed the wisdom of maintaining its respectability. The
                                Common Pleas system - the offspring of our new Constitution - was
                                liable to the objections of expensiveness and inefficiency. There
                                were 44 Judges of Common Pleas, and fifteen circuits making 59
                                courts. This was a proposition to reduce the number of the Judges
                                and of circuits to thirty. He showed the history of these bills,
                                going back to the Legislature of 1857. The annual expensiveness of
                                the Common Pleas in 65 counties, as reported by the State Auditor,
                                for 1856, was $99,248 27. Adding his estimate for the remaining 26
                                counties, which failed to show their hands, the cost of the Common
                                Pleas for 1856 was $138,700. But, if it was not a suggestion of
                                economy, he would oppose the Common Pleas,as affording an unhealthy
                                facility for litigation. He compared the expensiveness of the two
                                systems, and showed the advantage on the side of his own. The
                                expensiveness of the judicial system was attributable to the number
                                of courts, and their attendant bailiffs, jurors, &c. The line of
                                jurisdiction between the Common Pleas and Circuit Courts had never
                                been settled; and one of the results of this was, that the Supreme
                                Court was overwhelmed with appeals, until now no man could go into
                                the Supreme Court with any reasonable expectation of getting through
                                in less than two or three years. He showed also, that less than 30
                                Judges could not do the judicial business of the State.
                            He rehearsed the provisions of the bill, No. 55, whice gave surrogate
                                powers to the Clerks of the Circuit Courts, saving cases and
                                questions in the partition and sale of real estate in which the
                                title to real estate may be put in issue. Such was the practice now,
                                in effect. This system had been maintained in the State of New York,
                                as long as he could remember. He should very much regret to see the
                                system fail for want of agreement as to the number of circuits.
                            Mr. NEBEKER of Warren. He belonged not to a profession claiming
                                exclusively the prerogative of regulating the judiciary; but he was
                                a tax-payer, and could look at the case through figures. The present
                                Common Pleas judge salaries was $35,000. He favored the proposition
                                in another bill, to reduce the number of Common Pleas judges. The
                                proposed reduction of these judges to 20, and the reduction of terms
                                proposed, would admit of raising the salaries of the Common Pleas
                                judges to $1,200, and then make a large saving above that which
                                could be obtained under the system of the gentleman from Randolph.
                                He replied at length to Mr. Colgrove. The gentleman had passed over
                                the cost of his surrogate system without estimates, and he supposed
                                that also must cost something.
                            
                            Mr. BAIRD was pledged to this change in our judicial system, and had
                                not withheld his hand in the committee from a due share of the work
                                which had produced these bills. He also plead for the proposition on
                                the score of economy, and gave examples. From the zeal with which
                                the gentleman from Warren had pitched into these bills, it would not
                                surprise him to learn that the gentleman himself desired a Common
                                Pleas judgeship, for this very desire for judgeships has originated
                                and continued this Common Pleas system. He expected to have
                                advocated here a pure surrogate system, but had yielded to the fact
                                that it would involve expense, and then, in some counties, there
                                could not be found men to accept the office.
                            Mr. SCOTT did not understand the people as asking to abolish the
                                Common Pleas. Change of laws on frivolous pretenses should be
                                avoided. There should be a necessity for it before we change an
                                established system. He believed the expense of the proposed system
                                of Circuit Courts would be greater than the present. The great end
                                of a system of courts should be the speedy administration af
                                justice. He gave examples. Almost all the collecting business was
                                done in the Common Pleas. The Court of Common Pleas was deemed a
                                Court of Justice in his region, not a mere place to multiply errors-
                                He deprecated change. On this subject, if on any, he was a
                                conservative. He would go for reducing the number of the Common
                                Pleas districts.
                            Mr. GRIFFIN. There was a just gradation in our courts. The business
                                of the Common Pleas Court was necessarily more tardy than in the
                                Circuit Court, and less satisfactory; and as there was no appeal to
                                the Circuit Court, the eases of error had to go to the Supreme
                                Court, and so that docket was crowded beyond reason. He reasoned at
                                length in favor of the proposed system, giving examples.
                            Mr. COLGROVE indicated his willingness to accept of the compromise of
                                25 for the number circuits.
                            Mr. MELLETT had moved postponement, to test the sense of the House on
                                the system. But he was willing to withdraw for the compromise of the
                                friends of the bill.
                            Mr. MURRAY was not satisfied that the proposed system would save
                                anything. He reviewed the argument for the proposed change. It was
                                that the Common Pleas had leather-headed judges. Such an argument,
                                if admitted, would abolish every office in the State, and the
                                Legislature besides.
                            On motion by Mr. Speaker GORDON, the committee reconsidered the vote
                                agreeing to the first section, and adopted the following amendment,
                                striking out "30" and inserting "25" circuits.
                            Mr. HARNEY moved, now, that the committee rise and recommend the
                                indefinite postponement of the bill No. 47.
                            Mr. AUSTIN moved to amend that the committee rise and ask to be
                                discharged from the consideration of the subject.
                            The latter motion was agreed to; so the committee rose, the chairman
                                reported and the committee were discharged accordingly.
                            Mr. HARNEY moved indefinite postponement of the bill.
                            Mr. AUSTIN, though opposed to the abolition of the Common Pleas
                                Court, should also vote against postponement, because he was
                                unwilling to repress debate and investigation of the subject.
                            Mr. Harney's motion was lost by the following vote:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Black, Bowman, Boxley,
                                            Carr, Collier, Comstock, Durham, Gifford, Gregory,
                                            Harney. Hartley, Jones, Jordan, Knowlton, Lawhead,
                                            Lewis, McLain, Mellett, Murray, Nebeker of Vermillion,
                                            Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, Parrett, Ritter, Scott, Smith
                                            of Perry, Snyder, Stanfield, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of
                                            Elkhart, Wheeler, Whiteman and Wood - 34.

                                        NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Baird, Boyd,
                                            Branham, Brotherton, Cavins, Clark, Clayton, Colgrove,
                                            Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Devol, Early, Edwards, Fordyce,
                                            Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Wayne,
                                            Harrison, Jeffries, Kelly, Kempf, Major, Mansfield,
                                            Massey, Merrifield, Martin, Robinson, Row, ShieIds,
                                            Shockley, Shull Smith of Miami, Sullivan, Treadway,
                                            Waterman, Whetzel,Wildman and Mr. Speaker-41.
                                    
                                
                            
                            The bill was then ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. Colgrove's bill (55), giving Circuit Court Clerks probate
                                jurisdiction, prohibiting Clerks and their deputies from practicing
                                law, &c., coming up - 

                             Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, called for the yeas and nays on the question
                                of engrossment, and desired a test of the system.
                            Mr. COLGROVE said this bill was not hos. tile to the Common Pleas. It
                                was a mere relief of that Court, and a cheapening and simplification
                                of the probate businessa mere authorization of practice now, in most
                                cases in the State.
                            The bill was ordered to be engrossed - yeas 44, nays 28.
                            Mr. Colgrove's bill, No. 56, abolishing the Common Pleas, coming up - 
                            Mr. HARNEY asserted the popular approval of the Common Pleas Court in
                                his county, and believed this was the case wherever they had good
                                Judges. The establishment of this Court had stimulated the Circuit
                                Courts to a commendable zeal in working up their dockets; and he
                                reasoned briefly In favor of continuance of the Common Pleas, which
                                he believed had given all the satisfaction expected by its original
                                friends. He would not be willing to forego its advantages for its
                                alledged expensiveness.
                            Mr. COLGROVE replied, pleading for engrossment now, and a test vote
                                with a full House to-morrow.
                            The bill was then ordered to be engrossed.
                            The SPEAKER laid before the House the petition of citizens of the
                                State, asking for a law requiring preferment of graduates of the
                                blind school amongst applicants for employment therein, which was
                                referred to the Committee on Benevolent
                                    Institutions.
                            Mr. KNOWLTON presented the memorial of the Cass county and Eel River
                                Seminary Society, asking for an amendment of charter, which was
                                referred to the Judiciary Committee.
                            Mr. JORDAN presented the petition of Daniel Arloy, against the
                                ravages of dogs, which was ruled out of order, it being addressed to
                                the Honorable Harry Jordan, instead of the General Assembly.
                            The House then (at 5 o'clock) adjourned.
                        
                    
                    
                    
                    
                         IN SENATE.
                        
                             TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1859. 
                        
                        
                            PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
                            Mr. CONNER presented a petition from certain citizens of Wabash
                                county, with reference to the Wabash and Erie Canal; which was laid
                                on the table.
                            Mr. HAMILTON presented a memorial from certain citizens of Allen
                                county, on the same subject; which was also laid on the table.
                        
                        
                            REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                             Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee, turned
                                his bill (188), recommending its passage. The report was concurred
                                in, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. HENDRY, from the same committee, turned a resolution of inquiry
                                upon the question of authorizing County Auditors to sell mortgaged
                                lands for the nonpayment of principal and interest due on school
                                funds; recommending that no further legislation be had on the
                                subject. The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. CONNER, from the same committee, returned Mr. Green's bill (202),
                                recommending its passage. The bill was ordered engrossed.
                            Mr. BENNETT, from the same committee, returned Mr. Conley's bill
                                (176), recommending its passage. The bill was ordered to be
                                engrossed.
                            Mr. MURRAY, from the same committee, returned Mr. Hill's bill (155),
                                recommending its passage. The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. HEFFREN, from the same committee, returned his bill (165),
                                recommending its passage. The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. BLAIR, from the Committee on County and Township Business,
                                returned the bill (H. R. 48) to amend the 6th section of an act to
                                provide for the organization of County Boards, &c., approved
                                June 17, 1852, recommending its passage.
                            On motion by Mr. BEESON, the bill was read the third time and finally
                                passed the Senate yeas 41, nays 0.
                            Mr. WILSON, from the committee on the State Library, returned Mr.
                                Gooding'sbill (138), recommending its passage. The bill was ordered
                                to be engrossed.
                            Mr. SLACK, from a select committee, returned Mr. Cobb's bill (151),
                                with an amendment recommending its passage. The bill was ordered to
                                be engrossed.
                            Mr. GOODING, by leave, from the committee on the Judiciary Committee,
                                returned the bill (H. R. 29), to license, regulate and restrain the
                                sale of spirituous liquors, recommending its passage.
                            Mr. SLACK moved to strike out all in the first section that refers to
                                vinous and malt liquors.
                            Mr. MURRAY moved to lay on the table.
                            The motion was agreed to, by yeas 20, nays 19, as follows:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson,
                                            Bennett, Blair, Cooper, Cravens, Culver, Green, Hendry,
                                            Hill, Kinley, McLean, March, Murray, Odell, Stevens,
                                            Thompson, Turner wagner and Wilson - 20.
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Brown, Carnahan, Cobb,
                                            Conley, Fisk, Gooding, Hamilton, Hargrove, Heffren,
                                            Johnston, Line, Lomax, McClure, Miller, O'Brien, Slack,
                                            Tarkington, Wallace and Williams - 19.
                                    
                                
                            
                            On motion by Mr. HENDRY, a call of the Senate was had.
                            Mr. JOHNSTON moved a substitute, which strikes out from the enacting
                                clause and inserts an entire new bill.
                            The substitute was read, when - 
                            Mr. GOODING rose to a personal explanation.
                            The PRESIDENT pro tempore interrupted him by saying
                                that there was a special order for this hour [10 o'clock], being the
                                consideration of the Committee on County and Township
                                    Business' bill (145), to provide for a more uniform
                                mode of doing: township business.
                            Mr. SLACK moved to postpone the special order.
                            The PRESIDENT pro tempore. The Senate will decide
                                whether the Senator shall rise to a privileged question.
                            The question was submitted to the Senate by the Chair, and the Senate
                                decided upon a division - affirmative 15, negative 12 - that Mr.
                                Gooding was in order, and should have leave to proceed.
                            Mr. GOODING. Mr. President: I find published in the >Sentinel of this morning an account of a very
                                disagreable difficulty that occurred a few days since between the
                                Senator from Washington [Mr. Heffren] and myself, in which that
                                Senator is reported to have said some things that I do not think he
                                said, and other things which he ought not to have said.
                            Mr. WAGNER, [interrupting.] Mr. President: Must these things continue
                                the whole entire time of this session? I protest against it.
                            Mr. GOODING. No sir. It will end now.
                            Mr. HEFFREN. It may, and it may not. It may, and it may not.
                            Mr. MARCH. I don't suppose it's any body's business whether it closes
                                now or not.
                            Mr. WAGNER. I object to pressing these matters on the time of the
                                Senate.
                            Mr. GOODING. If I have permission I will read what the Senator from
                                Washington is reported to have said. It is as follows:"
                            
                                I have heretofore time and
                                        again branded that Senator as a liar and a coward; I have
                                    denounced him upon this floor as a rascal, a lying,
                                        croaking villain, and he has not had manliness enough
                                    to resist it. He cannot now force me to be the assailant by any
                                    such language as he is now using, or can use. I will not notice
                                    one so lost to all honor as to coolly and calmly and cowardly pocket insults in the manner he does. He is a
                                        cowardly dog."
                            
                            This, Mr. President, is the language he is reported as having used. I
                                now ask that Senator if he used that language?
                            Mr. HEFFREN. I repeat every word that is there that you have read. I
                                know he has a pistol, Mr. President, I have seen him march in here
                                with it; but I am not to be cowed - [cries of "order," "order."]
                            Mr. GOODING. I say if he makes these statements and indorses them as
                                true, I hurl - 
                            [Hereupon Mr. Heffren, who had previously placed himself near to Mr.
                                Gooding, seemed to strike at him violently with his hand; and the
                                two engaged, oversetting chairs and disturbing the table of this
                                Reporter. Senators then immediately interfered, together with
                                parties outside.

                            
                            While Mr. Heffren was punishing one of the interfering parties, a
                                brother of M . Gooding, as it has been represented, advanced and
                                gave him a full blow with a cane on the back of his head, and then
                                retreated from the chamber.]
                            Pending these things - 
                            The PRESIDENT, pro tempore prorogued the session
                                till 2 o'clock.
                        
                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                             Mr. TURNER offered the following:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That no Senator shall be
                                            permitted, while in the Senate Chamber, or going to or
                                            returning from the same, to carry on or about his person
                                            any dirk, pistol, or any other deadly weapon, and any
                                            member violating this rule shall, on motion, be expelled
                                            from this Senate.
                                    
                                
                            
                            Senator Heffren and Senator Gooding apologized to the Senate for
                                their breach of decorum.
                            Mr. SLACK moved to lay the resolution on the table.
                            The motion was agreed to - yeas 30, nays 9.
                            Mr. STEVENS offered the following:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        WHEREAS, Hon. Horace Heffren, a
                                            Senator from the county of Washington, and Hon. D. S.
                                            Gooding, a Senator from the counties of Hancock and
                                            Shelby, did, this forenoon, while the Senate was in
                                            regular session, greatly to the annoyance, peace and
                                            quiet of the Senate, and to the honor and dignity of the
                                            State, engage in a personal combat, contrary to the laws
                                            of the State of Indiana; and, whereas, believing this
                                            Senate is bound to maintain honor and dignity in its
                                            organization, therefore
                                        Resolved, That a committee of five be
                                            appointed to investigate the matter of difficulty
                                            between the honorable Senators named in the preamble,
                                            and report to this Senate what course is necessary to
                                            take to vindicate the honor and dignity of the Senate.
                                        
                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. Slack opposed and Mr. Murray favored the adoption of the
                                resolution.
                            Mr. Murray offered the following as a substitute:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        WHEREAS, a rencounter occurred this
                                            morning, on the floor of the Senate, between the Hons.
                                            Horace Heffren and David S. Gooding, members of the
                                            Senate, disgraceful to the Senate, and to its great
                                            disturbance, therefore
                                        Resolved, That a select committee of
                                            five be appointed by the Senate to investigate the facts
                                            of the case, and report to the Senate what action is
                                            necessary and proper, and whether others interfered and
                                            participated, not members of the Senate, and what action
                                            is necessary so far as they are concerned, and that said
                                            committee have power to send for persons and papers, and
                                            if deemed necessary, employ a clerk. 
                                    
                                
                            
                             The resolution was debated by Senators March, Wallace, Hamilton,
                                Greene, Bennett, Tarkington, Wagner and Robinson.
                            Mr. SLACK moved to lay the whole subject on the table.
                            The motion was rejected - yeas 7, nays 36.
                            Mr. STEVENS could see but little distinction between the original
                                resolution and the substitute.
                            He therefore accepted of the substitute.
                            The resolution was then adopted, and the following Senators were
                                designated by the Senate as the committee, viz: Senators Wallace,
                                Stevens, Murray, Rice and Tarkington.
                            Mr. HAMILTON, by consent, offered the following, which was
                                adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved, That the use of the Senate
                                            Chamber be given this evening to citizens of the State
                                            who desire to revive the Indiana Historical Society
                                            established in the year 1830.
                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. HARGROVE offered the following, which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the Treasurer of State be
                                            directed to report to the Senate at his earliest
                                            convenience the amount of moneys received into the State
                                            Treasury from the General Government for sales of swamp
                                            lands erroneously sold by the Government; by whom paid
                                            in; the time of payment; if disbursed, the objects of
                                            such disbursement and if known, the amount of such sales
                                            remaining due from the General Government. 
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. SLACK offered the following, which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the Auditor of State is
                                            required to communicate to this Senate the state of the
                                            accounts between the State of Indiana and Governor
                                            Wright; also, between the State and Elijah Newland, and
                                            John P.Dunn, late Treasurer and Auditor of State, as to
                                            the amount of money which came into their hands,
                                            belonging to the Swamp Land Fund, and the disposition
                                            made thereof, and what amount if any, is yet due from
                                            either of said officers.
                                    
                                
                            
                             Mr. WALLACE offered the following, which was adopted:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        Resolved,That the President of the
                                            Senate be requested to submit to the Senate any
                                            communication he may have from the General Land Office,
                                            relative to the receipts and expenditures of funds due
                                            the State, arising from the Swamp Lands.
                                    
                                
                            
                            The Committee on County and Township Business'
                                bill (145) for a more uniform mode of doing township business coming
                                up, the question being on a motion of the Senator from Washington,
                                to reconsider the vote by which the Senate refused to adopt the
                                substitute for the bill proposed by the Senator from Union - 
                            Mr. HEFFREN withdrew his motion.
                            Mr. SLACK renewed it.
                            Mr. HEFFRFN moved to lay the motion on the table.
                            The motion was agreed to - yeas 25, nays 23.
                            Mr. WALLACE moved to strike out all that part of the bill which gives
                                Trustees the powers of a Justice of the Peace.
                            The motion was agreed to.
                            On motion by Mr. WILLIAMS, the bill was read the third time.
                            Mr. LINE moved to recommit so as to give the Trustee power to vacate
                                and lay out roads and highways in the townships according to the
                                provisions of law in that case made and provided.
                            Mr. WALLACE moved to lay the motion on the table.
                            The motion was agreed to - yeas 31, nays 16.
                            Mr. GREEN moved that the provision which requires the trustee to keep
                                an office open for the transaction of township business, be stricken
                                out.
                            There being objection made the motion was ruled out of order.
                            Mr. BENNETT moved to recommit with instructions to take away from the
                                trustee the duty of acting as treasurer, and that the money shall be
                                disbursed by the County Treasurer upon the order of the trustee.
                            On motion by Mr. CONLEY, the motion to recommit was laid on the
                                table.
                            The bill was then finally passed the Senate by yeas 30, nays 18.

                            
                                TEMPERANCE BILL.
                                The temperance bill (H. R. 29) coming up, the question being on
                                    the adoption of a substitute proposed by the Senator from Putnam
                                    [Mr. Johnston.]
                                Mr. BENNETT moved to lay the substitute on the table.
                                The motion was agreed to - yeas 28, nays 13.
                                Mr. BENNETT moved to amend by striking out the words, "or to any
                                    female ;" also, to strike out $20 and insert $50.
                                
                                Mr. MURRAY hoped the bill would be put on its passage. He moved
                                    to lay the amendments on the table.
                                The motion was rejected - yeas 16, nays 27.
                                And then the Senate adjourned.
                            
                        
                    
                    
                    
                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
                        
                            
                                TUESDAY, February 15, 1859.
                            
                        
                        
                            PETITIONS.
                            By Mr. MURRAY: of Francis Henry and others, citizens of Lagrange
                                county, against the repeal of the horse thief detecting law, and
                                presenting claims for money expended. &c., which was referred to
                                the Committee on Claims.
                            By the SPEAKER: the claim of C. C. Campbell of Indianapolis, which
                                was referred to the Committee on Claims.
                        
                        
                            REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                            By Mr. STANFIELD - Judiciary - returning Mr.
                                Whetzel's bill (98), to amend the supervisor's act of June 18, 1852,
                                with the expression of opinion that the bill is unconstitutional and
                                inexpedient, and recommending indefinite postponement.
                            Also - returning the bill (S. 8), to amend the first section of the
                                act concerning the alienation of real estate, &c., stating that
                                the bill proposes to amend the law so that all aliens - Africans
                                included - shall have the right to purchase, sell or take by descent
                                any real property in this State, and they recommended its indefinite
                                postponement.
                            These reports were concurred in.
                            He also returned Mr. Hunter's bill (125), for the protection of
                                railroad tracks, inserting - 
                            SEC. 3. Any person who shall wilfully or
                                negligently leave upon any railroad track anything to endanger the
                                train, shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than $5, nor more
                                than $1,000, to which may be added imprisonment not exceeding six
                                months.
                            The amendment was adopted, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                            By Mr. TURPIE - Judiciary - returning Mr. Early's
                                bill (72), to amend sections 1 and 2 of the act of March 1, 1853,
                                providing compensation for animals killed by railroad cars, with an
                                amendment striking out the words, "at any one time."
                            On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, the bill and amendment were referred to Mr.
                                Edwards and 4 others.
                        
                        
                            GAME LAW.
                            By Mr. DAVIS - Judiciary - returning Mr. Hamilton
                                of Boone's bill (64), amending, and Mr. Turpie's bill (18),
                                repealing the game law, with sundry petitions on that subject,
                                recommending that No. 64 and the petitions be laid on the table, and
                                that No. 18 be amended by substitute.
                            Mr. TURPIE demanded the yeas and nays on concurrence.
                            Mr. DAVIS stated the effect of the amendment of the game law
                                proposed. It is provided that any man may kill game at any time on
                                his own premises; it repeals the clause giving half to the informer,
                                and extends the time of general killing from the 1st of January till
                                the 15th day of February.
                            Mr. TURPIE and Mr. BOYD were in favor of repealing the game law, but
                                should vote for the report, as perhaps the best they could get
                            The vote on concurrence stood - yeas 36, nays 46.
                            So the House refused to concur; and the question recurred on the
                                engrossment of the original bill, No. 18, (Mr. Turpie's) to repeal
                                the game law of February 26,1857.
                            Mr. TURPIE moved, that Mr. Hamilton of Boone's bill be laid on the
                                table.
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone. The House has just refused to lay the bill on
                                the table, in refusing to concur in the report.
                            Mr. DAVIS moved recommitment, ineffectually.
                            The question recurring on the engrossment of No. 18 - 
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY moved its indefinite postponement - the vote resulting,
                                yeas 46, nays 43 - as follows:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Austin, Baird, Black,
                                            Branham, Brotherton, Clark, Claypool, Clayton, Colgrove,
                                            Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Dougherty, Durham,
                                            Edwards, Fordyce, Gregory, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush,
                                            Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison, Jeffries, Johnston, Keefer,
                                            Lawhead, Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Merrifield, Miller,
                                            Murray, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren,
                                            Robinson, Scott, Sherman, Smith of Miami, Snyder,
                                            Stanfield, Stiles, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway,
                                            Waterman and Whiteman - 46.
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Blythe, Bowman, Boyd,
                                            Boxley, Carr, Cavins, Clements, Collier, Devol, Early,
                                            Eastham, Firestone, Gifford, Hamilton of Boone, Harnev,
                                            Hartley, Hunter, Jones, Jordan, Kelly, Kempf, Knowlton,
                                            Lewis, McLain, Massey, Martin, Nelson, Newton, Prosser,
                                            Ritter, Row, Rynerson, Shields, Shockley, Shull, Smith
                                            of Perry, Stanley, Summers, Turpie, Usrey, Wheeler,
                                            Whetzel, Wildman and Wood - 43.
                                    
                                
                            
                             So the bill was postponed.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY moved to reconsider this vote - and that motion was
                                laid on the table, by yeas 43, nays 46.
                            The bill No 64, to prevent the killing, &c. saving the right of
                                farmers on their own premises, and repealing the compensation of
                                inlormers, &c., was then ordered to be engrossed.

                            Which was adopted, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
