                        IN SENATE
                        
                             SATURDAY, February 19, 1859. 
                        
                        On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the reading of the journal was dispensed
                            with.
                        
                            REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                            Mr. McLEAN, from the Judiciary Committee, returned Mr. Shoemaker's
                                bill 198, recommencing that it lie on the table.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            M. HENDRY, from the same committee returned the bill H. R. 79,
                                recommending indefinite postponement.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. COBB, from the same committee, returned his bill 206,
                                recommending its passage.
                            The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be
                                engrossed.
                            Mr HEFFREN from the same committee, returned the bill H. R. 95,
                                recommending indefinite postponement.
                        
                        
                             COMMON PLEAS COURT.
                             Mr. MARCH, fiom the same committee, returned his bill 164, to
                                enlarge the jurisdiction of the Court of Common Pleas, recommending
                                its passage.
                            Mr. HEFFREN hoped the report would not concurred in. He was opposed
                                to the whole system of Common Pleas Courts.
                            Mr. ANTHONY was opposed to the recommendation that the bill pass.
                            Mr. BENNETT was in favor of the final abolishment of the Common Pleas
                                system, and opposed to the report of the committee.
                            Mr. MARCH sustained the report of the committee and urged the
                                adoption of his bill.
                            Mr. GREEN thought it humbuggery to talk about abolishing the Court of
                                Common Pleas and having only one court.
                            Mr. McLEAN had before expressed himself as in favor of abolishing the
                                Common Pleas Court. He was in favor of the bill, and consequently in
                                favor of concurring in the report of the committee.
                            Mr. SLACK moved to concur, with the following amendment: strike out
                                ot section 1 the words "actions on the official bond of any State or
                                county officer."
                            Mr BENNETT moved to lay the report, with the pending amendment, on
                                the table.
                            The motion was rejected - yeas 11, nays 31.
                            The motion to concur in the report, with the amendment, was agreed
                                to.
                            
                            The bill was then ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. TARKINGTON made an ineffectual motion to reconsider the vote by
                                which the bill H R. 95 was indefinitely postponed.
                            Mr. ANTHONY from the same committee returned the bill H. R. 147,
                                enabling corporations to reduce the amount of their capital stock
                                &c., recommending its passage.
                            Mr. WILSON moved to postpone the consideration of the bill and report
                                till Tuesday, 10 o'clock.
                            Senators Anthony and McLean were opposed to the postponement, and
                                urged the passage o the bill now.
                            Mr. JONES explained the object of the postponement.
                            The motion was agreed to.
                        
                        
                            THE TEMPERANCE BILL.
                            Mr. GOODING moved to suspend the regular order of business in order
                                to take up the House temperance bill (29) and vote upon it.
                            The motion was agreed to - yeas 25, nays 23.
                            Mr. GOODING demanded the previous question, and, there being a
                                second, the main question was ordered. A constitutional provision
                                demanding the yeas and nays, they were ordered and being taken,
                                resulted - yeas 26, nays 20 - as follows:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson,
                                            Bennett, Carnahan Cobb, Cooper, Cravens, Culver,
                                            Gooding, Green, Hamilton, Hendry, Jones, McLean, Murray,
                                            Odell, Bice, Robinson, Steele, Stevens, Studabaker,
                                            Tarkington, Thompson, Wagner, Williams and Wilson -
                                            26.
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Blair, Brown, Conner,
                                            Craven, Fisk, Hargrove, Heffren, Hill, Jennings,
                                            Johnston, Kinley, Line, Lomax, McOlure, March, O'Brien,
                                            Shoemaker Slack, Turner and Wallace - 20.
                                        Messrs. Bobbs and Miller refused to vote.
                                    
                                
                            
                            Mr. BENNETT makes the following explanation of his vote:
                            Mr. President - The peculiar position which I occupy as a Senator on
                                this floor, in reference to the temperance question, makes it
                                necessary for me to give an explanation for the vote I shall give on
                                the bill now before the Senate. I represent a district of temperance
                                men. No counties in the State are more anxious for a constitutional
                                and effective temperance law, than Fayette and Union. And as their
                                representative, I should prove recreant to my duty, were I to spire
                                any exertion to secure the passage of such a law. I have said on
                                this floor and elsewhere that I did not think I ever could vote for
                                any law which recognizes the license system. I am utterly opposed to
                                the principle of licensing an acknowledged evil. I have regarded
                                drunkenness a great moral, social and political evil. I believe it
                                the source of crime, and the enemy of all good government. I have
                                believed as a lawyer, that the people through their legislatures,
                                had a right to prevent these evils, by removing the cause thereof. I
                                have never been able to arrive at that high degree of legal
                                knowledge which affects to discover in the organic law of the State
                                a principle which by any possible construction, would restrain this
                                necessary power of the people. My law books teach me that the power
                                of protecting society from evils, by removing the causes thereof, is
                                as old as civilization itself, and never doubted save where whisky
                                is in controversy. The power to protect rights and to prohibit
                                wrongs, is the primary object of law. I have not thus far in my
                                legal researches, been able to discover the nice technical
                                distinctions which some courts and politicians seem to have
                                discovered between the evils which flow from intemperance and those
                                from any other source, the well written opinion of our own Supreme
                                Court to the contrary notwithstanding. I have in all the preliminary
                                votes taken on this question in the Senate, during this and the
                                extra session, voted against the license system. But, sir, I am
                                satified from the many test vote which have bee taken here, and in
                                the other end of the Capitol that no other law can bo passed. I am
                                also satisfied that such a law as my constituents would prefer,
                                would be destroyed by the Supreme Court and at present constituted.
                                I am very anxious to have some law on the subject, and believe that
                                the bill now before the Senate, with the Senate amendments, will, in
                                such counties as I represent have the effect of suppressing the
                                evil. It hagf many provisions which will prove efficient and produce
                                good results, and while it may not kill the "monster," it will do
                                him great bodily harm. As legislators, we must compromise our
                                differences, for the public good. Therefore, protesting against the
                                license system, believing the bill a step in the right direction,
                                and as a dernier resort, I vote "aye."
                            Mr. BOBBS makes the following explanation to-wit : He expressed
                                himself against the bill for the following reasons. In the first
                                place he was opposed to any license law, out particularly to this
                                one, because it allowed a discrimination between the fashionable
                                saloon, and the less pretentious places of drinking. The County
                                Commissioners may not choose to exercise this power of
                                discrimination, it is true, but if they should not, it is not
                                because this bill does not allow them that privilege. Some Senators,
                                I believe, support this bill expressly on the grounds that, it would
                                allow the Commissioners, by the maximum license permitted, to
                                suppress the sale of ardent spirits in their counties. And in my
                                county, the largest saloons can afford to pay the highest license,
                                if by that, they can shut out all competition in the traffic.
                                Whether they so regard it, I do not pretend to know, but that they
                                would find it to their interest to do so, can hardly be denied. Just
                                in proportion to the amount of be paid for license required by this
                                bill, will the smaller groceries be closed and those remaining lave
                                a larger field for operations. And if the maximum, price of a
                                license should be required, reduces the traffic to a monopoly in the
                                hands of a few who can afford to advance the amount of license. If
                                the sale of intoxicating liquors is to be restricted at all, that
                                restriction should operate alike upon all, and not discriminate in
                                favor of those who can afford to indulge in this luxury, and against
                                those who can not afford this. My constituents are divided in
                                opinion upon the subject of the principle upon which a temperance
                                law should be based, and I am left without any instruction of their
                                wishes upon the present bill. As I believe this bill does not
                                reflect the wishes of a majority of my constituents, I decline to
                                vote for it.
                            Mr. CULVER makes the following explanation of his vote:
                            
                            No legislation can come before this body that will be of so much
                                general importance to the people as the subject matter contained in
                                this bill. It will affect for good or ill,directly or in directly,
                                the welfare of every family in this State. The evil that this
                                legislation proposes to remedy has often been the subject of
                                legislation. We have had prohibition, that has been decidedly
                                unconstitutional. Whether that decision was right or wrong, we have
                                not the power, by legislation, to overturn its decrees. As we can
                                not make a prohibitory law, the only practical question is, shall we
                                have a pay license or simply a bond to keep an orderly house,
                                &c. Between these two systems, I am for the former, believing
                                that the ends to be gained will plead a justification ol the means
                                used. I look upon the House bill as imperfect in many of its
                                details. Yet at this late day of the session, unless we take that
                                bill and pass it without loading it down with material amendments,
                                we will get no law upon this subject. I do not like this bill; the
                                latitude given in the amount of the license, and I vote for it
                                without a change, believing that an amendment would be fatal to the
                                bill in the other end of the capitol. This is so regarded by its
                                friends there This kind of legislation, to be beneficial, ought to
                                be kept clear of party. We ought to have a law that can not be
                                charged as the exclusive act of any faction. This can only be done
                                by mutual concession by the different elements that we have upon
                                this floor in regard to this question. I hope that this law, if it
                                passes, may be the means of suppressing intemperance. The few
                                extreme temperance men ought to know, that oppose this bill, that
                                this is the most stringent law that can pass. As a friend of a
                                stringent law, I vote for this - not with my entire approval, but as
                                a compromise.
                            Mr. HILL makes the following explanation of his vote:
                            It is, in my opinion, and in the opinion of many of the most
                                intelligent of my constituents, wrong in principle for the State to
                                license men to deal out to our people intoxicating liquors, the
                                effects of which are too well known and felt to need enumeration
                                here. The law, as I understand it, allows any person without
                                license, and without giving bond and security, to sell as much
                                intoxicating liquor as they choose in any quantity not less than one
                                gallon. The law, therefore, in my opinion, will be absolutely
                                worthless in protecting us against the evils of intemperance; and as
                                it involves a principle that I do not wish to sanction, I vote
                                no.
                            Mr. ODELL makes the following explanation of his vote:
                            Mr. President - I vote for this bill, not because I approve of all of
                                its provisions, but because there is now no law on that subject; as
                                it is a conceded fact that there will be no law passed this session,
                                unless this bill shall pass, and as I prefer it to no law at all on
                                that subject.
                            Mr. STEVENS makes the following explanation of his vote:
                            Mr. President - I shall vote for the bill now on its passage, not
                                that I indorse the principle of license, but for the reason that I
                                am convinced that if it fails, no other can be passed at the present
                                session of the General Assembly. I feel,then, that I am compelled to
                                take this or no law at all, and believing that if the provisions of
                                this act are enforced, and the County Commissioners reflect, in
                                their action, the sentiments of the people on the subject, that in
                                the county I represent, and in more than half the counties in the
                                State it will amount to a prohibitory law. I am aware that the
                                temperance people of the State, are opposed to the license system;
                                so am I, but the question now before me is, shall I vote I for the
                                bill which authorizes license, or against it and have no law at all;
                                in this dilemma I have no hesitancy.
                            Mr. WAGNER makes the following explanation for his vote:
                            Mr. President - I wish to say, sir, that this bill is not such a one
                                as I would like; but, sir, my constituents wish some kind of a law,
                                and the question is whether this law is the best one that might be
                                passed. I admit that the principle of a license law is wrong - the
                                State ought not to be a party to such a traffic - but, as under the
                                Constitution, as decided by our courts, we can not prohibit the
                                traffic altogether, we must do the best we can, and believing that
                                if we do not pass a license law we will pass none this session, and
                                believing further that my people desire some kind of a temperance
                                law, I will vote for this bill. But while I do this let me say it is
                                with great reluctance. So the bill passed.

                        
                        
                            WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
                            Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee,returned
                                Mr. Conner's bill (201) on the Wabash and Erie Canal, recommending
                                its passage.
                            Mr. CARNAHAN moved to concur in the report, with an amendment
                                striking out the 5th section: [releasing the trustees from
                                maintaining bridges across the Canal.]
                            Mr. MURRAY objected to the amendment.
                            [A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of
                                the bill (S, 145) to provide for a more uniform mode of doing
                                township business.]
                            Mr. McLEAN opposed the amendment. He thought the interests of the
                                State demanded some legislation on the subject.
                            Mr. STEELE said this bill was the only plan that could be agreed upon
                                by Senators along its line. He would not vote a dollar from the
                                State Treasury, but was willing to release the trustees from keeping
                                up the bridges, and allow them to be kept up by the townships in
                                which they lie. He should vote for the bill.
                            Mr. HAMILTON feared the adoption of the amendment would be fatal to
                                the Canal. He trusted the bill would pass.
                            Mr. WALLACE intended to oppose this bill; desired time for further
                                consideration, but proceeded to discuss and explain his objections
                                thereto He regarded this bill as the entering wedge to the taking
                                back of this Canal.
                            On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the further consideration of the matter was
                                postponed till Monday night at 7 o'clock.
                            On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, his bill (23) fixing the time of holding
                                the Courts of Common Pleas in Adams county, was read the third time,
                                and passed the Senate by yeas 43, nays 0.
                            Mr. RICE, from the Judiciary Committee, re-  turned Mr Cooper's bill (189)
                                recommending that it lie on the table. The report was concurred
                                in.
                        
                        
                            BANK OF THE STATE OF INDIANA.
                             Mr. STEELE, from the Committee on Banks returned
                                Mr. Odell's bill (122) taxing the Bank of the State of Indiana and
                                its branches, and prohibiting said bank from issuing on deposits
                                recommending its passage.
                            Mr. MARCH moved to amend by striking out section - and inserting in
                                lieu thereof the following:
                            The capital stock of said bank, together with the amount of its
                                circulation over and above the amount of its capital stock, ami its
                                real estate and other property shall ba subject to the same rate of
                                taxation for State, county and municipal purposes, as the property
                                of individuals.
                            Mr. MARCH could not see why this bank should not be taxed for its
                                capital stock and its circulation over and above the amount of
                                capital stock paid in. Unless that bank is so taxed it has a decided
                                advantage over individuals.
                            Mr. STEELE believed the bank ought to be taxed as individuals or
                                other institutions are taxed.
                            Mr. MURRAY thought we had a right to make the bank law conform to the
                                general law upon the subject of taxation.
                            Mr. WALLACE and Mr. TARINGTON each were heard in a few remarks.
                            [On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, Mr. Stevens' bill 192, was taken irom the
                                table and placed on the file of the Senate.]
                            The amendment was then adopted - yeas 31, nays 7.
                            Mr. SLACK moved to strike out the preamble.
                            [Mr. GOODING obtained leave of absence till Monday, 2 o'clock p.
                                m.]
                            The motion was adopted - yeas 27, nays 9.
                            The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. MURRAY made an ineffectual attempt to refer the bill to a select
                                committee of five.
                        
                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                             Mr. STEELE, from the Committee on Banks returned Mr. Hargrove's bill
                                (93), recommending indefinite postponement.
                            Mr. WILLIAMS moved to reconsider the vote by which Mr. Odell's bill
                                (122) was ordered to be engrossed.
                            The motion was agreed to.
                            On motion by Mr. BOBBS, the bill was referred to Messrs. Bobbs,
                                Williams and Steele.

                            
                                BANK OF THE STATE OF INDIANA.
                                Mr. WAGNER, from the Committee on Banks,
                                    returned his bill (187), creating six additional bank districts,
                                    recommending its passage[Senators March and Jennings
                                    dissenting.]
                                Mr. HENDRY moved to concur with the following amendment: "insert
                                    that the books shall be kept open for thirty days."
                                Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend the amendment by adding "that the
                                    stock shall be divided in proportion to the amount of stock
                                    subscribed; and that the books shall be kept open from 9 o'clock
                                    to 12 o'clock."
                                Mr. HENDRY accepted.
                                The report and amendment were concurred in.
                                Mr. MARCH moved to amend the 15th section of the charter by
                                    adding his amendment to the bill (122) as printed above; and the
                                    9lst section, as follows:
                                 The Legislature may at any time alter or repeal this act, but
                                    said bank, or any of its branches, shall not be authorized by
                                    any amendment to suspend or refuse the payment of specie, for
                                    its notes, bills or obligation, or for a money received on
                                    deposite, and the faith of the State is hereby pledged that no
                                    such amendment shall ever be made.
                                SEC. The power given by this act to establish
                                    additional branches of said Bank of the State, is made upon the
                                    express condition precedent, that said bank accept the
                                    amendments to its charter in the manner prescribed in the said
                                    91st section of its original charter.
                                Mr. MARCH could not consent to extend its branches, unless the
                                    bank should be placed under the control of the Legislature.
                                Mr. HAMILTON said it was not he desire of the bank that, this
                                    increase should be made.
                                Mr. HEFFREN was in favor of taxing this bank the same as
                                    individuals are taxed; but thought the amendment was asking more
                                    than the bank was willing to concede, and we would consequently
                                    get nothing. He was willing to compromise, but was forninst giving the bank any more previleges than it
                                    has.
                                Mr. WAGNER thought the State should do justice to the portions of
                                    the State which have not had branches located in them; and to
                                    accommodate these people this bill was intended. He moved to
                                    make this subject the special order for Monday at 3 o'clock.
                                The motion was agreed to
                            
                            
                                LIABILITY OF RAILROADS.
                                Mr. CRAVEN; from the select committee, thereon, returned his bill
                                    [?]45, with amendments recommending passage. The report was
                                    concurred in.
                                Mr. MURRAY moved to recommit with instructions to amend, so that
                                    when the company come forward and tenders two-thirds of the
                                    value of the property killed or injured, and the party refuse to
                                    take it, and institute suit to recover the full value on account
                                    ofnegligence, that he shall not recover the cost of action.
                                Mr. MARCH contended there was no necessity for the adoption of
                                    the amendment.
                                The motion to recommit was rejected.
                                On motion by Mr. BOBBS, the bill was laid on the table.
                                On motion by Mr. GREEN, a resolution from the House, requesting
                                    the return of the bill H. R. 147, was considered and concurred
                                    in.
                                Mr. KINLEY, by leave, offered a resolution which was adopted,
                                    directing the Committee on Finance to incorporate in the
                                    specific appropriation bill some compensation to Professer Mills
                                    for his suggestions on the Common School system.
                                On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, Mr. Stevens' bill 192, about the public
                                    printing, was taken up, amended, and ordered to be engrossed for
                                    a third reading.
                            
                            
                                THE CALENDAR.
                                The following Senate bills were read the second time and
                                    appropriately referred:
                                Mr. Wier's 225 and Mr. Wier's 235, to the Committee on
                                        Banks.
                                Mr. March's 227, Mr. Slack's 228, and Mr.Wagner's 237, to the
                                        Committee on Finance.
                                
                                Mr. Carnahan's 226, to the Committee on
                                        Corporations.
                                Mr. Slack's 229, Mr- Shoemaker's 230, Mr. Tarkington's 232, Mr.

                                        Committee.
                                Mr. March's 236, ordered to be engrossed.
                                Mr. Craven's 238, to the Committee on
                                        Agriculture.

                                    appropriately referred:
                                No 142, referred to the Judiciary
                                    Committee.

                                Mr. STUDABAKER, by leave, introduced a bill (240) to authorize

                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
                        
                             SATURDAY, February 19, 1859. 
                        
                        Messrs. Hartley, Treadway, Shields and Sullivan had leave of absence till
                            Monday.
                        The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from James S. Athon,
                            Superintendent for the Hospital for the Insane, responding to an inquiry
                            of the House of Representatives respecting the cost of patients.
                            &c.
                        Also a communication from the Governor responding to a resolution of the
                            House of the 16th instant.
                        On motion of Mr. COLLIER, Mr. Boyd's ten minutes speech resolution was
                            taken up and adopted.
                        Mr. SCOTT asked and obtained leave to submit a resolution for night
                            session every alternate session.
                        Mr. DOUGHERTY proposed to add:
                        
                            "For the purpose of introduction and consideration
                                of bills on the first and second reading."
                        
                        Mr. CAVIN submitted an amendment byway of substitute, viz:
                        
                            "That during the remainder of the session, the
                                House of Representatives will hold evening sessions each Monday,
                                Wednesday and Friday - commencing at 7 o'clock.
                        
                        It was agreed to, and then the resolution as amended, was adopted without
                            a division.
                        Mr. REEFER made an ineffectual motion to take up the bill No. 200.
                        
                            WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
                            Mr. COLGROVE, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned his bill
                                (246), surrendering to the trustees of the Wabash and Erie Canal all
                                the right the State has to redeem the Wabash and Erie Canal,
                                &c., with amendments, [as heretofore proposed by Mr. C., with
                                one exception striking out the provision in the 4th section which
                                releases the trustees from keeping up the canal bridges,]
                            Mr. AUSTIN moved to lay the subject on the table.
                            Mr. COLGROVE, by leave, expressed a desire for engrossment and
                                printing.
                            Mr. EDWARDS, by leave, desired opportunity to consider and hear from
                                parties interested.
                            Mr. BLYTHE, by leave, desired to amend the motion by laying on the
                                table, and ordering the printing of 100 copies, but made no
                                motion.
                            The subject was laid on the table - yeas 62, nays 7.
                        
                        
                            ACTIONS WHERE THE NOTE-MAKER RESIDES.
                             On the motion of Mr. BOYD, the order of business was suspended for
                                the consideration of bills on the third reading.
                            Mr. Prosser's bill (37) to amend the 33d section of the practice act
                                of June 18, 1852, so as to provide that no suit against, the maker
                                of any note or written contract shall be commenced without the
                                county of the maker's residence, coming up - 
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, objected to the bill. It gave preference to a
                                class of defendants, and you must drag yourself and the other
                                defendants to sue where the preferred defendants reside.
                            Mr. PROSSER. It will not change the law, but only prevent fraudulent
                                assignments for jurisdiction. The jurisdiction is not removed,
                                except in cases where the note or contract has been assigned in
                                writing for the purpose of obtaining jurisdiction.
                            The bill was lost-yeas 31, nays 39as follows:

                                            Brotherton, Carr, Cavins, Clayton, Colgrove, Davis,
                                            Dougherty, Early, Fordyce, Gifford, Harrison, Jones,
                                            Jordan, Knowlton, Lawhead, Major, Mansfield, Mellett,
                                            Murray, Parks, Prosser, Row, Shockley, Shull, Thompson
                                            of Madison, Turpie, Waterman, Wildman and Mr. Speaker -
                                            31.

                                            Warren, Nelson, Ritter, Robinson, Rynerson, Scott,

                            On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, (upon a reconsideration,) the
                                regular order was resumed.
                            Mr. SHIELDS, by leave, from the Committee on Ways and
                                    Means, to which was referred that portion of the
                                Governor's message recommending the erection of a building for the
                                Supreme Court, reported a bill (297) authorizing the Governor,
                                Secretary of State and Treasurer, to receive bids for the
                                construction of such a fire-proof building, for the accommodation of
                                the Supreme Court and the several State officers, on the corner of
                                Tennessee and Washington streets, south of the State House Square -
                                the cost not to exceed $25,000, which was passed the first
                                reading.
                            Mr. HARRISON, by leave, presented the memorials of citizens and
                                lawyers of Logansport, Peru and Fulton, concerning an impeachment of
                                the Common Pleas Judge of Cass and Miami, which were referred
                                without reading to Messrs. Knowlton, Smith, of Miami, Harrison,
                                &c.
                        
                        
                            HORSE THIEF DETECTORS.
                            Mr. WILDMAN, from the Committee on Claims,
                                reported favorably on the claims of Leonard Bowers and others,
                                claiming indemnity for expenses incurred under the requisition of
                                the Governor, in detecting and recovering fugitive horse thieves, to
                                the amount of $2,000.
                            Mr. CAVINS submitted a minority report.
                            
                            On motion by Mr. COLLIER the report was laid on the table.
                            Mr. WILDMAN moved to reconsider this vote.
                            Mr. MURRAY, by leave, explained the majority report. It was not for a
                                reimbursement of money for detecting horse thieves, but for
                                reclaiming fugitives under the requisition of the Governor.
                            Mr. DAVIS. Were these petitioners concerned in the murderous hanging
                                of McDougal, in Noble county ?
                            Mr. MURRAY. No That was before this organization took place. These
                                horse thieves and black legs, in the North-west counties, became so
                                bold and formidable, that, it was almost incredible to tell of their
                                acts, and the terror they inspired. He gave examples under his
                                knowledge in Lagrange county. This organization had procured the
                                detection and imprisonment of twenty-five thieves, and there were
                                five others awaiting trial.
                            Mr. CAVINS, by leave, explained and defended the minority report. It
                                was made some time ago, and intended to apply to all this class of
                                claims, including those awarded by the House to certain claimants of
                                Marion county. They were all claims for voluntary service,
                                &c.
                            Mr. WILDMAN gave examples of the character of the organization of the
                                regulators in question - the oath required by it - the necessity for
                                itthe extent of the organization of desperadoes in Noble county and
                                elsewhere, and the success of the regulators in breaking them up.
                                Mr. McDougal was lynched before the regulators' associations were
                                organized. He regarded this as an extreme and extraordinary
                                case.
                            Mr. HUNTER opposed the allowance of these claims. He regarded these
                                regulators as a curse to any people.
                            Mr. DOBBINS made an ineffectual motion to lay the motion to
                                reconsider on the table.
                            The House then refused to reconsider - yeas 28, nays 44.
                            Mr. MURRAY hoped the House would now do themselves and all parties
                                the justice to Strike out all such allowances from the specific
                                appropriation bill.
                            Mr. GRIFFIN, from the Committee on Roads, reported upon petition, a
                                bill (298) to provide for laying out and repairing highways on the
                                line between the State of Indiana and adjoining States; which was
                                passed the first reading.
                            Mr. RYNERSON, from the Committee on Agriculture, returned the
                                committee's bill (244) to amend the 73d section of the assessment
                                act of June 21, 1852, (with reference to agricultural statistics),
                                recommending passage.
                            Mr. RYNERSON explained its provisions requiring copies of township
                                tables to be filed with County Auditor, State Auditor, and to be
                                submitted for publication in the local newspapers.
                            Mr. MILLER and Mr. PROSSER regarded the whole thing a as a
                                humbug.
                            Mr. MURRAY. It adds this to the law: It requires the assessor to tell
                                the number of acres cultivated, the amount of yield per acre, and a
                                copy of each township statement to be tendered to the local papers
                                for publication - to be printed without charge.
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, would vote for the bill if he could get out
                                that part requiring report to the Auditor of State.
                            Mr. JORDAN proposed to recommit with instructions
                            
                                "To change the present law so as to provide
                                    for the taking of such statistics but once in three years."
                            
                            Mr. MURRAY was in favor of that.
                            Mr. HARNEY was for this favorable legislation to agriculture. This
                                was the way to favor any great interest. The manufacturing and
                                mercantile interests were amply reported in this way and its
                                importance was understood. Strange that agriculturists were so
                                willing to go it blind in their business. He suggested that the
                                present imperfect statistical information gave a pretty certain
                                indication that our Indiana lands were falling off in their
                                productive value, and hence the importance to this great interest of
                                encourageing the collection of statistical information.
                            Mr. NEBEKER, of Vermillion, desired to wake up the farmers to some
                                appreciation of their interests in this direction, &c. He hoped
                                this information would be given yearly.
                            Mr. JOHNSTON moved to amend the instructions by striking out "three,"
                                and inserting "five" years.
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, moved to lay the motion and instruction on
                                the table - which was decided in the affirmative - yeas 44, nays
                                42:
                            And then the bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                            On motion of Mr. SHIELDS, the orders being suspended for the purpose,
                                it was ordered that the Clerk request the Senate to return his bill,
                                No. 147, for further consideration and amendment in the House of
                                Representatives.
                        
                        
                            NEW BILLS UNDER DISPENSATION.

                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                            NEW BILLS
                             Mr. MERRIFIELD said he desired leave to a bill to reduce the
                                salaries of public officers - not that he himself desired the
                                success of the proposition. On the contrary there was probably no
                                man on this floor who would vote to give our public officers more
                                competent salaries than he would. But because a bill had been to-day
                                introduced into the House,(the bill No.302) of which he understood
                                the history, and which he denounced as a base and cowardly attempt
                                to strike down as true a democrat as ever breathed the vital air; he
                                intended, by the introduction of this bill, that it should share the
                                same fate with that. If the State Printer was to be striken down, he
                                was determined that the friends of those aiding and abetting in the
                                act should share a similar fate.
                            Mr. CAVINS, (by leave.) In the early part of the session, before the
                                election of printer, the question arose among Republicans whether or
                                not the compensation of the Public Printer should be reduced, and
                                though nothing definite was done he distinctly remembered telling
                                his friends, Republicans and Democrats, that it mattered naught to
                                him whether Mr. Sulgrove were elected or anybody else, he was
                                determined to vote for reducing this compensation. He cared not
                                particularly about abolishing the office, but he was for reducing
                                the compensation. It was not a proposition to strike down a
                                political enemy, because it was known, he presumed, that those in
                                favor of it had been so from the first. It was supposed by some that
                                Colonel Walker's time would be out next August. He did not know as
                                to that; but if that were so,of course the proposed act should be
                                amended so as not to apply till his time shall be out. He hoped
                                those Democrats who had said, when the election was about to be
                                brought on, that they would vote for this reduction, would not now
                                retrain from doing so, for the sake of sustaining a political
                                partisan.
                            Mr. MERRIFIELD. He had referred to the bill to abolish the office of
                                State Printer.
                            The leave was accorded by consent, and Mr. Merrifield's bill (305)
                                providing for the salaries of public officers and the manner of
                                paying the game, was read and passed the first reading.
                            Mr. JORDAN, by leave, presented a statement and certificate of the

                            The special order - Mr. Shoemaker's bill No. 90 - was postponed till

                            Mr. BENNETT, by leave, returned Mr. Green's bill 41, with amendments,

                            The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be
                                engrossed.
                            Mr. ANTHONY, from the same committee, returned joint resolution No.
                                2, recommending the adoption of a resolution instructing the
                                Attorney General to bring suit and proceed to collect by due process
                                of law, all moneys due to the State from William R. Noffsinger, and
                                to collect all notes or drafts held as collateral security.
                            Mr. WILLIAMS moved to strike out the resolving clause and insert the
                                enacting clause.
                            Senators Miller, Steele, Murray and Ricespoke against, and Hamilton,
                                Studabaker, Slack and March, spoke for the resolution, and then-The
                                amendment was rejected.

                            A message from the House announced its refusal to concur in two of

                            Mr. STUD A BAKER obtained leave to vote "no" on the County and
                                Township bill. [The vote is recorded on page 208 of these Reports
                                ]

                            
                                SUPERVISORS OF HIGHWAYS.
                                Mr. Shoemaker's bill (178) providing for the election and
                                    appointment of supervisors of highways, was read the third
                                    time.
                                Mr. STUDABAKER moved to recommit the bill to a select committee
                                    of three, with instructions to add after the word "taxation" in
                                    section 20 the words "assess a tax not to exceed one and
                                    one-fourth of a cent on each acre of taxable property, for road
                                    purposes."
                                Mr. WAGNER said if this amendment was not adopted he could not
                                    vote for the bill.
                                Mr. HENDRY moved additional instructions, as follows:
                                
                                    "Strike out all that part of the bill
                                        which authorizes the County Commissioners to do the township
                                        business."
                                
                                Mr. Studabaker's motion was agreed to, by yeas 27, nays 11.
                                Mr. HENDRY withdrew his instructions.
                                Mr. SLACK renewed them.
                                Mr. JONES moved the following additional instructions:
                                Insert in the proper place: Provided, that no person shall be
                                    required to work more than two days in each year otherwise than
                                    in the payment of taxes on property.
                                Mr HENDRY sustained the motion made by Mr. Slack.
                                Mr. MURRAY said the proposition of Mr. Jones might do for the old
                                    settled portions of the State,but it would not do for the newly
                                    settled.
                                Mr. WAGNER objected to the last proposed amendment
                                Mr. JONES thought the property holders should keep the road in
                                    repair, and not let that burden fall on the poor men of the
                                    land. With this view he offered the amendment.
                                Mr. SLACK proposed to add the words "except in cases of
                                    necessity."
                                Mr. CONLEY was opposed to the amendment.
                                Mr. HAMILTON agreed with Mr. Jones, and thought land holders
                                    should keep up the roads.
                                On Mr. CONLEY'S motion the instructions proposed by Mr. Jones
                                    were laid on the table.
                                Mr. MARCH moved to amend by providing that when a party refuses
                                    to work, and judgment is obtained, it shall be collected without
                                    the benefit or the exemption laws.
                                On motion by Mr. BLAIR., the committee was further instructed to
                                    amend the law so that persons refusing to work shall pay
                                    commutation money.
                                On motion by Mr. TARKINGTON, the consideration of Mr. Warner's
                                    bill (187), was postponed till to-morrow, at 3 o'clock.
                                The PRESIDENT laid before the Senate a communication from H. Clay
                                    Gooding, "disclaiming any intention of interfering either to
                                    encourage or prevent the encounter [between his brother and Mr.
                                    Heffren on the 15th inst.] and certainly without the most remote
                                    idea of taking any personal part," which was referred to the
                                    Senate difficulty investigating committee.
                                And then the Senate took a recess till 7 o'clock, P. M.

                             REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                             By Mr. COLGROVE - Judiciary - returning the bill
                                (S. 112) amendatory of the City Corporation law, with
                                amendments:
                            The ninth section is amended so as to make the terms of office two
                                years of all the officers elect.
                            The original section made the term one year, except the Mayor and
                                City Judge, who held two years.
                            Section 17 is amended - requiring a special election to fill
                                vacancies, to be conducted in the same manner as biennial elections
                                are, instead of annual elections.
                            An additional section, after section 11, requiring Railroad Companies
                                to keep a light at the crossings, and provide a guard to prevent
                                accidents.
                            The 84th section is so amended as to prevent the city from annexing
                                contiguous territory of 5 acres or upward, used for gardening or
                                agricultural purposes, without the consent of the owner.
                            Which amendments were ordered to be engrossed, and the biil as
                                amended, to the third reading.
                            By Mr. DOUGHERTY, from the Committee on Fees and Salaries, returning
                                Mr. Devol's fee bill (211) amendatory of sections 2, 3, 4,7, 8 and 9
                                of the act of March 2, 1855, with an amendment by substitute.
                            The substitute was read.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY explained the bill. It makes but few radical changes.
                                The changes affect only Clerks, Sheriffs and Auditors. The object is
                                not so much a reduction of the fees, as to prevent abuses which have
                                grown up under the present, law. It makes reduction of the Clerk's
                                fees in business that relates to e[?]ettlement of estates and
                                guardianships. Issuing letters testamentary, are reduced from $1 to
                                75 cents - proving will, to 75 cents - qualification of
                                administrator, to 75 cents - recording claim, 25 cents examining
                                each administrator's settlement, 50 cents - examining report,
                                nothing - the Clerk to receive 25 cents for affidavit only when he
                                writes it; with other slight reductions.
                            The fees of Sheriff are not reduced. It cuts off extra allowance of
                                75 cents for summoning jury - the County Commissiner's allowance to
                                be in full. The bill corrects the abuse of Sheriffs charging 15
                                cents per mile for each convict sentenced to the State Prison at the
                                same term, instead of 15 cents for one, and 10 cents for each
                                additional convict - prescribing that all the convicts sentenced at
                                one term shall be taken at the 
                            
                        
                    
                    
                
                
                
                    BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
                    BY ARIEL & W. H. DRAPIER
                    
                        Vol. II.
                        INDIANAPOLIS, FEB. 25, 1859.
                        No. 15.
                    
                    
                        
                            same time. It prevents also the Sheriffs' fees for services performed
                                by his bailiffs and paid out of the County Treasury. It prevents
                                duplications of allowance for extra services. The bill does not
                                reduce the specific fees of the County Auditor, but aims to correct
                                abuses under the present law. It allows 5 cents for each county
                                order, for each allowance - nothing for any additional order under
                                the same allowance. It allows ten cents per 100 words for copying
                                duplicates and land descriptions - for words and figures actually
                                written in the proper column, &c. It requires the Auditor to
                                make out his quarterly itemized statement of fees, under oath - to
                                be recorded in the County Commissioner's books, and published as
                                required by law.
                            Mr. BAIRD and Mr. MELLETT moved and pleaded ineffectually for its
                                reference to the Judiciary Committee.
                            Mr. HARNEY proposed to amend the bill, by adding the following:
                            The county treasurer shall not receive more than a thousand dollars
                                when the duplicate is less than $50,000, and for each $25,000
                                additional upon the duplicates, they shall be allowed $500 for clerk
                                hire; and he shall account for all money received except his fees
                                now allowed by law. which shall not exceed in the aggregate the
                                amount specified above.
                            The amendment was adopted.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY (under a motion to reconsider) stated that it was
                                against the constitution to amend a statute, without setting forth
                                the section amended.
                            Mr. PROSSER opposed the amendment.

                                to bring it forward in a separate bill.

                                LICENSE LIQUOR LAW.
                                On the motion of Mr. MURRAY, the House took up the Senate's
                                    amendments to Mr. Mansfield's liquor bill, No. 29.
                                On motion of Mr. DOUGHERTY, the Senate's amendments were
                                    considered separately.
                                The amendments to the third section were read.
                                Mr. MANSFIELD saw now a change in the opinion of temperance men -
                                    they being now willing to take conservative ground. Place the
                                    license and the bond too high, and honest men would be slow to
                                    run the risk. One thousand dollars for license, and two thousand
                                    dollars for the bond was too high; and the securities of bad men
                                    we e generally worthless. This and the four instead of two
                                    free-hold sureties was unfavorable to the general objects and
                                    beneficent aims of the bill.
                                The four sureties amendment and the maximum of license extended
                                    to $1,000 was then concurred in.
                                The Senate's change of the maximum of the bond from $500 to
                                    $2,000 in the 3d section, was concurred in, by yeas 41, nays 39
                                    - as follows:
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            YEAS. - Messrs. Austin, Blythe,
                                                Boyd, Brotherton,Carr, Cavins, Clark, Collier,
                                                Cotton, Davidson, Devol, Fordyce, Gregory, Hall of
                                                Grant, Hall of Hush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of
                                                Wayne, Harrison, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Jones,
                                                Knowlton, Lawhead, Mellett, Murray, Martin, Nebeker
                                                of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Parks, Power,
                                                Ritter, Robinson, Scott, Shull, Thompson of Elkhart,
                                                Treadway, Whetzel, Whiteman, Wildman and Wood -
                                                41.
                                            NAYS. - Messrs Baird, Bowman,
                                                Branham, Clements, Comstock, Davis, Dobbins,
                                                Dougherty, Early, Gifford, Hancock, Harney, Jordan.
                                                Kelly, Kempf, Lewis, McLain, Major, Mansfield,
                                                Massey, Merrifield, Nelson, Newton, Prosser, Row,
                                                Sherman, Shields, Shockley, Smith of Miami, Smith of
                                                Perry, Stanfield, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of
                                                Madison, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler and Mr.
                                                Speaker. - 39.
                                        
                                    
                                
                                The further amendments affixed by the Senate were severally
                                    concurred in, without a division, excepting the amendment
                                    striking out from section 15 the clause admitting druggists to
                                    sell for medicinal purposes; and this was also concurred in by
                                    yeas 53, nays 82; and excepting also the question of concurrence
                                    in the Senate's amendment allowing the manufacturer of wine and
                                    cider from fruits grown in the State, or any other person to
                                    sell such wine and cider in any quantity, whereupon the vote

                                                Shull, Stanfield, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of
                                                Elkhart, Thompson of Madison, Treadway, Turpie,
                                                Usrey, Waterman, Whetzel and Wood. - 41.

                                                Brotherton, Clark, Claypool, Colgrove,

                                GAME LAW.
                                 Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's bill (64) to prevent the killing of
                                    wild game, &c., coming up - 
                                
                                Mr. DOUGHERTY said this was no game law - it allowed of any
                                    killing at any time, if the object was to preserve growing
                                    crops. He was willing to vote for a compromise on the question,
                                    but not for this.
                                Mr. CAVINS. I believe that all game laws are wrong - they are
                                    relicts of English aristocracy, promotive only of indolence,
                                    thrittlessness and dissipation. They are restrictions on the
                                    personal property of our citizens, that are incompatible with
                                    the spirit of Republican institutions. The amendment proposed by
                                    the bill under consideration is odious, as granting exclusive
                                    privileges to owners of lands, but not so bad as the law
                                    proposed to be amended. Therefore inasmuch as the Legislative
                                    has refused to repeal the game law, I will vote for the
                                    amendment.
                                Mr. DOUGHERTY moved, ineffectually, to lay the bill on the table
                                    - yeas 32, nays 47.
                                The vote on the final reading was then reported yeas 45, nays 34
                                    - as follows:
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            AYES - Messrs. Bowman, Boyd,
                                                Brotherton, Carr, Cavins, Clark, Clements, Collier,
