                        IN SENATE
                        
                            TUESDAY, February 22, 1859.
                        
                         Mr. WILLIAMS presented a letter from one of his constituents on the
                            subject of milk sickness, claiming to have found the cause thereof that
                            it originates from the exhalation of metalic substances in the earth,
                            and that the same effects can be produced by the feeding of a cow upon
                            bran boiled in a copper kettle.
                        On motion by Mr. BROWN, the bill (H. R. 149) fixing the time of holding
                            the Common Pleas Courts in St. Joseph, Marshall and Starke, was taken
                            up, read the third time and passed by yeas 38, nays 0.
                        On motion by Mr. STEELE, his bill (69) to prevent the circulation of the
                            withdrawn currency of the old State Bank, and to punish persons
                            violating the provisions of this act, was taken up and passed - yeas 32,
                            nays 6.
                        On motion by Mr. KINLEY, his bill (134) providing for the assessment of
                            taxes for township library purposes, was read the third time.
                        
                        Senators Turner, Line, Hill, Murray anc Bobbs, favored the bill, and
                            Senator Carnahan opposed it.
                        The bill was then passed - yeas 29, nays 9.
                        On motion by Mr. JOHNSTON, his bill (101) to authorize county treasurers
                            to assess property which may be omitted by assessors, and to legalize
                            assessments heretofore made by treasurers was read the third time and
                            passed - yeas 37 nays 0.
                        Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee returned Mr.
                            Studabaker's bill (240) to authorize Justices of the Peace, within their
                            respective counties, to administer oaths generally, and to legalize such
                            as have been made in good faith: and without fraud since the 6th day of
                            May 1853, recommending its passage. The report was concurred in.
                        On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, the bill was read the third time and passed
                            by yeas 37, nays 0.
                        Mr. BENNETT, from the same committee returned Mr. Conley's bill (176) to
                            amend sec tions 8 and 10 of the Justices' Act, approved June 9, 1852;
                            [proposing to give Justices concurrent jurisdiction to the amount of
                            $300;] recommending its indefinite postponement.
                        Mr. CONLEY urged the necessity of the passage of the bill and the
                            rejection of the report.
                        Senators Bennett, Slack, Stevens and Green favored concurrence in the
                            report
                        Senators Williams, March, Line and Johnston opposed concurrence.
                        The report of the committee was rejected - yeas 16, nays 24.
                         [A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of the
                            bill (H. R. 210) to create the 10th Judicial Circuit.]
                        Mr. JOHNSTON moved to recommit to the Judiciary Committee
                            - to so amend as to give Justices of the Peace jurisdiction on
                            all notes or written agreements for the payment of money not exceeding
                            $200.
                        Mr. SLACK made a motion to instruct the committee to amend so as to allow
                            an appeal from the Justice to the Township Trustee.
                        On motion by Mr. CONLEY this proposition was laid on the table.
                        Mr. WILLIAMS moved to instruct the committee to give Justices of the
                            Peace exclusive jurisdiction in sums of $200.
                        A division of the question was demanded.
                        Mr. Johnston's motion was agreed to.
                        Mr. Williams' motion was rejected>
                        The special order for this hour - Mr. Wagner's bill 187 - was made the
                            order for 2 o'clock today.
                        Mr. COOPER, from the Committee on the Benevolent Institutions of
                                the State, returned Mr. Turner's bill 67, recommending its
                            passage. The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be
                            engrossed.
                        Mr. HARGROVE. from the same committee, returned Mr. Bobbs' bill 52,
                            recommending that lie on the table. The report was concurred in.
                        Mr. O'BRIEN, from the same committee, returned Mr. Turner's bill 58, with
                            an amendment recommending its passage. The report was con curred in and
                            the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                        Mr. CRAVENS, from the same committee returned a Senate resolution of
                            inquiry as to the expediency of erecting an additional wing to the
                            Insane Hospital recommending that it is inexpedient at this time,
                            inasmuch as the finances of the State are embarrassed. The report was
                            concurred in.
                        Mr. SHOEMAKER, from the Committee on County and Township Business,
                            returned Mr Conley's bill 214, recommending that it lie on the table.
                            The report was concurred in.
                        Mr. STEVENS, from the Committee on Printing, returned
                            Mr. Hamilton's resolution,and Mr. Anthony's preamble and resolution of
                            inquiry on the subject of printing; also, various petitions on the same;
                            recommending that they lie on the table. The reports were concurred
                            in.
                        Mr. STUDABAKER, from the select committee thereon, returned the bill (25)
                            for the distribution of the Sinking Fund, recommending its passage with
                            the following amendments:
                        Amend 5th section as follows: insert after the word '"cancelled" the
                            words "the amount thereof, and the amount paid for the same," and add to
                            the bill the following section:
                        SEC. 15. All laws not inconsistent with this act, in regard to the
                            Sinking Fund, or giving powers to or prescribing the duties of the
                            Sinking Fund Commissioners, their officers, clerks, agents and servants,
                            or prescribing punishments again't them for malfeasance in office, that
                            were in force on the day preceding the 1st of January,1859, are hereby
                            declared to be in full force, and to apply to the present Board of
                            Sinking Fund Commissioners, and its officers clerks, agents and
                            servants, but all such laws as are inconsistent with this act are hereby
                            repealed.
                        The report was concurred in.
                        Mr. STUDABAKER moved that the bill be considered as engrossed, and read
                            the third time now.
                        Mr. BOBBS proposed to amend so us to provide as follows:
                        That the Auditor of each county shall report to the Board of
                            Commissioners of such county, at their annual meeting in March, any
                            losses the Sinking Fund distributed to such county may have sustained,
                            and which have not been secured or refunded at the time of making such
                            report; and it shall be the duty of such Commissioners to assess a tax
                            upon the taxables of such county, to reimburse said fund to the full
                            amount of such loss; and the Auditor shall place such assessment upon
                            his duplicate, and the Treasurer of the county shall collect the same as
                            the other taxes are collected for county purposes
                        Mr. STUDABAKER thought the proposition in itself may be right, but would
                            rather not see it placed in the bill at his present time.
                        Mr HAMILTON favored the amendment.
                        Mr. MURRAY, notwithstanding he was in favor of the original proposition,
                            should vote for the bill as it now is, whether this amendment be adopted
                            or not; but he insisted upon the adoption of the amendment.
                        Mr. WILLIAMS proposed as a substitute for the amendment, that when it is
                            ascertained there has been a loss, it shall be the duty of the County
                            Commissioners to pass an order upon the County Treasury for the amount
                            of such loss, unless it has occurred through the negligence or
                            misconduct of the county officers; and then they are to be held
                            responsible for such loss.
                        Mr. LINE could see no objection to the amendment. 
                        Mr. STUDABAKER proposed to raise no 
                            [se]rious objection to either of the amendments, but would prefer the
                            one submitted by Mr. Williams.
                        Mr. BOBBS accepted of the substitute, with the accountability of officers
                            stricken out - to which Mr, Williams agreed.
                        The amendment was then adopted.
                        The bill was read the third time and passed - yeas 33, nays 10, as
                            follows:
                        
                            
                                
                                    YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Blair,
                                        Brown, Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Conner, Cooper, Culver, Fisk,
                                        Green, Hamilton, Hargrove, Hendry, Hill, Johnston, Line,
                                        Lomax, McClure, McLean, March, Murray, Odell, Robinson,
                                        Shoemaker, Slack, Studabaker, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner,
                                        Williams and Wilson - 23.
                                    NAYS - Messrs. Bennett, Bobbs, Cravens,
                                        Jones, Kinley, O'Brien, Rice, Steele, Stevens and Wagner -
                                        10.
                                
                            
                        
                        The special order for 11 o'clock, being Mr. Conner's bill (212),
                            releasing the right of the State of Indiana, to redeem the Wabash and
                            Erie Canal, and granting permission to the trustees thereof to rent or
                            lease the same, was then considered.
                        Mr. CONNER occupied the floor in favor of his bill until the hour of 12,
                            when he gave way for the recess till 2.

                        
                            AFTERNOON SESSION.
                             Mr. McLEAN presented a remonstrance from certain lawyers of Terre
                                Haute, against the abolishment of the Court of Common Pleas, which
                                was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
                            Mr. CONNER resumed and concluded his remarks on his bill 212.
                            [A message from the House announced its adherence to its refusal to
                                concur in the Senate amendments to the temperance bill (H. R. 29)
                                and that Messrs. Murray, Mansfield and Dougherty, were the House
                                conferees thereon.
                            The PRESIDENT, pro tem., announced the special
                                order - Mr. Wagner's bill (178), creating six additional bank
                                districts; the question being on the amendment proposed by Mr.
                                March, as printed on page 218 of these reports.
                            Mr. ANTHONY thought it would give additional security to the bill
                                holder to increase these branches, and that it would be beneficial
                                to the interests of the State.
                            Mr. MARCH thought the increase of these branches would be an increase
                                of the powers of the Institution, whether they be for good or for
                                evil. He would not vote to give the bank additional powers, unless
                                it would consent to come under the control of the Legislature.
                            Mr. HAMILTON desired gentlemen to know that the bank does not ask for
                                this increase of its branches; and insisted that an increase of the
                                branches did not give it additional powers, but simply increased its
                                responsibilities.
                            Mr. GOODING was opposed to the bill, and thought the creation of the
                                additional branches proposed would increase the power and influence
                                ot this bank monster.
                            Mr. MURRAY objected to the amendment proposed, and contended that we
                                have no right to impose the restrictions upon the bank that are
                                contemplated in the amendment.
                            Mr. STEELE expressed himself as decidedly opposed to the amendment,
                                and if it was adopted there could be no chance of creating
                                additional brauches.
                            Mr. BENNETT moved to lay the amendments on the table.
                            Mr. STUDABAKER demanded a division of the question.
                            The first amendment - the one to section 15 - was not laid on the
                                table by yeas 17, nays 27.
                            The next amendment - the one to section 19 - was laid on the table -
                                yeas 24, nays 21.
                            The last amendment proposed by Mr. March Demanding an additional
                                section - was also laid on the table - yeas 24, nays 21.
                            The question then recurred on the adoption ot the amendment to the 15
                                th section - the one taxing banks the same as individuals.
                            Mr. STUDABAKER was willing to tax the banks for the amount of stock
                                paid in.
                            Mr. BENNETT proposed to amend by striking out the words "together
                                with the amount of their capital stock."
                            Mr. ANTHONY opposed the passage of the amendment, but would vote for
                                the bill as it is.
                            Mr. HEFFREN was opposed to the amendment, but would favor the
                                amendment to the amendment. The increase of branches would decrease
                                the profits of those already in operation.
                            Mr. MARCH objected to the amendment to the amendment, speaking at
                                length.
                            Mr. WAGNER. I like to see Senators debate a matter fairly and
                                honestly,and resort to the kind of arguments used by the Senator
                                from Delaware, who upon all occasions reports for the benefit of the
                                Senate, that same old buncombe sheech which we have all heard ever
                                since my earliest recollection. It is the same old speech against
                                banks, corporations and monopolies, and other associations to whom
                                we are indebted for all our improvements. He then gave way for a
                                motion to adjourn.
                        

                    
                    
                    
                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
                        
                            
                                TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1859.
                            
                        
                        Mr. Speaker GORDON (Mr. Davis in the Chair) moved to reconsider the vote
                            of Saturday, refusing to concur in the report of the Committee
                                on Claims adverse to the claims of certain persons in
                            Lagrange and Noble counties, to the extent of $2,000, on account of the
                            arrest of horse thieves, &c.
                        The vote was reconsidered.
                        Mr. Speaker GORDON then moved to amend the report so far as to admit of
                            the allowance of $1,000.
                        Mr. HUNTER. These claims, if paid at all, should be paid out of the
                            treasuries of the counties where the service has been performed. How
                            could this House investigate these remote cases? 
                        Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, concurred with Mr. Hunter. If this game of claims
                            was to be played upon the State Treasury, his county would come in for a
                            large share.
                        Mr. COMSTOCK. This claim was meritorious as any, but he had determined to
                            vote against the whole of them here, and leave them to their respective
                            counties.
                        Mr. Speaker GORDON replied to Mr. Hunter. That the claim was fairly
                            preferred, he argued the constitution of the Committee on Claims. The
                            gentleman's argument was striking at the very first principles of
                            justice. It was urged in forgetfulness of what is right between man and
                                 man, and the citizen and the
                            State. He spoke at length, giving examples.
                        Mr. COLGROVE considered the equity of the case. Upon what principle of
                            justice could the State be required to pay the counties for catching and
                            punishing their criminals? Why not pay all the costs - the witnesses and
                            clerks - in criminal cases?
                        Mr. MURRAY. Claims of this character had been allowed, and now when those
                            citizens of Lagrange and other northern counties come here by their
                            representatives, and ask for $1,000 of $6,000 which they have expended
                            under the Governor's requisition, where was the injustice? Such
                            allowances had been made heretofore without question.
                        Mr. MELLETT had been voting under the impression that claims of this
                            class ought not to be allowed, and he expected to continue to so
                            vote.
                        Mr. HUNTER spoke again. The allowance of claims arising out of costs in
                            criminal cases would break down the treasury of the State, &c. To
                            were wiser to have a law paying the prosecuting Attorneys and Sheriffs.
                            But such a law would be ruinous of the State finances.
                        Mr. DAVIS considered the importance of the principle of executing the
                            laws. You authorize your Governor to make requisition of fugitives from
                            other States, and then, by refusing this class of claims, yon paralyze
                            the arm of the Governor in this very thing. He would confine allowances
                            to cases oi services rendered under the Governor's requisition, &c.
                            There ought to be a remedy for the fact, that, because the State pays
                            nothing for criminal prosecutions, nearly all the talent of the bar was
                            commonly enlisted on the side of the defense.
                        Mr. THOMPSON, of Elkhart, alleged that the County Commissioners, and
                            others, in Noble, Lagrange and Steuben counties, had paid their full
                            share of the expense in these arrests of thieves and black legs. More
                            than $25,000 had been so paid. There was a man, now in this Hall, who
                            paid for this purpose a hundred dollars out of his own pocket.
                            &c.
                        Mr. SCOTT. The General Assembly might refuse to be generous, but, they
                            could not shirk the demands of Justice. He was surprised to hear
                            gentlemen declare they would not vote for any of these claims, no matter
                            how just the claim might be. Such was not the feeling that would actuate
                            him. He read names of several gentlemen whose claims, similar to these,
                            had been allowed during the present, session. It was very questionable
                            whether the County Commissioners have the right to make these
                            allowances.
                        Mr. AUSTIN moved to lay the report and amendment on the table.
                        Mr. DAVIS gave notice that, if this motion should not prevail, he would
                            move to recommit the report, &c., with instructions to inquire how
                            much had been actually expended in the case under the requisition of the
                            Governor.
                        The Clerk reported the vote - yeas 38, nays 47. So the House refused to
                            lay on the table and then - 
                        Mr. DAVIS submitted his motion to recommit with instructions.
                        It was recommitted without a division.
                        
                             THE FINANCES OF THE STATE.
                             Mr. HARNEY, (under a dispensation) from the Committee on Ways and
                                Means, returned the said committee's finance bill (195) with
                                amendments, as directed by instructions heretofore adopted by the
                                House, recommending the adoption of all the amendments except that
                                requiring the Treasurer to convert into specie all revenue received
                                by him in bank notes as fast as the same shall amount to $1,000.
                            Mr. HARNEY. The report provides for striking out from the bill all
                                that relates to County Treasurers and State Comptroller, and for
                                amending the fourth section, prescribing what moneys shall be paid
                                into the treasury, adding these words: "Eleventh.
                                All moneys arising from the sale of bank bonds or stocks deposited
                                under the provisions of the general banking law, and all moneys
                                belonging to or accruing to the State, or to any fund of the State:"
                                together with the amendment directed by the House, that whenever
                                payments shall be made into the State Treasury, in the notes of
                                solvent, specie-paying banks, to the amount of $1,000, it shall be
                                the duty of the Treasurer to convert the same into coin, by
                                presenting and demanding the specie thereon. The report recommends
                                the adoption of all but the last, which is recommended to be laid on
                                the table.
                            Mr. MURRAY moved a call of the House, and it was ordered that the
                                names of the following absentees be entered on the journal, viz:
                            Messrs. Black, Boxley, Durham, Eastham, Firestone, Hartley, Kempf,
                                Parrett, Stiles, Stinson and Sullivan.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY said the report did not embrace the instructions of Mr.
                                Robinson.
                            The SPEAKER. The instructions fall.
                            Mr. AUSTIN. The House adjourned when his instructions were
                                pending.
                            The SPEAKER. The adjournment cut them off.
                            Mr. MELLETT. The gentleman's instructions were incorporated in the
                                report amending the 13th section.
                            Mr. HARNEY demanded the previous question, and under its force, the
                                several amendments reported were adopted, and upon the
                                recommendation to lay on the table the clause requiring the bank
                                notes in the Treasury to be converted into coin, the vote stood -
                                yeas 46, nays 42.
                            So the report was concurred in, and the bill was ordered to be
                                engrossed, by yeas 51, nays 37.
                            Mr. HUNTER moved that the bill be considered as engrossed, and read
                                the third time now.
                            The motion was agreed to under the pressure of the previous question,
                                and the bill, being again read through by the Clerk, was passed the
                                final reading in the House of Representatives, by the following
                                vote:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Boyd, Branham,
                                            Brotherton, Cavins Clark, Claypool, Colgrove, Collier,
                                            Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Devol, Fordyce, Gifford,
                                            Gregory, Hall of Grant Hall of Bush, Hamilton of Boone,
                                            Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Harrison, Hunter, Jeffries,
                                            Johnston, Kempf, Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller,
                                            Murray, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of
                                            Warren, Newton, Parks, Power, Ritter, Row, Rynerson,
                                            Scott, Sherman, Shields, Smith of Miami, Smith of Perry,
                                            Stanfield, Thompson of Elkhart, Usrey, Waterman,
                                            Whetzel, Whiteman, Wildinan and Mr. Speaker - 52.
                                        
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Blythe, Bowman,
                                            Carr, Clayton, Clements, Davis, Dobbins Dougherty,
                                            Early, Hancock, Hartley, Jones, Jordan, Keefer, Kelley,
                                            Knowlton, Lawhead, Lewis, McLain, Massey, Merrifield,
                                            Nelson, Prosper, Robinson, Shockley, Shull, Snyder,
                                            Stanley, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Treadway,
                                            Turpie, Wheeler and Wood - 36.
                                    
                                
                            
                            On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the House took up the Senate's last message
                                on the disagreeing voles on the Mansfield bill, (No. 29,) and moved
                                that the House insist on its nonconcurrence in the Senate's
                                amendment to Mr. Mansfield bill, (No. 29,) admitting the
                                manufacturer of wine or cider, from fruits grown in this State, or
                                any other person, to sell such wine or cider without license.
                            Mr. MANSFIELD. The Senate had returned the bill with a number of
                                amendments. The House accepted them all except two; of which one
                                was, that the license shall be forfeited in case of any breach of
                                any of the provisions contained in the bill. The Senate has since
                                conceded that point and set it aside. The other amendment attached
                                by the Senate, and rejected by the House, was this: That not merely
                                the manufactured of wine and cider from fruits grown in this State
                                shall be permitted to sell the same in any quantity without license,
                                but "any other person." These words "any other person," were
                                objected to by the House. I understand that this amendment of the
                                Senate was adopted in a great hurry, and the gentleman who made it,
                                told me that it was not, his design to enable the manufacturers ot
                                wine and cider to keep tippling houses, but merely to encourage the
                                farmer in making these things, which are less harmfulth an whisky or
                                brandy. But now this additional clause in the bill, That it shall
                                not be drank on the premises where sold, will give us the advantage
                                in the free conference, and there is no doubt but the Senate will
                                immediately accede this mistake. I hope the House will insist, and
                                that we shall yet, be able to succeed in making this bill not merely
                                a good license law, but also a good temperance law.
                            Mr.BAIRD and Mr. AUSTIN. The Senate's amendment went only to allow
                                the manufacturer to sell.
                            Mr. HUNTER. The effect of the Senate's amendment would be to make
                                every grocery-keeper in the State a manufacturer.
                            Mr. MURRAY preferred the Committee on Free Conference.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY had submitted this clause originally, and he construed
                                it, and hoped the House would insist.
                            Mr. PROSSER concurred with Mr, Baird.
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush. There was obscurity, and laws should be so framed
                                as to avoid misconstruction.
                            The House then adhered to its amendment,and ordered the appointment
                                of a committee of free conference, which the SPEAKER makes to
                                consist of Messrs. Murray, Mansfield and Dougherty.
                            Mr. COMSTOCK, undor a dispensation, from the Committee on Roads,
                                returned Mr. Shields' bill (250), to compel County Boards to declare
                                all surveyed roads which pass through one or more counties, public
                                highways,&c., recommending indefinite postponement.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            On motion by Mr. AUSTIN, the orders being dispensed with for the
                                purpose, the House took up from the table and considered the bill
                                (S. 142) amendatory of the assessment law of 1858the question being
                                on ordering the bill to the third reading.
                            Mr. AUSTIN proposed to recommit the bill to a select committee of
                                three, with instructions to amend the 7th and 13th sections of said
                                act, which instructions were read. The act of the extra session
                                requires a description ot lands, lots. &c., "by metes and
                                bounds;" the instructions are to amend in sections 7 and 13, so as
                                to require only a general description - thus saving perhaps a
                                thousand dollars to each county in the State, and attaining all the
                                ends of the bill just as well.
                            The bill was ordered to be so referred, and the instructions agreed
                                to.
                            On motion by Mr. HUNTER, the said committee was further instructed to
                                amend the said act of 1858 in the 20th section. He said the act
                                required the County Auditor to file all these statements, for which
                                he is entitled to a fee of five cents each, and which, in a large,
                                rich county, would amount to five or six hundred dollars. He merely
                                proposed to strike out the word "file," and leave the direction,
                                "shall carefully preserve the same.
                            Mr. EARLY. The Auditor was obliged to file these statements, and the
                                gentleman might better obviate the difficulty by inserting the
                                words, "without charge."

                                THE SINKING FUND - SCHOOL LAW.
                                 Mr. BOWMAN asked and obtained a dispensation to present the
                                    following memorial from a citizen of Washington county, which
                                    was referred to the Committee on Education.
                                    It is as follows:
                                
                                    To the Honorable, the Senate and House of
                                        Representatives of the State of Indiana:
                                
                                Every man is, or ought to be, interested in whatever relates to
                                    the cause of education and science. There appears to be great
                                    diversity of opinion as to the best and safest plan of investing
                                    the Sinking Fund - the main reliance, in future, for the support
                                    of Common Schools. Your memorialist would venture, with your
                                    permission, to make one or two suggestions to your honorable
                                    body.
                                If a public debt is a public blessing and to be perpetuated for
                                    all coming time, there might be a seeming propriety in
                                    converting the Sinking Fund into State or United States bonds,
                                    but in view of the growing sentiment in favor of the speedy
                                    liquidation of all public indebtedness, and the constitutional
                                    barrier in the way of contracting new debts, except in a few
                                    specified cases of great emergency and for limited periods - it
                                    follows most conclusively, that public stocks can not furnish a
                                    reliable investment for that purpose.
                                It is not necessary to stop to consider whether the Sinking Fund
                                    might not be invested profitably and safely in bank stock,
                                    because as banks are at present organized, the people will never
                                    consent to confide a trust so sacred to their keeping.
                                What, then, shall be done with the Sinking Fund? It ought, as
                                    your memorialist believes, to be apportioned and distributed
                                    amongst the several counties of the State, on the basis of
                                    population, as may be ascertained by the next census, and loaned
                                    on mortgage of real estate, under the laws now regulating the
                                    loaning of other trust funds, when amended as follows: 
                                
                                Amend section 60, revised school law, so as to require the
                                    township trustees, alone, to appraise any land offered in
                                    mortgage.
                                Amend section 67, so as to require that the sum loaned shall not
                                    excel one-third o the appraised value of the premises proposed
                                    to be mortgaged, clear of all perishable improvements.
                                Or, let the value of all real estate offered in mortgage he
                                    determined by the County Auditor from the returns of the County
                                    Appraisers on file in his office, and allow mortgage to be
                                    executed without the signature of the wife, if surviving.
                                This plan submitted creates no new officers, involves no
                                    additional expense, places the security of the fund on a basis
                                    not to be questioned, and whatever advantages accrue from the
                                    use of the money, the people of the whole State share equally
                                    among thousands. J. I. MORRISON.
                                Salem, February 12,1859.
                            
                            
                                WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
                                 Mr. WHEELER submitted the following, which was adopted:
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            Resolved,That the Trustees of the
                                                Wabash and Erie Canal be requested to inform this
                                                House if it is probable that they can not maintain
                                                tbe Wabash and Erie Canal in navigable condition,
                                                and if so, to state the reasons why; and in that
                                                event, what legislation, in their opinion, if any,
                                                is necessary to enable them to maintain or cause to
                                                be maintained, navigation on said Canal, and whether
                                                such legislation would in any manner involve a
                                                change in the arrangement and settlement with the
                                                bond-holders, made in 1846 and in 1847.

                            FEES OF OFFICERS.
                             Mr. RICE, from the Judiciary Committee, returned
                                Mr. Shoemaker's bill 233, to regulate the fees of officers, with
                                amendments, recommending its passage.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. STUDABAKER moved to amend by inserting in the proper place
                                "except that, in counties where the Sheriff's fees do not exceed
                                $800, the County Commissioners may make such an additional allowance
                                for extra services as may appear just."
                            Senators Heffren, Green, Slack and Miller objected to the amendment,
                                and Senator Hamilton favored it.
                            The amendment was rejected.
                            Mr. GOODING moved to amend section 8 so as to provide that no County
                                Auditor shall be allowed out of the county treasury more than $1,000
                                per annum.
                            Senators Hamilton and Anthony opposed the amendment.
                            On motion by Mr. TARKINGTON, it was laid on the table.
                            Mr. SLACK moved to lay the whole subject on the table.
                            The motion was rejected - yeas 14, nays 28.
                            Mr. MARCH moved to add to the first section as follows:
                            A complete record shall not be made in any case in the Supreme Court
                                unless requested by one or both parties, and shall be paid for by
                                the party requesting it; and, if made by both parties, it shall be
                                paid for in equal proportions.
                            Mr. GOODING moved to amend section 8 by requiring the County Auditors
                                to file with the Board of County Commissioners quarterly a written
                                statement, subscribed to under oath, giving a detailed account of
                                all fees received during the quarter.

                                against the bill anyhow.

                            The motion was rejected - yeas 16, nays 27.
                            Mr. TARKINGTON opposed the amendment.

                            Mr. WILLIAMS favored the motion. 
                            The motion was agreed to.

                                THE PUBLIC PRINTING.
                                 On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the printing bill 192 was
                                    considered.
                                Mr. CONLEY thought the bill was to legislate the present State
                                    printer out of office. He was willing to reduce the prices paid
                                    for printing but would not vote for the bill because it turns
                                    the present State Printer out of office.
                                Mr. HEFFREN stated that the present State Printer goes out of
                                    office the first day of August, anyhow, for his commission only
                                    extended to that time.
                                
                                Mr. HAMILTON said he would not vote to abolish the office, but
                                    would vote to reduce the prices.
                                Mr.STUDABAKER moved to recommit the bill to a select committee,
                                    with instructions to so amend the bill as to continue the office
                                    of State printer, but to reduce the prices now paid for the
                                    public printing.
                                Mr, HEFFREN moved to lay the motion to recommit on the table.
                                The motion was agreed to-yeas 28, nays 16.
                                Mr. STUDABAKER moved to recommit with instructions to strike out
                                    section 10.
                                Mr. SLACK moved, as additional instructions, to amend so that the
                                    superintendence of the pubic printing, the binding and
                                    distributing of the laws be let to the lowest bidder.
                                Mr. MURRAY demanded the previous question.
                                There being a second, under its operation, the motion to recommit
                                    was lost - yeas 16, nays 29; and the bill passed by yeas 31,
                                    nays 14 - as follows:
                                
                                    
                                        
                                            YEAS - Messrs. Beeson, Bennett,
                                                Blair, Bobbs, Brown. Conner, Cooper Cravens, Craven,
                                                Culver, Green, Heffren, Hendry, Hill,
                                                Johnston,Kinley, Lomax, McClure, March, Murray,
                                                Odell, Rice, Robinson, Shoemaker, Steele, Stevens,
                                                Tarkington, Thompson, Turner, Wanner and Williams -
                                                31.
                                            NAYS - Messrs. Carnahan, Cobb,
                                                Conley, Fisk, Gooding, Hamilton, Hargrove, Jones,
                                                Line, McLean. Miller, Slack, Studabaker and Wilson -
                                                14.
                                        
                                    
                                
                                Mr. GOODING makes the following explanation of his vote: Mr.
                                    President, it is well known to this Senate that I favor a great,
                                    reduction of the prices paid the State Printer, and would so
                                    vote, but I can not now consent to abolish the office, believing
                                    as I do that personal reasons and political considerations have
                                    prompted this attempt to abolish the office after the election
                                    of Colonel John C. Walker, a Democrat. Again, I say that I am
                                    anxious to reduce the costs of State printing at least thirty
                                    three per cent., and would have voted to abolish the office
                                    before the election, but, neither party seemed willing at that
                                    time. I say now let us reduce the prices, but
                                    not abolish the office. Another objection to this bill is, that
                                    I fear the object is to establish at the Capital an
                                    office-holders' organ to take charge of the Democratic party,
                                    the State Sentinel having lost its character
                                    and power as a Democratic paper.
                                Mr. McLEAN makes the following explanation of his vote: He
                                    opposed the bill from the belief that under its provisions there
                                    would be more abuses than under the present law - that under its
                                    provisions it would cost the State as much to do the public
                                    printing as under the existing laws. This has been the
                                    experience of other States which have let out the printing to
                                    the lowest bidders. If the present law is defective, and the
                                    cost of printing under its provisions is too high, let the law
                                    be amended or modified and the cost of printing reduced. Under
                                    the law proposed the letting out of the printing would be a
                                    matter of personal or partisan favoritism with foe Secretary of
                                    State, who has charge of it, and as such he should oppose the
                                    bill under consideration.
                                So the bill passed the Senate.
                            
                            
                                WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
                                On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, the bill (212) releasing the right of
                                    the State to redeem the Wabash and Erie Canal, was
                                    considered.
                                On motion by Mr. CONNER a communication from the Attorney
                                    General, giving as his legal opinion on the bill under
                                    consideration that there was nothing in it which could be
                                    construed to make the State liable, was read by the
                                    Secretary.
                                On motion by Mr. STEELE it was ordered to be spread upon the
                                    journal.
                                Mr. LINE moved to amend Mr. Carnahan's motion on page 217 of
                                    these reports by inserting a provision that if any person or
                                    persons shall take the canal and fail to keep up the bridges,
                                    the State shall not be bound to pay for the bulling or repairing
                                    of said bridges.
                                Mr. CRAVENS [Mr. Wagner in the Chair] spoke against the bill, not
                                    that he opposed it in principle, but because he apprehended the
                                    provisions of the bill were such as would bring upon the State
                                    many and complicated difficulties.
                                [ A message from the Governor announced his approval and
                                    signature of the bills (H. R 16) defining misdemeanors; (H. R.
                                    20) prohibiting the carrying of concealed weapons; (H. R. 259)
                                    changing the time of holding the Courts of Common Pleas in the
                                    counties of St. Joseph, Marshall and Stark, and (H. R. 27)
                                    authorizing road companies to consolidate their stock with
                                    similar companies]
                                Mr. RICE wished to be heard briefly upon the bill under
                                    consideration - as no subject of legislation affected his
                                    constituents more vitally than the question of maintaining the Wabash and Erie Canal, and while he
                                    was opposed here and elsewhere to appropriating one cent out of
                                    the State Treasury for such purposes - and while he was also
                                    opposed to the passage of any law, which would in the slightes
                                    degree involve the State in any liability to the the Bondholders
                                    for that portion of our public debt which was discharged by the
                                    transfer of the Wabash and Erie Canal - yet he was in favor of
                                    and his constituents asked of this Legislature such legislation
                                    as would prevent that great work traversing the the State
                                    diagonally from north-east to south west, a distance of some
                                    three hundred and eighty miles, and that, too, through the
                                    richest and fairest portion of the State, from abandonment and
                                    general ruin. And while the bill under consideration vigilantly
                                    guarded the interests of the State, it provided the needful
                                    legislation for the mantainance of the Canal. He could not see
                                    the force or pertinence of the objections to the bill the idea that the State, by relinquishing the
                                    right of redemption of the Canal, thereby incurred or revived
                                    the original debt liquidated by its transfer, seemed to him
                                    preposterous and absurd. He did not so understand the law. or
                                    common sense, as applied to the business transactions of life.
                                    He discussed the bill by sections, and was in favor of its
                                    general provisions. He further proceeded to show how his
                                    constituents would be effected by the abandonment of the Canal.
                                    This work passed through the entire length of his county - a
                                    distance of more than thirty five miles-and at least one million
                                    of bushels grain were shipped annually from his county upon the
                                    Canal. During the suspension of navigation last summer, when his constituents had
                                    to de end upon the railroad for the transportation of their
                                    grain, they had to pay three cents additional to Canal
                                    transportation - this item of three cents per bushel, would lose
                                    to his constituents some thirty thousand dollars - then the
                                    additional expense of hauling one half millions of bushels of
                                    grain to the railroad, would be at least five cents per bushel,
                                    which-would make some twenty-five thousand dollars more- These
                                    two items would make some fifty-five thousand dollars, which his
                                    constituents would lose annually by the abandonment of the
                                    Canal. The Canal traversed some fourteen counties, and he
                                    supposed his to be an average - then multiply the above sum by
                                    fourteen, and you have the enormous sum of more than three
                                    quarters of a million o dollars that these counties would lose
                                    annually by the abandonment of the Canal. These considerations
                                    he urged upon the consideration of the Senate, and particularly
                                    upon those Senators who were not immediately interested.

                                            YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson,
                                                Bennett, Cobb, Cooper. Cravens, Culver, Gooding,
                                                Green, Hendry, Jones, Line, McLean, March, Murray,
                                                Rice, Robinson. Steele, Studabaker, Thompson,
                                                Turner, Wagner, and Wilson - 23.
                                            NAYS - Messrs. Brown, Carnahan,
                                                Conner, Fisk, Hamilton, Hargrove, Heffron, Johnston,
                                                Kinley, Lornax, McClure, Miller, O'Brien, Odell,
                                                Shoemaker, Slack, Stevens, and Tarkington - 18.
                                        
                                    
                                

                                 Mr. GOODING makes the following explanation of his vote: Mr.
                                    President, I shall now vote for this bill, regarding it as the
                                    only chance of obtaining any law at this session. Rather than go
                                    home and leave the State and the people without any law to
                                    protect them from the evils of intemperance, I will vote for any
                                    constitutional bill on this subject, however objectionable some
                                    of its unimportant i may be.
                                One objection I have to the bill is prohibiting the sale of cider
                                    or native wine by another person than the manufacturer, in less
                                    quantity than one gallon. I do not indorse or approve the bill,
                                    but only support it between the unrestricted sale of liquor
                                    consequent evils, and this bill with its imperfections.
                                 Mr. TURNER makes the following explanation of his vote:
                                Mr. President - It is well known that I have uncompromisingly
                                    opposed this bill from the first, but there are some provisions
                                    in the bill that I heartily approve of, while the main portions
                                    of it I as heartily oppose. Believing, as I do, that traffic in
                                    intoxicating liquors is a great moral as well as political evil,
                                    fostering pauperism, misery and crime, and producing more evil
                                    than any or all other crimes known in this or perhaps any other
                                    country, I could not, under any circumstances, lend my influence
                                    to legalize so great a wrong; and believing that this provision
                                    is not wrong in itself, but calculated to make the bill more
                                    acceptable to the temperance people of Indiana. Believing that
                                    if it fails now, it willbe impossible to pass any Temperance Law
                                    this session; I, therefore, solemnly protesting against the
                                    right of any Legislature to license a moral evil, reluctantly
                                    vote "aye."
                                The PRESIDENT pro tempore decided that the bill
                                    should be yet read through and passed by yeas and nays.
                                Mr. MURRAY appealed from the decision of the Chair
                                Mr. SLACK moved to lay the appeal on the table.
                                The motion was rejected - yeas 13, nays 29.
                                The question being shall the decision of the Chair stand as the
                                    judgment of the Senate? It, was not so decided yeas - 20, nays
                                    23.
                                Mr. HEFFREN gave notice of a protest against such ruling
                                On motion of Mr MCLEAN the Wabash and Erie Canal bill (212),
                                    [described on page 179 of these Reports] was taken up.
                            
                        
                    
                    
                    

                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
                        
                             WEDNESDAY, February 23, 1859. 
                        
                        
                            REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                             Mr. STANFIELD submitted the following:
                            Mr. Speaker - The Committee on the Judiciary, to
                                whom House bill 261, to amend section 77 of an act to revise,
                                simplify and abridge the rules of practice and pleadings, &c.,
                                so as to prevent sham pleadings, have had the same under
                                consideration, and directed me to report the same hack and recommend
                                its passage. Cases arise in the Common Pleas Court where great
                                injustice is done by reason of the merest sham and trickery in
                                pleading, that ought not to be tolerated in any court, yet as the
                                law is now held, the court is powerless over such pleading. Take a
                                case like this, an action is brought in that court to recover a
                                judgment on a promissory note; the defendant appears and answers
                                that the note was given to the plaintiff for a tract of land and
                                that he had no title to it, whereby the consideration of the note
                                had failed. The answer, if true, would be good, but it is wholly
                                false. The note was given for personal property, yet the plaintiff
                                must reply and deny the defendant's answer. That bringing into
                                question the title to real estate, the court is ousted of
                                jurisdiction. The plaintiff must dismiss his action, pay the costs
                                and suffer the delay, and all this because that court has no power
                                over false and knavish pleading.
                            By Mr. STANFIELD from same committee reporting that Mr. Cotton's bill
                                (274), for  fencing square No.
                                25 in the town of Indianapolis, and adopting the same for a
                                State-house site, is inexpedient, and recommend indefinite
                                postponement.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            He also returned Mr. Blythe's bill (281) providing for the

                             RIGHT OF REDEMPTION.
                            On the motion of Mr. GRIFFIN, the vote of this morning, laying his
                                bill No. 32 on the table, was reconsidered, to enable him to submit
                                a minority report thereon from the Judiciary
                                    Committee, which he read, reasoning at length against
                                the adverse report of the majority, and in favor of the bill:
                            This bill proposes that when real estate is sold on execution, or
                                order of sale, the judgment debtor may have one year to redeem it by
                                paying to the purchaser six per cent, interest and six per cent,
                                penalty, and if the debtor fails to redeem in that time any other
                                judgment creditor may redeem it in three months thereafter - and the
                                officer or person selling the same is to give a certificate of
                                purchase to the purchaser, which is assignable by indorsement in
                                writing, in the same way that a note or bill of exchange is
                                assignable. It also gives the purchase the possession of real
                                estate, and makes him accountable for waste. It thus affords an easy
                                and legal means whereby money may he invested at 12 per cent., and
                                at the same time gives the debtor an opportunity to save himself
                                from ruin should the land not be redeemed at the end of 15 months
                                from the day of sale Upon the presentation of the certificate the
                                officer who sold the same or his representative, is to make a deed,
                                which is final. This is a provision that has been on the statutes of
                                Illinois for twenty years, and Ohio nearly as long. This bill will
                                serve as a temporary relief to the debtor under our present
                                financial crisis.
                            Messrs. Baird, Merrifield and Colgrove opposed the bill; and Messrs.
                                Nebeker, of Warren and Griffin defended the provisions of the
                                bill.
                            
                            The bill was again laid on the table - yeas 48, nays 34as
                                follows:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Baird, Blythe, Bowman,

                             THE FINANCES OF THE STATE.
                            On motion by Mr. HUNTER, the Embezzlement bill No. 192, of the series
                                of bills reported from the Committee on Ways and
                                    Means, was taken up.
                            Mr. SMITH, of Perry, from said committee, in obedience to what was
                                understood to be the instructions of the House, reported an
                                amendment striking out that which relates to County Treasurers.
                            Mr. STANFIELD trusted the House would not strike out. If the
                                provision were just, it should apply to all public officers
                                alike.
                            Mr. COLGROVE concurred with Mr. S.
                            Mr. TURPIE hoped a felony would not be created for such causes, and
                                especially in such terms as embodied in this bill. It made it a
                                felony for a public officer to deposit the public moneys with his
                                wife, as it might be, &c.
                            Mr. SMITH, of Perry. The committee were satisfied with the bill as it
                                is, &c. The object of the amendment was not to disturb the right
                                of the County Treasurers to use or loan the county funds, leaving
                                him to his local responsibility, and to confine the felony to
                                officers of State. We want to stop this system of loaning the funds
                                of the State, whether with fraudulent intention or not. These moneys
                                belong to the State, and should be kept in the hands of their legal
                                custodians.
                            On motion by Mr. TURPIE, the bill and pending amendment were referred
                                to the Committee on the Judiciary.

                            Mr. AUSTIN, from the select committee on the Senate assessment bill
                                (S. 142), returned the same with the amendments embraced in the
                                instructions adopted yesterday, and so amended, he recommended the
                                passage of the bill.
                            The amendments were adopted.
                            Mr. STANFIELD proposed to amend by striking out from the first
                                section all after the word "situation" in the 43d line, and
                                inserting:
                            That the appraiser, in estimating the value of such railroads, plank
                                roads, &c., shall take into consideration the location of the
                                same for business, the amount of its gross and net earnings, and the
                                condition of such roads for present and future business, so as to
                                enable him to arrive at the true value of such roads, without
                                reference to their cost or indebtedness.
                            Mr. STANFIELD. The assessment act of the extra session treats this
                                property as real estate. This bill repeals that act so far as the
                                road beds and iron on the track are concerned, and hence the
                                necessity for this amendment. The difficulty was to equalize
                                appraisements, and there was not now time to perfect a system, and
                                in the mean time he considered the amendment the best that could be
                                done.
                            Mr. BRANHAM submitted that a fair value could not be attained where
                                the roads are not entirely within our own State. His plan would be
                                to compel the valuation of the road as a whole, and distribute it
                                among the counties in proportion to the distance run, subject to the
                                revision of the Board of Equalization. He contended for the
                                principle of the act of 1852, and gave examples.
                            On motion by Mr. STANFIELD, the bill and amendment were referred to
                                the Judiciary Committee.
