                        HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
                        
                             FRIDAY, February 25, 1859. 
                        
                        
                            PETITIONS.
                            By Mr. KNOWLTON: memorial of the city of Logansport, for legislation
                                in regard to the power of such city to change, alter, amend or
                                terminate such city government, which was referred to Messrs.
                                Knowlton, BIythe and Davis.
                            By Mr. SNYDER: of E. M. Chord, and others, of Jasper county, for a
                                certain State road, in Jasper county, south of Renssellaer, &c.,
                                which was referred to the Committee on Roads.
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY, from the Committee on Fees and
                                    Salaries, returned Mr. Devol's amended bill (211)
                                relative to the fees of Clerks and Treasurers, recommending passage,
                                and that the instructions referred lie on the table.
                            The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be
                                engrossed.
                            Mr. COMSTOCK, from the Committee on Agriculture,
                                reported (upon petitions referred,) in favor of the passage of an
                                act, authorizing commutation money for working the roads, &c.,
                                and in connection therewith - 
                            Mr. HARTLEY had leave to introduce a bill (No. 332) to amend the 10th
                                section of the act to provide for the election of Supervisors of
                                highways, and prescribing the duties of county and township officers
                                in relation thereto, which was passed the first reading. [It
                                authorizes commutation for working the roads; when judgement is
                                obtained for neglecting to work, no exemption or appraisement laws
                                shall prevent collection, &c.]
                            Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, submitted the following, which was
                                adopted.
                            
                                
                                    
                                        WHEREAS, It is believed that large
                                            sums of money are, and have been due the State Treasury
                                            for different lengths of time, from different persons,
                                            who have heretofore held State and County offices, and
                                            from banks and individuals as drawers and indorsee of
                                            bills of exchange or otherwise; which seems are in
                                            danger of being lost by the statute of limitation or
                                            otherwise. Therefore, be it
                                        Resolved, By the Senate and and House of
                                                Representatives of the State of Indiana, That
                                            the Auditor of State be instructed to ascertain without
                                            delay, and as near as possible the exact amount legally
                                            due the State Treasury from every person who has
                                            heretofore been an officer, agent or trustee, of any
                                            funds rightfully belonging to State, from every source,
                                            and in like manner the amount that may be due the state
                                            from any bank corporation or company, or from any
                                            individual for money had or received, or as drawer or
                                            indorser of any note, debt or bill of exchange in favor
                                            of the State that has been protested for non-payment,
                                            and to make an immediate demand from such ex-officer,
                                            agents, trustees, or companies for the amounts
                                            respectively found due from each; and in case of failure
                                            or refusal to pay the same, to make out a certified copy
                                            of the amount due from such ex-officers, agents
                                            trustees, person or persons, banks or corporations, or
                                            companies, so failing or refusing to pay, and to place
                                            the same in the hands of the Attorney General, who is
                                            hereby instructed to bring suit for the recovery of the
                                            same without delay.

                                returned sundry papers on the subject of accepting the Congressional
                                donation of public lands [20,000 acres to each Representative and
                                Senator in Congess, and 20,000 acres to each Representative to which
                                the State shall be entitled under the next census and apportionment
                                to each of the land States, and the same proportionate amount in
                                land scrip to the States in which there is no public land,] to be
                                applied to the erection of colleges for the encouragement of
                                agriculture and the mechanic arts - and reported two bills founded
                                thereon, entitled:
                            A bill (No. 333), accepting on the part of the State of Indiana,
                                certain public lands, donated to such States of the Union as shall
                                accept and provide for the erection of colleges for the support of
                                agriculture and the mechanic arts, and providing for notice of the
                                same to be given by the Governor of the State to the Secretary of
                                the Interior:
                            A bill (334), defining the duties of the Auditor and Treasurer of
                                State in the management and security of the trusts arising from the
                                donation of certain public lands for the erection of colleges for
                                the encouragement of Agriculture and the mechanic arts, and
                                providing for the election of a Board of Regents for the government
                                of  such institution , and
                                defining their powers and duties, &c.
                            Which were passed the first reading.
                            Mr. MANSFIELD, from the Committee on Education,
                                reported on the petition from Sullivan county, with reference to the
                                return of the $188,000 of the School Fund in the State's hands, and
                                the distribution of the Sinking Fund among the counties, with
                                information that the Committee on Ways and Means
                                were engaged on a bill for the return of said fund.
                            Mr. BLACK, from the select committee thereon, returned Mr. Knowlton's
                                bill (278), fixing court time in the 11th Judicial Circuit,
                                recommending indefinite postponement.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. SHERMAN, from the select, committee on Mr. Collier's bill (310),
                                to regulate the practice of Medicine and Surgery, returned the same
                                with verbal amendments, recommending passage.
                            The amended bill was ordered to be engrossed.
                             Mr. RITTER, from the same committee, returned Mr. Kempf's bill
                                (312), prohibiting unqualified persons from practicing the science
                                of Medicine and Surgery, and the Pharmaceutical Art, recommending
                                that it be laid on the table.
                            The report was concurred in.
                            Mr. DOBBINS, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill
                                (304), with an amendment by substitute.
                            The amendment was adopted, and the bill, as amended was ordered to be
                                engrossed.
                            Mr. CARR, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill (314),
                                to repeal the 73d section of the assessment act of 1852, with a
                                favorable recommendation.
                            It was ordered to engrossment.
                            Mr. CAVINS, from the select committee thereon, returned Mr. Hunter's
                                bill (125) for protection of railroad tracks, &c., with
                                amendments comformable to instructions reported yesterday. 
                            The amendments were adopted and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. STILES, from the Committee on Corporations,
                                returned Mr. Edward's bill (269), concerning enclosures, trespassing
                                animals, fence enclosing railroads, &c , with an amendment,
                                adding these words:
                            Provided, That whenever any fence shall be destroyed by fire
                                communicated by any locomotive, the same shall be rebuilt by the
                                railroad company owning such locomotive.
                            The amendment was adopted and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
                            On motion by Mr. STANFIELD, the bill was considered as engrossed and
                                put upon its final reading.
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, objected to the farmer being compelled to
                                keep up half the fence. It was a scheme to avoid railroad
                                responsibility, &c.
                            Mr. PARKS concurred with Mr. H.
                             Mr. BRANHAM'S experience and knowledge in the case, was that more
                                stock was killed where the railroad was fenced. Assuredly railroad
                                men would not kill stock if they could help it. It was the jeopardy
                                of lives, and the loss in costs and damages on their part. There was
                                the best, guarantee in the world that engineers would not run over
                                stock if they can help it. This bill allowed the farmer to enclose
                                up to the track itself. It gave no immunity for killing stock. It
                                was directly for the advantage of the farmer adjoining the track.
                                Stock killed generally belongs, not to those adjoining the track,
                                but to trespassers beyond. Why not give the company the same right
                                accorded to individuals, &c.?
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone. We do treat railroads as individuals. We tell
                                them to keep a good and sufficient fence around their unruly engine.
                                The bill, makes the owner of the field or enclosure a partner in the
                                fence, and so relieves the road from the responsibility for killing
                                stock, because the fence is not kept up.
                            Mr. MANSFIELD considered the development of the resources of the
                                country by railroads, and the duty of the Legislature to assume the
                                effort or the company to avoid running over stock. He claimed that
                                the provision of the bill requiring the farmer to keep up one-half
                                the fence, was simply what is right between man and man, &c.
                            Mr. KEEFER. The bill would compel the farmer to join in keeping up a
                                fence for the track through his field, whether he desired to do so
                                or not.
                            Mr. BRANHAM. Such was not the intention.
                            Mr. MURRAY. By the present, law the railroad is compelled to
                                fence.
                            He could not vote for a bill that would compel the farmer to keep up
                                half the fence.
                            Mr. POWER. If the gentleman was right, he could not vote for such a
                                bill.
                            Mr. EDWARDS asked unanimous consent to enable him to amend the bill
                                as follows:
                            
                                "Provided, That where any
                                    railroad runs through an enclosure, the company owning it shall
                                    build the fence thereof through such enclosure, and maintain the
                                    same at its own proper expense."
                            
                            He said the sole object of the bill was to have the fence kept in
                                repair, for the security of life and property. That was the object
                                of the bill, without this proposed amendment.
                            Mr. HALL, of Rush, was willing to extend even handed justice to the
                                roads. The amendment, of the gentleman from Vigo obviated all the
                                difficulty in his mind.
                            Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, moved to recommit, with instructions to amend
                                as proposed by the gentleman from Vigo, which he subsequently
                                withdrew.
                            Mr. SULLIVAN moved to lay on the table; but withdrew the motion for
                                the final vote on the bill without the Amendment, which resulted
                                yeas 50, nays 42.
                            So the bill failed for lack of a constitutional majority: and then - 
                            On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, the bill was recommitted to Messrs.
                                Edwards, Branham, Parrett, Jeffries and Gregory, with the above
                                instructions submitted by him
                            Mr. DOUGHERTY, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill
                                (321) declaring it usury for banks to charge for exchange,
                                recommending passage.
                            It was ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. CLEMENTS, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill
                                (313) fixing the salaries of the Trustees of the Wabash and Erie  Canal, without amendment,
                                recommending passage.
                            It was ordered to be engrossed.
                            Mr. MARTIN, from the select committee thereon, returned the bill (S.
                                102) redistricting the State for Common Pleas purposes, with an
                                amendment by substitute (21 districts, judge's salary $1,000 -
                                repealing sections 29 and 38 of the Common Pleas act.)
                            The amendment was ordered to be engrossed, and the bill passed to the
                                third reading.
                            On motion by Mr. MARTIN, the amendments were considered as
                                engrossed
                            Mr. SHULL proposed to recommit with instructions to strike out
                                "1,000" and insert "500."
                            Mr. DAVIS. It was impossible to make all the districts acceptable.
                                The bill would save $15,000 a year. Against his habit, he was almost
                                ready to move the previous question.
                            Mr. AUSTIN proposed to amend the instructions by striking out "$500"
                                and insert "$1,200-" He said: The argument against the present
                                Common Pleas system has been that the present, salary is
                                insufficient to secure men of competent ability to discharge the
                                duties. I submit then whether, when we increase the labors, to
                                double the present, and only increase the salary two hundred
                                dollars, will it not bring the system into disrepute. I desire that
                                the amendment be made, that I may be able to vote for the bill;
                                without it, I will be compelled to vote against it.
                            Mr. MURRAY demanded the previous question, and under its force, the
                                amendments to the instructions were rejected, the House refused to
                                recommit, and the bill, as amended, passed the House o
                                Representatives - yeas 69, nays 25 - as follows:

                                            Boxley, Brotherton, Carr, Cavins, Clark, Clements,

                            Mr. EDWARDS, from the select committee thereon, returned the bill No.

                                it runs through an enclosure the railroad pays all the expense of
                                construction and repairs.
                            The amendment was adopted and ordered to be engrossed.

                                strip of his grounds to keep up one-half of the fence also.

                                SUPERVISOR'S ACT
                                 Mr. Massey's bill (77), to revise the Supervisor's act, coming
                                    up - 
                                Mr. MASSEY asked unanimous consent to amend the bill so as to
                                    make it conform to the one township trustee system; but Mr.
                                    Comstock and Mr. Prosser objected - asking if the only object
                                    was to make the bill conform to the one trustee system.
                                Mr. MASSEY. That is the only object.
                                Mr. COMSTOCK withdrew his objections.
                                Mr. HALL, of Rush, moved ineffectually, to refer with
                                    instructions.
                                Mr. RYNERSON moved to recommit with instructions to inquire into
                                    the expediency of amending as proposed by Mr. Massey.
                                Mr. CLEMENTS feared there was not time to refer again. He desired
                                    the passage of the bill.
                                Mr. BOYD proposed to amend the instructions to strike out all
                                    that relates to taxation to keep up the roads.
                                Mr. COMSTOCK. The bill proposes an imperative tax of five cents
                                    on the $100. This was a discrimination in favor of the poor.
                                Mr. BOYD. Still it was a double tax upon labor and upon
                                    property.
                                Mr. DOBBINS defended the imperative tax.
                                Mr. PROSSER withdrew his objections.
                                Mr. MURRAY. This bill had been matured with care, and he hoped
                                    that it would be allowed to pass, with conformity to the change
                                    to the trustee system.
                                Mr. HALL, of Rush, considered the powers of the supervisors for
                                    assessment should be limited to 10 or 12 cents on the $100, and
                                    that some limit should be fixed as to the number of days a man
                                    may be called out
                                Mr. PARKS wished to have the tax apportioned to the real estate
                                    of the districts.
                                On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the motion to recommit, &c., was
                                    laid on the table.
                                Mr. KNOWLTON demanded the previous question, and there was a
                                    second, but - 
                                On motion by Mr. CLEMENTS, it was reconsidered, and the amendment
                                    was withdrawn.
                                Mr. CLEMENTS now hoped the amendments of Mr. Massey would be
                                    adopted by unanimous consent. ["No consent."]
                                On motion by Mr. ROBINSON, the vote on engrossment was
                                    reconsidered.
                                Mr. ROBINSON moved to recommit the bill.
                                On motion by Mr. SHULL, that motion was laid on the table.
                                On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, Mr. Massey's amendments were
                                    taken from the table, and adopted, and then - 
                                The bill was again considered as engrossed, (as now amended , and
                                    passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas
                                    is 56, nays 34 - as follows:

                        IN SENATE.
                        
                             SATURDAY, February 26, 1859. 
                        
                         On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the reading of the journal was dispensed
                            with.
                        
                            REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
                            Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee, returned Mr. Heffren's bill
                                106, recommending passage. Also, the petition of John Zount,
                                recommending that it lie on the table.
                            Mr. ANTHONY, from the same committee, returned Mr. Robinson's bill
                                239, recommending passage. Also, Mr. Tarkington's, 232, recommending
                                indefinite postponement.
                            Mr. CONNER, from the Committee on Corporations,
                                returned his bill 252, recommending passage.
                            Mr. BLAIR, from the same committee, returned his bill 14, Mr.
                                Carnahan's bill 9, and a memorial from Posey and Vanderburg counties
                                praying for a more uniform mode of doing township business,
                                recommending that they lie on the table.
                            Mr. LOMAX, from the Committee on Rights and
                                    privileges, returned his bill 190,recommending
                                passage.
                            Mr. GREEN, from a select committee thereon, returned bis bills 243
                                and 244, recommending passage.
                            These reports were severally concurred in.
                            Mr. SHOEMAKER, from the  Committee on Roads,
                                returned Mr. Turner's bill (221) empowering supervisors of highways
                                to keep in repair roads which have been changed by the construction
                                or running of railroads, recommending passage.
                            The bill, on motion, was read the third time and passed, by yeas 28,
                                nays 11.
                            Mr. BOBBS, from a select committee thereon, returnee. Mr. Odell's
                                bill 222, with amendments, recommending passage.
                            Mr. RICE, from a select committee thereon, returned Mr. Wagner's
                                bill, 249, recommending passage.
                            Which reports were concurred in.
                            Mr. MARCH, by leave, introduced a bill (259) to prohibit persons from
                                preventing, hindering or delaying specie payments by the banks of
                                thia State.
                        
                        
                            THE PUBLICATION OF LAWS.
                             Mr. JONES moved to reconsider the vote taken last night on the
                                passage of Mr. Conner's bill (166) providing for the publication of
                                laws, [described on page 138 of these reports.]
                            Mr. JOHNSTON was in favor of reconsidering the vote. He thought it
                                would be a great expense with no comparative benefit resulting
                                therefrom.
                            Mr. GREEN opposed reconsideration.
                            Mr. CONNER explained the provisions of his bill. He was willing to
                                publish the laws in more than one paper in each county, if the
                                Senate would consent; but if we cannot have that, let us have the
                                act passed by the Senate last night.
                            Mr. MILLER voted against the law last, might, but he has since become
                                satisfied it is right,and should vote against reconsideration.
                            Mr. HEFFREN moved to lay the motion on the table.
                            The motion was agreed to, by yeas 22, nays 18 - as follows:
                            
                                
                                    
                                        YEAS - Messrs. Beeson, Bermett, Blair,
                                            Carnahan, Conley. Conner, Craven, Culver, Fisk, Green,
                                            Heffren, Hendry, Kinley, McClure, McLean, Miller,
                                            Murray, Odell, Rice, Slack, Steele and Stevens - 22
                                        NAYS - Messrs. Anthony, Bobbs, Brown,
                                            Cobb, Gooding, Hamilton, Hargrove, Johnston, Jones,
                                            Line, Lomax, Robinson. Shoemaker, Thompson, Turner,
                                            Wagner, Williams and Wilson - 18.
                                    
                                
                            
                             The select committee thereon, returned the petition of the
                                Cumberland Presbyterian and Plymouth Congregational Church, praying
                                for the use of the Senate Chamber on Sundays, during the recess of
                                the Legislature; recommending the adoption of a resolution granting
                                the prayer of said petitioners.
                            The resolution was adopted, by yeas 29, nays 15.
                            A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of
                                Mr. Slack's bill (255), to provide for the application of any
                                surplus that may remain in the hands of the Auditor of State after
                                the redemption of the circulation of any bank, or banking
                                association where such bank or banking association has received on
                                deposit money belonging to the State, and has failed to pay the
                                same.
